Title: Emphasizing the interdependence of topics in required undergraduate electrical engineering courses: A case study
Source title: Conference Record - IEEE Instrumentation and Measurement Technology Conference
Affiliations: Kansas State Univ, Manhattan, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dyer, S.A., Kansas State Univ, Manhattan, United States; Dyer, R.A., Kansas State Univ, Manhattan, United States
Abstract: During Fall Semester 1996 at Kansas State University, the authors carried out an experiment in teaching. The experiment involved Circuit Theory II and Electronics I, two core lecture courses in both the electrical engineering and the computer engineering curricula, which are normally taken concurrently. The basic approach to Electronics I was altered from a strict lecture format, with introductory material on solid-state electronics, two- and three-terminal solid-state devices, and basic electronic circuits, to a combination lecture/discussion/laboratory/design-and-management experience. In Electronics I, we placed emphasis on review and assimilation of topics covered in previous courses, as well as topics covered concurrently in the Circuit Theory II course. We used a `discovery' approach to the presentation of the subject matter, and we formed an imaginary company, with each student being both an engineer and a middle-level manager. Our company's goal was to produce a regulated dual-tracking power supply, which provided the vehicle for applying the basic subject matter of Electronics I. In addition, we addressed issues in scheduling, human resources, purchasing, procurement, financial management, marketing, customer/design-team interaction, public relations, publicity, intracompany communications, technical writing, engineering design, fabrication, manufacturing, CAD, graphics arts, test and measurement, and quality assurance. We present a brief summary of the experience.
Index Keywords: Computer aided design; Computer aided manufacturing; Electrical engineering; Electronics engineering; Graphic methods; Industrial management; Marketing; Networks (circuits); Purchasing; Quality assurance; Scheduling; Solid state devices; Automobile manufacture; Circuit theory; Computer aided design; Curricula; Electric power systems; Public relations; Quality assurance; Scheduling; Solid state devices; Teaching; Vehicle to vehicle communications; Dual tracking power supply; Intercompany communications; Engineering education; Education; Computer engineering curricula; Electrical engineering course; Engineering design; Financial managements; Kansas State University; Solid state electronics; Subject matters; Test and measurement

Title: Development of highly reliable control systems for the gas-insulated switchgear
Affiliations: Chubu Electric Power Co., Inc., Nagoya, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Mizuno, K., Chubu Electric Power Co., Inc., Nagoya, Japan
Abstract: In recent years, microprocessor-based control, protection and monitoring devices, such as digital relays and diagnostic systems, are applied to electric power fields. The Highly Reliable Control Systems (HRCS) based on microprocessor techniques for the gas-insulated switchgear (GIS) have been developed. The HRCS for the GIS uses the programmable logic controller (PLC), solid-state electronics and optical sensors as a replacement for conventional hard wired electromechanical control circuits which improves reliability and availability of the GIS control circuits. This paper introduces the results of verification tests together with the principle of the HRCS. Also reported is application to the high voltage substation. Objectives: The HRCS is designed according to the following objectives. • Improvement in the reliability of operation: to prevent misand non-operation of the tripping command, even if the mis-operation or damage occurs in one of the system; to prevent mis-operation by the control command, even if the mis-operation or damage occurs in one of the systems • Observation of any failures in the system resulting from the mis- or non-operation • An increase of maintainability • A significant electromagnetic compatibility because the system is installed near primary equipment. Configurations and Features: Figure 1 shows the system configuration of the HRCS for GIS. A programmable logic controller (PLC) is used in the control, supervision circuits, and furthermore an automatic monitoring function is provided. A logic circuit with combined semiconductors is in the drive circuits that amplifies the PLC output. Optical position sensors with self diagnosis are used for the switch status detection. The outdoor bay is constructed so as to have one panel per GIS circuit. Countermeasures for Outdoor Installation Reliability: In order to protect the electronic devices for outdoors in the HV substation, considerations against environmental factors such as high and low temperature, humidity, dust and salt contamination, and further Countermeasures against noise generated in the HV substation such as switching surges, lightning surges and radio wave noise were taken for the HRCS. Stability against environmental factors and noise immunity, and long-term performance were confirmed by various verification tests. Conclusions: The following conclusions were obtained from the development and results of verification tests conducted with the systems. • Microprocessor-based control system using PLCs, solid-state electronics and optical sensors has been confirmed to have high reliability for outdoor installation. • The systems have not only a high reliability but also self-diagnosis and maintainability. • The systems have been operating without failures in severe environmental conditions and electromagnetic conditions of the HV substation.
Correspondence Address: Mizuno, K.; Chubu Electric Power Co., Inc., Nagoya, Japan

Authors: Nakajima Anri, Futatsugi Toshiro, Kosemura Kinjiro, Fukano Tetsu, Yokoyama Naoki
Title: Room temperature operation of Si single-electron memory with self-aligned floating dot gate
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting
Affiliations: Fujitsu Lab, Ltd, Atsugi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nakajima, Anri, Fujitsu Lab, Ltd, Atsugi, Japan; Futatsugi, Toshiro, Fujitsu Lab, Ltd, Atsugi, Japan; Kosemura, Kinjiro, Fujitsu Lab, Ltd, Atsugi, Japan; Fukano, Tetsu, Fujitsu Lab, Ltd, Atsugi, Japan; Yokoyama, Naoki, Fujitsu Lab, Ltd, Atsugi, Japan
Abstract: Single-electron devices utilizing the Coulomb blockade effect are promising candidates for becoming the basic elements of future solid-state electronics. To develop these devices into commercial products, room temperature operation capabilities and a Si construct are necessary. This paper reports on a new Si single-electron memory device comprised of a narrow channel field effect transistor (FET) having an ultra-small self-aligned floating dot gate and its ability to exhibit clear, single-electron memory effects at room temperature.

Authors: Miyamoto J., Amos N., Gobbi B., Knoll G.F., Knoll G.F., Neal H., Oesch L., Rubinov P.
Title: Passivation of micro-strip gas chambers with an interstitial germanium coating
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium & Medical Imaging Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States
Authors with affiliations: Miyamoto, J., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Amos, N., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Gobbi, B., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Knoll, G.F., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Knoll, G.F., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Neal, H., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Oesch, L., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Rubinov, P., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States
Abstract: Micro-strip gas chambers (MSGCs) were constructed in the Solid-State Electronics Lab of the Univ of Michigan and their performance was studied. Many efforts have been made in the past to construct MSGCs that yield high absolute gas gain and stable gas gain. Introducing a thin germanium layer has been effective for passivation but difficulties associated with the poor adhesiveness of the thin layer have been a serious obstacle. This paper reports on a new method used to overcome these difficulties. Unlike the conventional coating method the thin germanium layer was successfully deposited between the strip lines. This technique requires a careful geometric alignment of a second photomask with the original micro-strip structure. The resulting detector performance was noteworthy and an absolute gas gain of 2·104 was easily achieved by the new chamber. The chamber's gain instability was also reduced significantly compared with those without interstitial coating.
Index Keywords: Gain control; Germanium; Masks; Metallizing; Microstrip devices; Passivation; System stability; Interstitial germanium coatings; Microstrip gas chambers (MSGC); Particle detectors

Authors: Mizuno K., Tsutsumi M., Matsumura M., Yagi Y.
Title: Development of highly reliable control systems for the gas-insulated switchgear
Affiliations: Chubu Electric Power Co.,Inc., Nagoya, Japan; Fuji Electric Co.,Ltd., Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Mizuno, K., Chubu Electric Power Co.,Inc., Nagoya, Japan; Tsutsumi, M., Fuji Electric Co.,Ltd., Tokyo, Japan; Matsumura, M., Fuji Electric Co.,Ltd., Tokyo, Japan; Yagi, Y., Fuji Electric Co.,Ltd., Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: In recent years, microprocessor - based control, protection and monitoring devices, such as digital relays and diagnostic systems, are applied to electric power fields. The Highly Reliable Control Systems (HRCS) based on microprocessor techniques for the gas - insulated switchgear(GIS) have been developed. From the results of the recent CIGRE circuit breaker reliability survey, the need for improving the reliability of switchgear control circuits is presented. The HRCS for the GIS uses the programmable logic controller(PLC), solid-state electronics and optical sensors as a replacement for conventional hard-wired electromechanical control circuits which improves reliability and availability of the GIS control circuits. The HRCS has been verified and applied to the substation. This paper introduces the results of verification tests together with the principle of the HRCS. Also reported is application to the high voltage substation. © 1995 IEEE.

Title: Time-resolved fluorescence spectroscopy for chemical sensors
Affiliations: Institut für Experimentalphysik, Karl-Franzens Universität, Universitätsplatz 5, Graz, A-8010, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Draxler, S., Institut für Experimentalphysik, Karl-Franzens Universität, Universitätsplatz 5, Graz, A-8010, Australia; Lippitsch, M.E., Institut für Experimentalphysik, Karl-Franzens Universität, Universitätsplatz 5, Graz, A-8010, Australia
Abstract: A family of sensors is presented with fluorescence decay-time measurements used as the sensing technique. The concept is to take a single fluorophore with a suitably long fluorescence decay time as the basic building block for numerous different sensors. Analyte recognition can be performed by different functional groups that are necessary for selective interaction with the analyte. To achieve this, the principle of excited-state electron transfer is applied with pyrene as the fluorophore. Therefore the same instrumentation based on a small, ambient air-nitrogen laser and solid-state electronics can be used to measure different analytes, for example, oxygen, pH, carbon dioxide, potassium, ammonium, lead, cadmium, zinc, and phosphate. © 1996 Optical Society of America.
Author Keywords: Anions; Carbon dioxide; Cations; Fluorescence lifetime; Oxygen; Ph; Potassium; Ptical sensors

Authors: Gulyaev Yu.V., Kurskij V.N., Proklov V.V., Sindler Yu.B., Fedorov S.A., Shtykov V.V.
Title: A design conception of cellular mobile communication system so the multiple access with code-time sharing on the basis of solid signal processors
Authors with affiliations: Gulyaev, Yu.V.; Kurskij, V.N.; Proklov, V.V.; Sindler, Yu.B.; Fedorov, S.A.; Shtykov, V.V.
Abstract: A design conception of a novel type of the cellular mobile broadband communication system with the multiple access and code-time sharing of the user signals based on the solid-state electronics is developed and substantiated. Application of the solid-state acoustoelectronic and acoustooptical processors of complex signals with the high processing speed, small dimensions and energy consumption allows to considerably extend the frequency band of the used signals in the cellular radio systems with code sharing.
Index Keywords: Acoustooptical devices; Channel capacity; Design; Radio telephone; Solid state devices; Code-time sharing; Signal processors; Cellular radio systems

Title: The birth and early childhood of active matrix - A personal memoir
Source title: Journal of the Society for Information Display
Affiliations: SID; Active-Matrix Associates, 5823 Kentucky Ave., Pittsburgh, PA 15232, United States; University of London; Westinghouse Research Laboratories; Thin Film Device Department; Panelvision Corporation; Magnascreen Corporation; Active Matrix Associates
Authors with affiliations: Brody, T.P., SID, Active-Matrix Associates, 5823 Kentucky Ave., Pittsburgh, PA 15232, United States, University of London, Westinghouse Research Laboratories, Thin Film Device Department, Panelvision Corporation, Magnascreen Corporation, Active Matrix Associates
Abstract: The genesis and evolution of the concept of active matrix and its reduction to practice at Westinghouse Labs in the early '70s is recounted from a personal viewpoint by the author, who was manager of the thin-film projects at the time. The story is continued beyond Westinghouse's abandonment of the project to the formation in 1981 of Panelvision, the first AMLCD company, and ends in 1985 when Panelvision was sold and Japanese companies assumed their present dominant position in the market. A postscript expresses views of the author on the future of active-matrix displays.

Authors: Hewett C.A., Taylor M.J., Zeidler J.R., Geis M.W.
Title: Specific contact resistance measurements of ohmic contacts to semiconducting diamond
Affiliations: Naval Command, Control and Ocean Surveillance Center, RDT and e Division, 49285 Bennett Street RM 111, San Diego, CA 92152-5790, United States; Naval Command, Control and Ocean Surveillance Center, RDT and e Division, 53570 Silvergate Avenue, San Diego, CA 92152-5070, United States; Lincoln Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Lexington, MA 02173, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hewett, C.A., Naval Command, Control and Ocean Surveillance Center, RDT and e Division, 49285 Bennett Street RM 111, San Diego, CA 92152-5790, United States; Taylor, M.J., Naval Command, Control and Ocean Surveillance Center, RDT and e Division, 49285 Bennett Street RM 111, San Diego, CA 92152-5790, United States; Zeidler, J.R., Naval Command, Control and Ocean Surveillance Center, RDT and e Division, 53570 Silvergate Avenue, San Diego, CA 92152-5070, United States; Geis, M.W., Lincoln Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Lexington, MA 02173, United States
Abstract: A simplified version of the specific contact resistance measurement scheme of G. K. Reeves [Solid State Electronics 23, 487 (1980)] has been developed. Its applicability to semiconducting diamond is demonstrated using four sample types: epitaxial films doped to mid 1019 acceptors/cm3 on 〈100〉 and 〈110〉 type IIa substrates; type IIb diamonds 0.25 mm thick, and type IIb diamonds thinned to 0.035-0.05 mm thick. The ohmic contacts were based on a solid-state annealing process using carbide forming metals. The measured specific contact resistance depends mainly on the doping level in the diamond. Measured values ranged from 8×10-6 Ω cm2 for heavily doped films to 1×10-2 Ω cm2 for lightly doped bulk samples. A simple analysis shows that the contacts to highly doped layers are suitable for device applications. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Title: Novel 3-axis monolithic silicon accelerometer
Source title: International Conference on Solid-State Sensors and Actuators, and Eurosensors IX, Proceedings
Affiliations: Chalmers Univ of Technology, Goterborg, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Andersson, Gert I., Chalmers Univ of Technology, Goterborg, Sweden
Abstract: Working prototypes of a novel 3-axis monolithic silicon accelerometer [1] have been manufactured at Chalmers University of Technology in co-operation with Saab Combitech AB and the Department of Solid State Electronics. Experience from the prototypes is most encouraging as they have confirmed the theoretical predictions of negligible cross-axis sensitivity. The accuracy in the separation of an arbitrary directed acceleration into acceleration vectors in a Cartesian system of coordinates has shown to be high almost beyond expectation. The accelerometer has good potential to develop into a low cost 3-axis accelerometer in the 0-2 g range with a resolution of about 10 mg. This in part due to the simple manufacturing process.

Title: Two-channel waveguide modulator based on surface wave propagating in a semiconductor-metal thin-film structure
Source title: Applied Physics A Materials Science & Processing
Affiliations: Kharkov State University and Scientific Center for Physical Technologies, 2 Novgorodskaya Street, 93, Kharkov, 310145, Ukraine; Department of Physics and Technology, Kharkov State University, 4 Svobody Square, Kharkov, 310077, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Ostrikov, K.N., Kharkov State University and Scientific Center for Physical Technologies, 2 Novgorodskaya Street, 93, Kharkov, 310145, Ukraine; Osmayev, O.A., Kharkov State University and Scientific Center for Physical Technologies, 2 Novgorodskaya Street, 93, Kharkov, 310145, Ukraine; Azarenkov, N.A., Department of Physics and Technology, Kharkov State University, 4 Svobody Square, Kharkov, 310077, Ukraine
Abstract: The results of theoretical investigations of two-channel waveguide modulator based on Surface Wave (SW) propagation are presented. The structure studied consists of two n-type semiconductor waveguide channels separated from each other by a dielectric gap and coated by a metal. The SW propagates at the semiconductormetal interface across an external magnetic field which is parallel to the interface. An external de voltage is applied to the metal surface of one channel to provide a small phase shift between two propagating modes. In a coupled mode approximation, two possible regimes of operation of the structure, namely as a directional coupler and as an electro-optical modulator, are considered. Our results suggest new applications in millimeter and submillimeter wave solid-state electronics and integrated optics. © 1995 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Motorola / Arizona State University - an experiment towards industrial/academic excellence
Affiliations: Motorola, Inc, Mesa, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hall, Edward L., Motorola, Inc, Mesa, United States
Abstract: In August, 1994, Motorola and Arizona State University entered into a partnering arrangement, new to both groups, in which Motorola placed a full time employee at ASU to co-direct a university research center, the Center for Solid State Electronics Research (CSSER). In this paper, the details of this two year 'experiment' between ASU and Motorola are presented. After giving a brief introduction, the Center for Solid State Electronics Research is described. Responsibilities for the industrial co-director and metrics for success, both from ASU's perspective and from Motorola's perspective are then given. Specific examples of improved linkages and accomplishments are illustrated. Finally, observations for the first nine months are presented and some future directions are outlined.
Index Keywords: Engineering education; Engineering research; Microelectronics; Personnel; Research and development management; Societies and institutions; Solid state electronics research; Solid state microelectronics; Semiconductor devices

Title: A D&T Roundtable Low-Power Design
Source title: ieee design and test of computers
Abstract: Low power has emerged as a prinicipal theme in today's electronics industry. Many market segments, from portable electronics to high-end computers, drive the need for lower power systems. This need has caused a major paradigm shift in that power dissipation is now as important a consideration as performance and area. There are several approaches to reducing power, however, the highest return on investment approach is through designing for low power. Unfortunately, it adds another dimension to the already complex design problem: Designs must be optimized for power as well as performance and area. In a roundtable held last June at the Design Automation Conference in San Francisco, participants reviewed various strategies and methodologies for designing low-pov/er circuits and systems. They discussed the many issues facing designers at architectural, logic, circuit, and device levels and presented some approaches that might overcome these difficulties. They also highlighted future challenges that must be met to design low-power, high-performance systems. D&T thanks participants John Hines (USAF Wright Laboratory, Solid-State Electronics Directorate), Uming Ko (Texas Instruments), Stephen Meier (Synopsys inc.), Simon Napper (Epic Design Technology), Kaushik Roy (Purdue University), and moderator Massoud Pedram (University of Southern California). ACM and SIGDA officers Robert A. Walker and Jim Cohoon, and D&T Editor-in-Chief Ken Wagner also attended. ACM SIGDA sponsored the roundtable, and the Design Automation Conference provided the facilities. Kaushik Roy (as D&T Roundtable editor) organized the event, and Sudip Nag (Xilinx) was the photographer. © 1995 IEEE

Title: Low-cost motor protection becomes reality in the 1990s
Authors with affiliations: Babb, Michael
Abstract: Sophisticated electronic motor overload protection devices have been around for many years and for good reason. They do an excellent job of safeguarding three phase induction motors, the workhorses of industrial production. The trouble with electronic overloads is, they cost a lot of money. Manufacturers of electromechanical control equipment have been struggling for some time to bring down the cost of this high-tech style of electronic but this has proven to be quite a challenge. However, undaunted by the technical difficulties, several US manufacturers pushed ahead and introduced solid state overload relays in 1991. Since then, control manufacturers are shifting their attention to solid state electronics.

Authors: Minehan W.T., Weidner W.K., Jensen R.J., Spielberger R.K., Jacobsen W.F., Speerschneider C.J.
Title: Fabrication, assembly, and characterization of stacked multichip modules using hot pressed, co-fired aluminum nitride
Source title: Proceedings of the 1994 International Conference on Multichip Modules, MCM 1994
Affiliations: Coors Electronic Package Company, Chattanooga, TN  37405, United States; Honeywell Solid State Electronics Center, Plymouth, MN  55441, United States
Authors with affiliations: Minehan, W.T., Coors Electronic Package Company, Chattanooga, TN  37405, United States; Weidner, W.K., Coors Electronic Package Company, Chattanooga, TN  37405, United States; Jensen, R.J., Honeywell Solid State Electronics Center, Plymouth, MN  55441, United States; Spielberger, R.K., Honeywell Solid State Electronics Center, Plymouth, MN  55441, United States; Jacobsen, W.F., Honeywell Solid State Electronics Center, Plymouth, MN  55441, United States; Speerschneider, C.J., Honeywell Solid State Electronics Center, Plymouth, MN  55441, United States
Abstract: A three-dimensional interconnect structure utilizing MCM-C technology is currently being developed by Honeywell Solid State Electronics Center (SSEC) and Coors Electronic Package Company. This concept involves the stacking of double sided co-fired aluminum nitride (AIN) MCMs. The double sided MCMs are stacked vertically using solder attached co-fired AIN spacer bars that have been manufactured with metallized through vias and have been designed to incorporate all electrical interconnection within the ceramic. The spacer bar acts as a thermal and electrical interconnect between substrates. Prototypes are currently being produced and evaluated for thermal, electrical, and mechanical integrity. Two technology characterization vehicles (TCVs) have been designed and constructed; the first TCV contains 6 metal layers and sites for wirebond, tape automated bonding (TAB), and flip chip mounting. A second characterization vehicle contains 15 metal planes and additional electrical characterization features. This paper will discuss the fabrication and assembly of the two TCVs. This Three-Dimensional Interconnect Structures Program is being funded by Naval Command, Control and Ocean Surveillance Center (NCCOSC). Title: Natural Lightning
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States
Authors with affiliations: Uman, M.A., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States
Abstract: The present understanding of natural lightning is reviewed. Recent research on lightning has been motivated, in part, by the need to protect advanced ground-based and airborne systems that utilize low voltage, solid-state electronics; by the desire to prevent spectacular accidents, such as occurred in 1969 during the launch of Apollo 12 and in 1987 during the launch of Atlas-Centaur 67; and by the desire to elucidate the physics of one of nature's most impressive phenomena. © 1994 IEEE
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Clouds; Control systems; Electric discharges; Electric equipment protection; Electric fields; Electric power systems; Electric properties; Electronic equipment; Thunderstorms; Airborne systems; Charge structure; Electric dipole; Electrical structure; Ground based systems; Natural lightning; Solid state electronics; Thundercloud; Lightning
Funding Details: National Science Foundation, NSF: Am-9014084

Title: Semiconductor electronics and the birth of the modern science of surfaces
Affiliations: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gatos, H.C., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States
Abstract: Semiconductor surfaces were the launching platform for the solid state electronic revolution. The brilliant concept of surface states led directly to the discovery of the transistor in 1947. The chemical instability of the Ge surfaces, however, rendered the new devices irreproducible and unstable. This threat to the viability of semiconductor electronics, precipitated an international search, of a magnitude unparalleled in the history of science and technology, directed at the understanding and controlling of semiconductor surfaces. The roots of all of today's powerful experimental tools, techniques, procedures and fundamental concepts at the disposal of surface science and engineering can be traced to that gigantic effort on the study of semiconductor surfaces. Clearly, solid state electronics, born and nurtured on semiconductor surfaces, gave, in turn, birth to the modern science of all surfaces. In this article, I attempt to convey a general impression of the mutually constructive interplay between the evolution of solid state electronics on the one hand and surface science and engineering on the other. I take this opportunity to highlight my own experiences and research involvement with semiconductor surfaces. © 1994.
Index Keywords: Engineering research; Microelectronics; Semiconductor device manufacture; Semiconductor materials; Surface science; Surfaces

Title: Development of small diameter in-line MFL inspection tools: a technical challenge
Source title: Proceedings of the International Offshore and Polar Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Pipetronix Ltd, Scarborough, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Loursen, Poul, Pipetronix Ltd, Scarborough, Canada; Atherton, David, Pipetronix Ltd, Scarborough, Canada
Abstract: Magnetic Flux Leakage is the most cost effective inspection method currently used. There is now a significant demand for tools with diameters from 100 to 305 mm. The challenge in designing these small tools is to fit therm within a pipe whose cross section may be 25 times smaller than for larger tools. The tool may also have to negotiate bends with radii as small as 1.5 pipe diameters, so trains with up to ten sections coupled with flexible links have been developed. Custom state-of-the-art solid state electronics is used for sensing devices, data acquisition and storage systems, together with high performance magnetic materials and the latest, most powerful magnets.
Index Keywords: Fluxmeters; Inspection; Magnetic leakage; Magnetic variables measurement; Intelligent pipeline inspection; Magnetic flux leakage; Small diameter tools; Pipelines
Correspondence Address: Loursen, Poul; Pipetronix Ltd, Scarborough, Canada
Sponsors: ISOPE;OMPEC;KSNAJ
Publisher: Publ by Int Soc of Offshore and Polar Engineerns (ISOPE), Golden, CO, United States

Title: Verilog library development using cadence central delay calculator
Source title: Proceedings of the 1994 International Verilog HDL Conference
Affiliations: Solid State Electronics Cent, Plymouth, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Phong X., Solid State Electronics Cent, Plymouth, United States
Abstract: The Honeywell Solid State Electronics Center (SSEC) is a semiconductor supplier that offers a variety of products and services such as sensors, memories and ASIC libraries and toolkits. The Honeywell rad-hard RICMOS ASIC libraries have traditionally been based on the Mentor platform, but recently, an effort was undertaken to develop a Verilog capability for customers who wanted to use Verilog. This paper will outline the Verilog design methodology developed by Honeywell, and how the Verilog library development effort used new tools such as the new Cadence Central Delay Calculator to implement the timing simulation and back-annotation capabilities.
Index Keywords: Computer aided software engineering; Computer simulation; Computer simulation languages; Computer software; Data structures; Database systems; Digital computers; Mathematical instruments; Timing circuits; User interfaces; Back annotation capabilities; Cadence central delay calculator; Standard delay format file; Timing simulation; Verilog library; Computer hardware description languages

Authors: Scarpetti R.D., Hofer W.W., Kania D.R., Schoenbach K.H., Joshi R.P., Molina C., Brinkmann R.P.
Title: High power, electron-beam induced switching in diamond
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference - Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States
Authors with affiliations: Scarpetti, R.D., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States; Hofer, W.W., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States; Kania, D.R., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States; Schoenbach, K.H., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States; Joshi, R.P., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States; Molina, C., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States; Brinkmann, R.P., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States
Abstract: We are developing a high voltage, high average power, electron-beam controlled diamond switch that could significantly impact high power solid-state electronics in industrial and defense applications. An electron-beam controlled thin-film diamond could switch well over 100 kW average power at MHz frequencies, greater than 5 kV, and with high efficiency. This performance is due to the excellent thermal and electronic properties of diamond, the high efficiency achieved with electron beam control, and the demonstrated effectiveness of microchannel cooling. Our electron beam penetration depth measurements agree with our Monte-Carlo calculations. We have not observed electron beam damage in diamond for beam energies up to 150 keV. In this paper we describe our experimental and calculational results and research objectives.
Index Keywords: Electron beams; Electronic properties; Monte Carlo methods; Semiconducting diamonds; Thermodynamic properties; Thin film devices; Electron beam controlled diamond switch; Electron beam penetration depth measurements; Microchannel cooling; Electric switches

Title: Models and simulation for analysis of a computer network
Source title: Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States
Authors with affiliations: McAfee Jr., L.C., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States
Abstract: Computer communication networks are becoming common items in office and manufacturing environments. Electrical component characteristics and network operation are understood by a small number of engineers and designers with knowledge about communication networks. This lack of widespread knowledge was recognized when a high-speed computer communication network was being installed in the integrated circuit (IC) fabrication facility in the Solid-State Electronics Laboratory (SSEL) at The University of Michigan. At a reasonable cost, it was not possible to independently verify a proper design for that facility. To develop a capability to analyze computer communication networks, two important methods were developed: (1) a model parameter extraction algorithm for network components and (2) a simulation algorithm to analyze electrical operation of an overall network. The model parameter extraction algorithm is crucial to the success of this effort. The model parameter extraction algorithm is based on a consistent mathematical formulation of multi-port models to represent the real-world situation of components with several input/output ports, and components that have specifications cited in terms of attenuation losses. The extraction algorithm has been used to compute model parameters for components having 1 port to 10 ports. The extracted model parameters are then placed in the network analysis simulation algorithm to compute characteristics for the complete network. The simulator includes automated input of the computer network description with component specifications, internal models of computer network components, automatic equation generation, equation solution methods, and output (display) of electrical operational characteristics of the computer network. The simulator has been used to analyze the network characteristics of the SSEL IC facility and other networks, including a generic computer network that was developed to exercise and validate all formulated models in the simulator. The important results of this article are: (1) a simulation algorithm to analyze computer communication networks using internal models of components, (2) an algorithm for model parameter extraction for the components of the networks, and (3) analysis of sample computer networks to validate the models, the model parameter extraction algorithms, and the simulation algorithm.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computer simulation; Data communication systems; Electric losses; Electric network analysis; Electric network parameters; Integrated circuit layout; Integrated circuit manufacture; Mathematical models; Network components; Parameter estimation; Systems analysis; Attenuation losses; Integrated circuit fabrication facility; Model parameter extraction algorithm; Multi port models; Network analysis simulation algorithm; Computer networks
Correspondence Address: McAfee Jr., L.C.; Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States
Sponsors: Wayne State University;IEEE Circuits and Systems Society
Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, United States
Conference name: Proceedings of the 36th Midwest Symposium on Circuits and Systems

Title: Low-temperature solid-state electronic absorption Fourier transform spectroscopy
Affiliations: Department of Applied Science, City Polytechnic of Hong Kong, Tat Chee Avenue, Kowloon, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Tanner, P., Department of Applied Science, City Polytechnic of Hong Kong, Tat Chee Avenue, Kowloon, Hong Kong; Krishnan, J., Department of Applied Science, City Polytechnic of Hong Kong, Tat Chee Avenue, Kowloon, Hong Kong
Abstract: The study of inorganic solid-state electronic and vibronic transitions at low temperatures, by a wide-range Fourier transform spectrometer, covering the range 150 to 47,500 cm-1, with a resolution between 0.5 and 2.0 cm-1, is described. The types of electronic transitions of molecular ions are given, and the link between calculation and experimental measurement is highlighted. Factors contributing to the linewidths in solidstate electronic absorption spectrometry are identified. The instrumental techniques for sample preparation and the recording of spectra at low temperature are described, together with parameters affecting the resolution, precision, and calibration of a Fourier transform instrument. Problems which may arise from sample heating, spectrum fringing, aliasing, and the operation of spectrum subtraction are discussed. Some applications of the Fourier transform spectrometer are presented. © 1993 Society for Applied Spectroscopy.
Author Keywords: Absorption; FT spectrometry; Low temperature
Index Keywords: Electronic transition; Fourier transform spectrometers; Fourier transform spectroscopy; Instrumental techniques; Low temperatures; Solid state electronics; Spectrum subtractions; Vi-bronic transitions; Absorption; Bolometers; Spacecraft instruments; Spectrometers; Temperature; Absorption spectroscopy

Title: New nontraditional materials for opto-and microelectronics
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Institute of Semiconductors, Ukrainian Academy of Sciences, Kiev, 252650, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Svechnikov, S.V., Institute of Semiconductors, Ukrainian Academy of Sciences, Kiev, 252650, Ukraine
Abstract: Non-traditional materials for solid-state electronics such as porous silicon, perovskites, electrides, conducting polymers whose structure imperfections and peculiar features of the structure are responsible for their unusual properties, are considered in this paper. Their distinctive characteristics, features of the structure, methods of fabrication have been presented. An outline of their properties and possible applications in micro-and optoelectronics are reported. The fundamental character of the cluster structure is emphasized, as an example, quasicrystals and fullerens are used. COPYRIGHT © SPIE. Downloading of the abstract is permitted for personal use only.

Title: Germanium
Affiliations: AT&T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, New Jersey, United States
Authors with affiliations: Becker, R., AT&T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, New Jersey, United States
Abstract: This chapter discusses that while silicon has dominated the solid-state electronics industry, as the semiconductor of choice, for device applications for more than 30 years, it is interesting to recall that the first transistor was constructed of germanium. Both germanium and silicon are indirect gap materials with otherwise remarkably similar band structure. Germanium forms tetrahedrally coordinated covalent bonds and takes the diamond crystal structure in its solid phase, like both carbon and silicon. Germanium has a lower melting point than silicon, 937°C versus 1410°C. Scientific and commercial interest in germanium has been increasing as heteroepitaxial growth methods improve resulting in attractive Ge-Si alloy structures with applications in bandgap engineering for optoelectronic devices. The chapter discusses that since the introduction of the vacuum tunneling microscope, a wide variety of germanium surfaces have been imaged by a growing number of investigators. While the number of experiments has been less than that for silicon, as in other fields of surface science, the scope has been nearly as great, with the major features of both clean and adsorbate-covered germanium surfaces brought to light. Recent experiments in the heteroepitaxy of germanium on silicon show that interest in this material is increasing, after taking a second seat to silicon in basic investigations for many years. © 1993, Academic Press Inc.

Title: Ultranac - The new programmable image converter framing camera - A review of Recent developments and applications
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Imco Electro-Optics Ltd., 14-16 Saffron Court, Southfields Industrial Park, Basildon, Essex, SS15 6SS, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Riches, M.J., Imco Electro-Optics Ltd., 14-16 Saffron Court, Southfields Industrial Park, Basildon, Essex, SS15 6SS, United Kingdom; Garfield, B.R.C., Imco Electro-Optics Ltd., 14-16 Saffron Court, Southfields Industrial Park, Basildon, Essex, SS15 6SS, United Kingdom
Abstract: Recent advancements in the Ultranac camera are described. The camera incorporates all solid state electronics which are used to drive the all metal/ceramic image converter tube. Individual exposure and inter-frame times are fully programmable via an external computer. A review is made of the applications in which Ultranac is being employed - these include combustion studies, particle flow, ballistics and detonation phenomena. © 1993 SPIE. All rights reserved.

Title: Natural lightning
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Industrial and Commercial Power Systems Technical Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Florida, Gainesville, FL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Uman, Martin A., Univ of Florida, Gainesville, FL, United States
Abstract: The present understanding of natural lightning is reviewed. Recent research on lightning has been motivated, in part, by the need to protect advanced ground-based and airborne systems that utilize low voltage, solid-state electronics: by the desire to prevent spectacular accidents, such as occurred in 1969 during the launch of Apollo 12 and in 1987 during the launch of Atlas-Centaur 67; and by the desire to elucidate the physics of one of nature's most spectacular phenomena.

Authors: Taur Y., Hsu C.H., Wu B., Kiehl R., Davari B., Shahidi G.
Title: Saturation transconductance of deep-submicron-channel MOSFETs
Affiliations: IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Authors with affiliations: Taur, Y., IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Hsu, C.H., IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Wu, B., IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Kiehl, R., IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Davari, B., IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Shahidi, G., IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Abstract: A new method is described for extracting electron and hole saturation velocities from saturation currents of deep-submicron-channel N- and PMOSFET's at room and low temperatures. The extracted results are (7 ± 0.5) × 106 cm/s at 300 K and (8 ± 0.5) × 106 cm/s at 77 K for electrons; and (7 ± 1) × 106 cm/s at both 300 and 77 K for holes. These numbers are used in an analytical model to calculate the MOSFET saturation transconductance as a function of channel length. Excellent agreement is obtained between the experimentally measured saturation transconductance at 300 and 77 K and the model calculations over a wide range of channel length from 10 to 0.15 μm. This also sets up a procedure for identifying the onset of velocity overshoot, which is reflected in the 77 K NMOSFET data below 0.25 μm. © 1993.
Index Keywords: Electron emission; Field effect transistors; Solid state devices; Electron hole; Saturation current; Solid state electronics; Transconductance; MOSFET devices

Title: Application of electromagnetics formalism to quantum-mechanical electron-wave propagation in semiconductors
Source title: Journal of the Optical Society of America B: Optical Physics
Affiliations: School of Electrical Engineering, Microelectronics Research Center, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, 30332, United States

Abstract: The formalism of electromagnetics can be applied to describe collisionless (ballistic) propagation, reflection, refraction, interference, and diffraction of electron waves in semiconductor crystals. This technique is complementary to applying the formalism of quantum-mechanical solid-state electronics to electromagnetic propagation in periodic dielectric structures as is done in photonic band structure research. © 1993 Optical Society of America.

Title: Lighting energy conservation and management
Affiliations: Energy Systems Engrg., Inc.
Authors with affiliations: Zackrison Jr., H.B., Energy Systems Engrg., Inc.
Abstract: We will illustrate the extent by which time-proven, off-the-shelf items can be employed to develop an energy conservative interior lighting system with low overall life cycle costs. The simple provision of adequate lighting at relatively low levels of energy consumption is no longer a technical problem as it was only a few years back. The challenge facing us today is to provide quality and control of lighting with attendant reductions in power consumption. Particular techniques emphasized will include the use of highly efficient lamp types, and control of lighting with automatic dimming. The intent of all of these techniques is the reduction of energy used by, and life cycle cost attributable to interior lighting systems. 1.For conventional overhead lighting, 2 foot by 4 foot grid troffers, whether static, nonair handling or dynamic air handling, mounted, fluorescent lighting fixtures, surface or pendent, the following design alternatives are listed and considered; A.In lieu of 40-watt fluorescent T-12 or T-8 lamps either use energy saving 34-watt rapid start (RS) fluorescent T-12 or T-8 lamps or 32-watt lamps which require a ballast change so that additional energy can be conserved in both the lamp and ballast. B.Group relamp all lighting fixtures on a regularly followed schedule to obtain more illumination for the same energy and reduce maintenance costs. C.Throughout the life of the facility, clean all luminaries reflective surfaces and their shielding media when group relamping lighting fixture luminaries whether lenses or louvers are used to gain greater illumination for the same energy use. D.Utilize lighting fixtures with solid state electronic ballasts, energy efficient T-8 lamps and use energy efficient virgin acrylic, female conic prism K19 silver tint lenses having high visual comfort probability (VCP) qualities. E.Install either branch circuit or lighting panelboard feeder circuit dimmers to reduce energy use in direct proportion to illumination reductions for all the lighting fixtures on the same circuit and/or same panelboard without having to change the ballasts. Energy saving 32-watt lamps cannot be used with this approach nor Thriftmate 33 or 50 lamps but 34 and 40 watt lamps can be used with this form of dimming system. 2.The following incandescent lamp and lighting fixture substitutes that can be used as alternatives are listed for consideration for porcelain enamel lampholders and high hat milligroove microbaffle downlights, ceiling drums and wall mounted cylinders, etc.; A.Utilize elliptical reflector ER lamps of half the PAR of R size wattage in a high hat downlight and obtain the same illumination level. B.Utilize either self ballasted circular fluorescent lamp units or twin tube fluorescent replacement units supplied with screw shell ballast lamp adapters for insertion in all porcelain enamel lampholders, drum type surface mounted overhead fixtures and for all incandescent table lamp fixtures. These self ballasted fluorescent lamps should not and do not require dimming. C.Use two 7-, 13- and 18-watt twin tube fluorescent lamps with screw shell ballast/lamp adapter for all wall mounted cylinders in lieu of two 100-watt incandescent lamps. Consider using 54-watt Krypton gas filled incandescent lamps. Both lamps equal a conventional 60-watt incandescent lamp and the 7-watt fluorescent is adequate. D.Consider using the enclosed and encapsulated fluorescent SL 18 unit produced by Philips in lieu of using a self ballasted circular or ballast lamp adapter twin tube fluorescent lamp unit as a substitute lamp. These lamps can be used in porcelain enamel lamp holders, table lamp fixtures and private bathroom lighting fixtures.
Index Keywords: Ballasts (lamp); Cost reduction; Cylinders (shapes); Enamels; Energy conservation; Energy efficiency; Energy utilization; Fixtures (tooling); Fluorescence; Fluorescent lamps; Incandescent lamps; Lenses; Life cycle; Lighting fixtures; Porcelain; Quality control; Screws; Design alternatives; Elliptical reflectors; Energy efficient; Fluorescent lighting; Illumination levels; Interior lighting; Reflective surfaces; Solid state electronics; Dimming (lamps)

Title: Progress on micromechanical inertial guidance system
Affiliations: WUMNSI Eglin AFBFL, United States; The Charles Stark Draper Laboratory, Inc, Cambridge, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Poth, T., WUMNSI Eglin AFBFL, United States; Elwell, J., The Charles Stark Draper Laboratory, Inc, Cambridge, MA, United States
Abstract: This paper updates the progress on the develop­ment of a lightweight, small, and inexpensive inertial measurement unit (IMU). This IMU will be built using micromechanical gyroscopes and accelerometers that are virtually invisible to the unaided eye. These instruments are fabricated out of silicon using inex­pensive low-labor-intensive batch processing tech­niques similar to those developed earlier for solid-state electronics. In order to reach the desired performance, improvements in the signal to noise ratio (S/N) must be realized. The major emphasis has been in the control loop analysis, the develop­ment of a buffer amplifier fabricated on the same substrate as the instrument (to minimize readout noise), designing the electronics, and instrument development (to increase the signal). Topics presented include a description of the IMU concept, a short explanation of how the gyro and accelerometer operate, a discussion of the control loops and electronics design, structural analysis, and test results. © 1992, American Instiiute of Aeronautics and Astronaurics, Inc., All rights rsservcd

Title: Design and test of a high power electromechanical actuator for thrust vector control
Source title: AIAA/ASME/SAE/ASEE 28th Joint Propulsion Conference and Exhibit, 1992
Affiliations: National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Marshall Space Flight Center, Huntsville, AL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cowan, J.R., National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Marshall Space Flight Center, Huntsville, AL, United States; Myers, W.N., National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Marshall Space Flight Center, Huntsville, AL, United States
Abstract: New control mechanisms technologies are currently being explored to provide alternatives to hydraulic thrust vector control (JVC) actuation systems. For many years engineers have been encouraging the investigation of electromechanical actuators (EMA) to take the place of hydraulics for spacecraft control/gimballing systems. The rationale behind this is to deliver a lighter, cleaner, safer, more easily maintained, as well as energy efficient space vehicle. In light of this continued concern to improve the TVC system, the Propulsion Laboratory at the NASA George C. Marshall Space Flight Center (MSFC) is involved in a program to develop electromechanical actuators for the purpose of testing and TVC system implementation. Through this effort, an electromechanical thrust vector control actuator has been designed and assembled. The design consists of the following major components: Two three-phase brushless dc motors, a two pass gear reduction system, and a roller screw, which converts rotational input into linear output. System control is provided by a solid-state electronic controller and power supply. A pair of resolvers and associated electronics deliver position feedback to the controller such that precise positioning is achieved. Testing and evaluation is currently in progress. Goals focus on performance comparisons between EMA’s and similar hydraulic systems. © 1992 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: The Future of Solid-State Electronics
Affiliations: IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, New York, United States
Authors with affiliations: Keyes, R.W., IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, New York, United States
Abstract: The growth of commerce around the end of the 16th century created a need for large amounts of numerical calculation. the increasing understanding of astronomical phenomena around the same time also depended on accurate computation. the difficulty of accurately performing large amounts of tedious numerical work by hand stimulated Leibniz, Pascal and others to invent mechanical adding and multiplying machines in the 17th century. (See figure 1.) the speed and complexity of mechanical computation were limited by inertia, friction, size and the difficulty of transmitting information very far. the development of electrical technology led to the introduction of electrical components in peripheral parts of computing machines, such as motors in place of hand cranks. Major improvements in performance, however, had to await the electrical representation of information. For three decodes most measures of the performance of digital electronics have been improving exponentially. What limits are in sight?. © 1992, American Institute of Physics. All rights reserved.

Authors: Budzier H., Hofmann G., Hess N.
Title: Modulation transfer function of pyroelectric linear arrays
Affiliations: Dresdner Institut für angewandte Sensori K (DIAS), Bergstrasse 69, Technische Universität Dresden, Institut für Festkörperelektronik Mommsenstrasse 13, 0-8027 Dresden, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Budzier, H., Dresdner Institut für angewandte Sensori K (DIAS), Bergstrasse 69, Technische Universität Dresden, Institut für Festkörperelektronik Mommsenstrasse 13, 0-8027 Dresden, Germany; Hofmann, G., Dresdner Institut für angewandte Sensori K (DIAS), Bergstrasse 69, Technische Universität Dresden, Institut für Festkörperelektronik Mommsenstrasse 13, 0-8027 Dresden, Germany; Hess, N., Dresdner Institut für angewandte Sensori K (DIAS), Bergstrasse 69, Technische Universität Dresden, Institut für Festkörperelektronik Mommsenstrasse 13, 0-8027 Dresden, Germany
Abstract: Spatial resolution, described by the modulation transfer function (MTF), is very important for multidimensional infrared sensors. The sensor-MTF of a pyroelectric linear array is determined by the geometric, thermal and capacitive MTF. These are calculated in detail by the use of a pyroelectric linear array developed at Dresden University of Technology, Institute for Solid-state Electronics. The linear array has 128 pixels with a centre-to-centre spacing of 100 μm. Deuterated and l-alanine doped triglycine sulfate (DTGS:L-A) or lithium niobate (LiNbO3) are used as pyroelectric materials. Finally, the theoretical results are substantiated by measurements. © 1992.

Title: Japanese residential air-conditioning: natural cooling and intelligent systems
Affiliations: Shimizu Corporation, Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Sociology and Rural Sociology, Washington State University, Pullman, WA 99164-4020, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fujii, H., Shimizu Corporation, Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Lutzenhiser, L., Sociology and Rural Sociology, Washington State University, Pullman, WA 99164-4020, United States
Abstract: Japanese residential heap pumps (which commonly combine cooling, dehumidifying and heating in a single system) are unlike American room air conditioners in a variety of ways. A key to the difference follows from the traditional Japanese focus on heating or cooling persons rather than spaces. When this focus is coupled with the widespread use of inverter technology, solid-state electronics, Japanese cultural norms, the constraints of house form, and the islands' climate, the result is a sophisticated system unlike anything available elsewhere. In addition to a large number of standard remote-control options, some Japanese systems can perceive and learn user preferences, while others can generate pre-recorded and algorithmic fluctuations of wind and temperature. We discuss some of the implications (both for users and for energy consumption) of these innovations. We also consider the results of a small survey of Japanese air-conditioner owners in which we found that despite the sophistication of their heat pump systems a significant majority prefers natural cooling. Most, for example, open windows and pursue other natural cooling strategies before using their air conditioners. While they view the devices as urban necessities, they also report limited knowledge of their machines' advanced features. This research examines the design, cultural context and use of Japanese air-conditioning systems, along with some of the behavioral and theoretical issues raised by their unique form. After discussing traditional Japanese housing and heating and cooling technologies, we describe contemporary Japanese heating/ cooling systems, speculate about the differences between US and Japanese systems, and present preliminary findings on Japanese cooling behavior from a small sample of Japanese air-conditioner owners. © 1992.
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Control systems; Heat pump systems; Heating; Houses; Intelligent systems; Japanese systems; Natural cooling; Residential heat pumps; U.S. systems; Air conditioning

Title: LED-compatible fluorosensor for ammonium ion and its application to biosensing
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Karl-Franzens Univ., Graz, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Wolfbeis, Otto S., Karl-Franzens Univ., Graz, Austria; Li, Hong, Karl-Franzens Univ., Graz, Austria
Abstract: We present a fluorescence-based sensing scheme for ammonium ion using nonactin as the receptor/carrier. The ammonium-sensitive material consists of a pvc membrane containing the nonactin, a plasticizer, and a proton carrier (lipophilic nile blue). Sensing is based on the selective extraction of the ammonium ions into the pvc membrane, and a concomitant release of a proton from the dye, contained in the pvc membrane, into the sample solution. Upon deprotonation, the dye undergoes a color change from blue to red which is detected via fluorescence intensity measurements. The sensor fully reversibly responds to ammonium ion, with detection limits varying from 0.03 to 10 mM at near neutral pH. Response times are about 1 min for membrane thicknesses of ca. 2 μm. The sensor is fully compatible with solid-state electronics (i.e., LED light sources and photodiode detectors) but suffers from a strong pH dependence of the signal so that the pH of the sample must be kept constant. The sensor is of potential utility in monitoring ammonium ion in wastewater and surface water samples, but may also act as a transducer in all kinds of biochemical reactions during which ammonium ion is released or consumed. Examples of biosensors for urea and creatinine are given.

Authors: Keys L.K., Rao R., Balakrishnan K.
Title: Concurrent Engineering for Consumer, Industrial Products, and Government Systems
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Components, Hybrids, and Manufacturing Technology
Affiliations: Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Systems Engineering, College of Engineering, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States
Authors with affiliations: Keys, L.K., Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Systems Engineering, College of Engineering, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States; Rao, R., Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Systems Engineering, College of Engineering, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States; Balakrishnan, K., Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Systems Engineering, College of Engineering, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States
Abstract: Since the early days of consumer solid-state electronics products, Japanese companies have used a team oriented integrated product/process development process to dominate the development of new multidisciplinary electronic, mechatronic, and other sophisticated technology products. Their leadership in solid-state color TV's, electronic 35-mm cameras, VCR's, and Camcorders are some examples of the power of this dynamic project management methodology. It is now behind all major new products development including telecommunications, automobiles, aircraft, computers, etc. It has begun to be adopted by many industries and business in the U.S. and the rest of the world. This integrated team multidisciplinary dynamic project management development process has come to be known as concurrent engineering (CE). Recent Institute for Defense Analysis (IDA) reports, NSF workshops, and other current efforts and publications addressing CE will be presented. © 1992 IEEE

Title: Dust monitoring. The latest technology for the forest products industries
Source title: Proceedings of the Washington State University International Particleboard/Composite Materials Series Symposium
Affiliations: Anacon Corp, Hopkinton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jollette, Ralph, Anacon Corp, Hopkinton, United States
Abstract: Based on the light extinction principle, a new dust monitoring system has been developed that includes: data logging and time weighted averaging, multicalibration, broken bag and malfunction alarms, RS423 interface (RS232 compatible), programmable outputs, and optional dual beam for high sensitivity applications. The monitor may be applied wherever rapid, sensitive detection of rising dust levels is required. Its unique design gives an accurate measurement of dust levels without being affected by fluctuations in light intensity, aging of the photo cell, or fouling of the sight windows. Standard operational features include: solid-state electronics, the absence of any moving parts, a weather-proof and dust-proof amplifier, zero-drift compensation, and audible/visual alarm capabilities. Due to the use of a filtered air purge through the source and detector housings, neither window filming nor condensation occur.

Title: Muscle YAGs. Precision plus power
Authors with affiliations: Sprow, Eugene
Abstract: With new muscle and fiberoptic delivery, the neodymium-doped yttrium aluminum garnet (YAG) solid-state laser is now challenging its older CO2 gas-laser cousin in a manner, some claim, much like the way solid-state electronics displaced their gas and vacuum-tube predecessors. Once relegated to delicate and temperature-sensitive laboratory work, the new, more powerful YAG will also be soon challenging a lot of nonlaser ways of doing welding, cutting, and drilling. This paper discusses the characteristics, applications, advantages and disadvantages of YAG lasers.
Index Keywords: Cutting Tools--Laser Applications; Drilling--Laser Applications; Welding--Laser Applications; Operating Cost; Yttrium Aluminum Garnet Laser; Lasers, Semiconductor

Abstract: This paper addresses the implementation of a semiconductor device Used to simulate the synaptic interconnection in hardware realization of neural network systems. We have incorporated these modifiable synaptic weights into a solid-state electronic linear adaptive neuron with a Widrow-Hoffs delta learning rule as the updating algorithm to investigate the electrical performance of these programmable synapses. Title: Electronic properties of the interface between DLC films and silicon
Affiliations: Hefei Univ of Technology, Anhui, China
Authors with affiliations: Mao, Youde, Hefei Univ of Technology, Anhui, China; Liu, Shenglei, Hefei Univ of Technology, Anhui, China
Abstract: Diamond-like carbon (DLC) films, also referred to as hydrogenated amorphous carbon (a-C:H) or i-c films, have many excellent properties. They are of interest for possible applications in solid state electronics, for example, as passivation films of the semiconductor devices and as gate dielectrics of MISFET, etc. In the present paper the DLC films were prepared by the low frequency (50 Hz) glow discharge plasma chemical vapor deposition at room temperature. The reactor was made of a glass bell jar and two parallel plate electrodes, the spacing between the two electrodes was 3-6 cm. The silicon substrates were placed on the lower ground electrode. The hydrocarbon source used in the deposition was benzene (C6H6) vapor. The deposited films were very hard, electrically insulative and semi-transparent. IR absorption measurements and Raman spectra showed that the structure of the films was amorphous and C bonding in the films was predominantly SP3. In order to investigate the electronic properties of the DLC/Si interface, the aluminum electrons 1 mm diameter were evaporated on the n-Si wafers with the DLC films to give Al/DLC/Si (MIS) structures, then capacitance-voltage (C-V) characteristics of MIS structures were measured at f = 1 MHz. The shapes of the C-V curves of Al/DLC/Si structures were similar to those of the usual MIS capacitors. If neglecting metal-semiconductor work function difference, the equivalent density of the surface states reflecting the charges accumulated in the DLC films and in the DLC/Si interface was about 1-2 × 1011 states cm-1 from the flat-band voltage of the C-V curves. From the deep depletion state to the accumulation state, a hysteresis loop appeared. Its width measured at the flat-band capacitance was about 1.5 V and its direction was clockwise. This hysteresis loop was different from that connected with the transport of mobile ions in the dielectric of the M/SiO2/Si structures. It is possibly due to the slow interface traps instability.
Index Keywords: Carbon - Electronic Properties; Coatings - Interfaces; Diamonds - Synthetic; Semiconducting Silicon - Coatings; Diamond Like Carbon; Hydrogenated Amorphous Carbon; Carbon

Authors: al-Kindi G.A., Baul R.M., Gill K.F.
Title: An example of Automatic Two-Dimensional Component Inspection Using Computer Vision
Source title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Leeds, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: al-Kindi, G.A., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Leeds, United Kingdom; Baul, R.M., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Leeds, United Kingdom; Gill, K.F., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Leeds, United Kingdom
Abstract: Automatic inspection processes require intelligent devices which combine the attributes of existing measuring techniques with those of the experienced practitioner. With the rapid growth of solid state electronics and computer applications during the last two decades, the field of computer vision has developed significantly and its application in the field of inspection is becoming a reality. This paper examines the use of computer vision for the inspection of engineering components. A range of existing edge detection algorithms has been tested for their suitabiliy for two-dimensional component inspection together with a new algorithm for application when contour tracing methods fail to detect localized edges in a complex scene. Assessments are mainly subjective but are also based on computational speed; an important factor in on-line inspection applications. An algorithm has been proposed which can be used for the simultaneous analysis of internal and external contours with the ultimate aim of automatic component classification. In addition an alternative boundary coding system eliminates errors which are normally associated with other coding methods when monitoring components at different orientations. © 1991, Institution of Mechanical Engineers. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Computer Vision - Applications; Edge Detection Algorithms; Robots, Industrial - Vision Systems; Inspection

Title: ULTRANAC - a new programmable image converter framing camera
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: IMCO Electro-Optics Ltd, Basildon, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Garfield, B.R., IMCO Electro-Optics Ltd, Basildon, United Kingdom; Riches, M.J., IMCO Electro-Optics Ltd, Basildon, United Kingdom
Abstract: The development of an image converter framing camera with the feasibility of operation at frame rates of up to 50 million frames per second is described. The camera incorporates a new 'grid' gated all metal/ceramic image converter tube which is manufactured 'in-house' by the vacuum transfer processing method. All solid state electronics are used to drive the image converter tube. Exposure and inter-frame times can be set individually to different times if required with these and other camera functions programmed and controlled via a standard personal computer. Results obtained for the camera operating in its various modes are presented.
Index Keywords: Electron Tubes, Image Converter; Photography, High Speed; Programmable Framing Camera ULTRANAC; Shuttering Method; Cameras

Title: Chemical processing of electrons and holes
Affiliations: Univ of Florida, United States
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, Timothy J., Univ of Florida, United States
Abstract: A synopsis is presented of four lectures given in an elective senior-level electronic materials processing course which introduces the student to solid state electronics. A discussion is presented of semiconductors under non-equilibrium conditions; p-n junctions; and, metal-oxide semiconductor (MOS) junctions. It is shown that the lectures demonstrate their operation in terms that, for the most part, are understandable by chemical engineers.

Title: Real-time demonstration of electronic circuit operation
Affiliations: Pennsylvania State Univ, Dep of, Electr Eng, University Park, PA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Croskey, Charles L., Pennsylvania State Univ, Dep of, Electr Eng, University Park, PA, USA
Abstract: Real-time classroom demonstrations that have been developed for use in a three-day short course on solid-state electronics are described. The techniques are used to illustrate transistor, op-amp circuit, and transducer operation. Working schematics are projected by an overhead transparency projector. As component values are changed or an oscilloscope probe is moved from node to node, cause and effect are easily observed. Large-screen display of the DC results of the demonstrations is shown with a projection analog meter or digital volt meter. The AC waveforms are displayed with a digitizing oscilloscope that produces a composite video signal that can be easily shown with a television or monitor.

Title: Dynamically-tunable smart composites featuring electro-rheological fluids
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Intelligent Materials and Structures Laboratory, Composite Materials and Structures Center, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI  48824, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gandhi, M.V., Intelligent Materials and Structures Laboratory, Composite Materials and Structures Center, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI  48824, United States; Thompson, B.S., Intelligent Materials and Structures Laboratory, Composite Materials and Structures Center, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI  48824, United States
Abstract: A new generation of revolutionary multi-functional, dynamically-tunable, intelligent, ultra-advanced composite materials featuring electro-rheological fluids is proposed herein for the active continuum vibrational-control of structural systems. This paper reports on pioneering proof-of-concept experimental investigations focused on evaluating the elastodynamic transient and also the forced response characteristics of beams fabricated in this new class of materials. The results of these investigations clearly demonstrate the ability to dramatically change the vibrational characteristics of beam-like specimens fabricated in ultra-advanced composite materials by changing the electrical field imposed on the fluid domains. In addition, experimental results are presented which characterize the elastodynamic response of a connecting rod of a slidercrank mechanism fabricated in these ultra-advanced composite materials. Again, the combined forced and parametric responses are controlled by the voltage imposed on the electro-rheological fluid domain in the structure. The capability of these materials to interface with modern solid-state electronics can be exploited by extending the fundamental phenomenological work presented herein through the successful incorporation of intelligent sensor technologies and modern control strategies in order to significantly accelerate the evolution of these novel composite materials for the military and aerospace industries. © 1990 SPIE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Aerospace industry; Bridge decks; Fiber optics; Interface states; Advanced composite materials; Elastodynamic response; Experimental investigations; Intelligent sensors; Slider-crank mechanism; Solid state electronics; Structural systems; Vibrational control; Composite materials

Title: Ultranac - A new programmable image converter framing camera
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: IMCO Electro-Optics Limited, Basildon, Essex, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Garfield, B.R., IMCO Electro-Optics Limited, Basildon, Essex, United Kingdom; Riches, M.J., IMCO Electro-Optics Limited, Basildon, Essex, United Kingdom
Abstract: Development of an image converter framing camera with the feasibility of operation at frame rates of up to 50 million frames per second with up to 24 frames per cycle is described. The camera incorporates a recently developed all metal/ceramic image converter tube which is manufactured 'in house' by the vacuum transfer processing method. All solid state electronics are used to drive the image converter tube whilst individual exposure and inter-frame times are fully programmable. All camera functions can be readily selected and controlled via any standard personal computer. © SPIE.

Authors: Schmitt R., Winkler D., Brunner M., Dortu J.M.
Title: Applications of high-speed electron-beam testing in solid-state electronics
Affiliations: Siemens Research Laboratories, Otto Hahn Ring 6, D-8000 Munich 83, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schmitt, R., Siemens Research Laboratories, Otto Hahn Ring 6, D-8000 Munich 83, Germany; Winkler, D., Siemens Research Laboratories, Otto Hahn Ring 6, D-8000 Munich 83, Germany; Brunner, M., Siemens Research Laboratories, Otto Hahn Ring 6, D-8000 Munich 83, Germany; Dortu, J.M., Siemens Research Laboratories, Otto Hahn Ring 6, D-8000 Munich 83, Germany
Abstract: A high-speed electron-beam tester was developed to measure signals inside integrated high-frequency circuits, in particular those on a GaAs basis. This paper describes the current stage of development. Using electron beam pulses down to only 7 ps makes the tester capable of measurements at frequencies of approx. 60 GHz. Simultaneously a probe diameter of 0.5 μm and a noise voltage at the system output of 2 mV/√Hz are achieved at 2.2 keV acceleration voltage and 1 GHz pulse repetition rate. To meet practical demands a wafer prober was designed extending the application of the tester to on-wafer measurements. A GaAs 1k SRAM is used by way of example to demonstrate the possibilities for practical applications. Extending into the ps range, the high temporal resolution of the tester leads to a detailed comparison between calculated and measured signals. While allowing verifacation of the parameters used for simulation, this also yields useful hints on measures for redesigning the circuit. © 1990.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Semiconductor--Testing; Electric Waveforms--Measurements; Electron Beams; Microelectronics--Testing; Probes; Electron Probe; Electron Pulses; Electron-Beam Testing; Gallium Arsenide Devices; Integrated High-Frequency Circuits; Wafer Prober; Integrated Circuit Testing

Authors: Coyle Laurence M., Mattison Edward M.
Title: Microcomputer-based adaptive data logging system
Source title: Instrumentation in the Aerospace Industry, Proceedings of the ISAAerospace Instrumentation Symposium
Affiliations: Smithsonian Astrophysical, Observatory
Authors with affiliations: Coyle, Laurence M., Smithsonian Astrophysical, Observatory; Mattison, Edward M., Smithsonian Astrophysical, Observatory
Abstract: We have described a data acquisition technique for meeting the requirements of both long-term data logging and fast sampling to capture data transients while conserving data storage space. We have discussed a compact, inexpensive data acquisition system, based heavily on commercially available circuit assemblies, that uses digital signal processing techniques to adapt itself to the data-handling needs of the system in which it resides. Mass storage is handled completely by solid-state electronics; there are no disc drives or magnetic tape mechanisms to cause maintenance problems. Users of the system have monitor and control capability via serial RS-232 ports. The ability to access the system over long-distance dial-up telephone lines and to download several days' worth of logged data has already proved its value in diagnosing system problems.
Index Keywords: Computers, Microcomputer--Applications; Data Storage, Digital; Digital Devices--Design; Data Monitoring System; Digital Filter Design; Infinite Impulse Response Filter; Data Processing
