Authors: Gandhi M.V., Thompson B.S., Choi S.B.
Title: A New Generation of Innovative Ultra-Advanced Intelligent Composite Materials Featuring Electro-Rheological Fluids: An Experimental Investigation
Affiliations: Intelligent Materials and Structures Laboratory, Composite Materials and Structures Center, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1326, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gandhi, M.V., Intelligent Materials and Structures Laboratory, Composite Materials and Structures Center, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1326, United States; Thompson, B.S., Intelligent Materials and Structures Laboratory, Composite Materials and Structures Center, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1326, United States; Choi, S.B., Intelligent Materials and Structures Laboratory, Composite Materials and Structures Center, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1326, United States
Abstract: A new generation of revolutionary, intelligent, ultra-advanced composite materials featuring electro-rheological fluids is proposed herein for the active continuum vibrational control of structural and mechanical systems. This paper reports on a pioneer ing proof-of-concept experimental investigation focussed on evaluating the static and elastodynamic transient response characteristics of cantilevered beams fabricated in this new class of materials. The results of this investigation clearly demonstrate for the first time the ability to dramatically change the vibrational characteristics of beam-like speci mens fabricated in ultra-advanced composite materials by changing the electrical field im posed on the fluid. The capability of these materials to interface with modem solid-state electronics can be exploited by extending the fundamental phenomenological work pre sented herein by the successful incorporation of intelligent sensor technologies and modern control strategies in order to significantly accelerate the evolution of this in novative class of multi-functional, dynamically-tunable, ultra-advanced, intelligent com posite materials for military, aerospace, advanced manufacturing applications. © 1989, Sage Publications. All rights reserved.

Title: The chemistry of solid-state electronics
Affiliations: Solid-State Science and Technology Research Laboratory, Bell Communications Research, Navesink Research and Engineering Center, Red Bank, NJ 07701-7040, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yablonovitch, E., Solid-State Science and Technology Research Laboratory, Bell Communications Research, Navesink Research and Engineering Center, Red Bank, NJ 07701-7040, United States
Abstract: Since the original theoretical insights of Bardeen and Shockley about 40 years ago, the progress of solid-state electronics has been paced by the ability to control chemical bonding structures, particularly at surfaces and interfaces. The functioning of solid-state devices depends on being able to produce interfacial structures with a minimum number of defective chemical bonds. A series of chemical discoveries and insights, on germanium (Ge) and silicon (Si) surfaces and gallium arsenide-aluminum arsenide (GaAs-AlAs) interfaces, has brought the electronics revolution to its present state of development. In most cases, the technological consequences of these accidental discoveries could not be accurately foreseen. With that caution, the technological prognosis for some current research is also reviewed.
Correspondence Address: Yablonovitch, E.; Solid-State Science and Technology Research Laboratory, , Red Bank, NJ 07701-7040, United States

Title: Development of pulse polarography and voltammetry
Affiliations: State Univ of New York at Buffalo, , NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Osteryoung, Janet, State Univ of New York at Buffalo, , NY, United States; Wechter, Carolyn, State Univ of New York at Buffalo, , NY, United States
Abstract: Stepwise changes in potential at a dropping mercury electrode were first employed by Kemula in 1930 while doing postdoctoral work at Charles University. Subsequently Ishibashi and Fujinaga in Japan pursued a line of development based also on mechanical switching of potential, while in England Barker and coworkers built the first electronic instruments. The advent of solid-state electronics made possible broad commercial development of instruments which in turn extended pulse techniques to other electrodes and stimulated applications. Computer-and microprocessor-controlled instruments have expanded the use of pulse techniques and encouraged development of specialized waveforms.
Index Keywords: Electrochemistry; Electrodes, Electrochemical; Electrodes--Mercury; Measurements--Computer Applications; Pulse Polarography; Square Wave Polarograph; Voltammetry; Polarographic analysis

Title: Natural and artificially initiated lightning
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611; Institute of Atmospheric Physics, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States
Authors with affiliations: Uman, M.A., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611; Krider, E.P., Institute of Atmospheric Physics, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States
Abstract: Recent research on lightning has been motivated, in part, by the desire to prevent spectacular accidents, such as occurred in 1969 during the launch of Apollo 12 and in 1987 during the launch of Atlas-Centaur 67, and by the need to protect advanced ground-based and airborne systems that utilize low voltage, solid-state electronics. The present understanding of both natural and artificially initiated (triggered) lightning is reviewed, and suggestions are given for future research that can improve our understanding both of the physics of lightning and the parameters that are important for protection.
Index Keywords: accident; Apollo 12; Atlas/Centaur vehicle; lightning; Parnassius apollo
Correspondence Address: Uman, M.A.; Department of Electrical Engineering, , Gainesville, FL 32611

Title: Biosensors. A new analytic technology for real-time, on-line biochemical monitoring
Affiliations: Biotronic Systems Corporation, Rockville, MD 20850, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hunter Jr., K.W., Biotronic Systems Corporation, Rockville, MD 20850, United States
Abstract: A new technology is evolving that has the potential of improving patient management while substantially reducing the overall cost of health care. This new technology is based on biosensors, analytic microelectronic devices that use biologic detector molecules (e.g., antibodies, enzymes, receptor proteins, lectins, nucleic acids) as the sensing or signal transducing elements. An array of different biosensor configurations are under development, spurred on by recent advances in biotechnology and solid-state electronics. Although not all biosensors can detect their target analytes instantaneously, nor perform continuous measurements, certain biosensors embody both capabilities. Real-time, on-line biochemical monitoring will offer important information heretofore unavailable to the physician. It is also inevitable that biosensor-based instruments will decentralize patient testing, but telemetric systems can maintain the active and necessary involvement of the clinical pathologist.
Index Keywords: antibody; biosensor; human; human cell; monitoring; priority journal; short survey; transducer; Biosensing Techniques; Centralized Hospital Services; Diagnosis, Computer-Assisted; Human; Monitoring, Physiologic; Pathology, Clinical; Time Factors
Correspondence Address: United States

Authors: Riva-Sanseverino S., Cali C., Misiano C., Varasi M.
Title: TI-indiffused and proton exchange hybrid technology for integrated optical devices in LiNbO3
Affiliations: Univ di Palermo, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Riva-Sanseverino, S., Univ di Palermo, Italy; Cali, C., Univ di Palermo, Italy; Misiano, C., Univ di Palermo, Italy; Varasi, M., Univ di Palermo, Italy
Abstract: One of the most relevant aims of the activities in the field of 'Optical signal processing' of CNR Special Project, named 'Materials and Devices for Solid State Electronics' (MADESS), is to spot and stimulate in Italy the specific technology advancement to integrated-optical devices for RF signal processing and wide band telecommunications development. This objective is now at an intermediate stage: a lot of fundamental technologies have been identified; some of these have reached a sufficient development level to allow the fabrication of medium-high complexity devices. Among these devices, the LiNbO3 acousto-optical spectrum analyzer is a typical target for complexity and diffused interest in industrial applications. Therefore this device is particularly useful as test to evaluate the real potential of integrated optics technology in Italy. In this paper we show preliminary results of some technologies that various Italian research groups used to fabricate a spectrum analyzer prototype.
Index Keywords: Acoustooptical Devices; Integrated Circuits, Hybrid--Manufacture; Lithium Compounds--Ion Implantation; Signal Processing; Spectrum Analyzers; Hybrid Technology; Integrated Optical Spectrum Analyzer; Lithium Niobate; Proton Exchange; Radio Frequency Signal Processing; Wide Band Telecommunications; Integrated Optics

Title: Amorphous semiconductors: A new generation of electronic materials
Source title: Proceedings of The Royal Society of London, Series A: Mathematical and Physical Sciences
Affiliations: Univ of Dundee, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Spear, W.E., Univ of Dundee, United Kingdom
Abstract: The review deals with the electronic properties and recent applications of amorphous silicon (a-Si), which can be regarded as the first member of a new generation of electronically viable thin-film materials. After a brief introduction of the structure and the distribution of electronic states in a-Si the preparation of the material by the decomposition of silane in a radio-frequency glow discharge is discussed. The possibility of doping in a-Si has removed a major limitation in the a-semiconductor field and has, during the past 10 years, led to an upsurge in applied interest in this electronically controllable thin film material. A summary of the present state of applied developments, many already in industrial production, is given.
Index Keywords: Semiconductor Materials--Amorphous; Amorphous Silicon; Silane; Solid State Electronics; Semiconducting Silicon
Correspondence Address: Spear, W.E.; Univ of DundeeUnited Kingdom
Abbreviated Source Title: Proc R Soc London Ser A

Title: Ultimate in microelectronics: Biomolecules
Source title: IEEE/Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society Annual Conference
Affiliations: AT&T Bell Lab, Murray Hill, NJ,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Powers, L., AT&T Bell Lab, Murray Hill, NJ,, USA
Abstract: Biological microstructures perform a variety of chemical and electrical functions: switches, proton pumps, power supplies, receptors, effectors, and transducers. In most biological systems, each function is carried out by a separate molecule or as part of a complex of molecules. In a few cases, the same molecule can perform more than one function. Since the larger of these molecules is only 5 nm in diameter, this is the ultimate in miniaturization. Although these processes are not executed rapidly by comparison with solid-state electronics, they are highly efficient. The underlying principles are parallel processes and feedback control, and the mechanisms involve electron tunneling, diffusion within or adjacent to the matrix, charge separation across a highly resistive low-capacity medium, energy stored in chemical bonds, and near-thermodynamic equilibrium pools for electron transport. Thus, a detailed understanding of the structure function relationship using a host of structural and spectroscopic techniques is paramount to design of molecular-based electronic architecture.
Index Keywords: Biochemistry; Diffusion; Electrons--Transport Properties; Thermodynamics; Biological Microstructures; Biomolecules; Electron Transport; Electron Tunneling; Molecular-Based Electronic Architecture; Biomedical Engineering
Correspondence Address: Powers, L.; AT&T Bell Lab, Murray Hill, NJ,,

Title: PNEUMATICS DESIGN FOR MICROPROCESSOR CONTROL.
Authors with affiliations: Andres, Paul D.
Abstract: Today's machine designs require power components to complement the microprocessor-based control systems, but most available components do not interface well with the controls, either mechanically or electronically. It shows how the company solved the problem with a printed circuit board concept, with pneumatic components and support solid-state electronics packaged to electronics industry specifications.

Abstract: Electronic-based equipment which activates modern wire production machines requires a high quality electrical supply. A variety of random disturbances periodically occur in service. According to the author, the solid state electronics that are installed in wire drawers, chamferers, testing units, winders, twisters, straighteners, welders, CNC and other machines today are not able to cope as well with disturbances as valves and diodes of former years. The article describes equipment for uninterruptible power supplies.

Title: PRECISION TIG WELDING.
Affiliations: Precision Systems Ltd, St. Ives, Engl, Precision Systems Ltd, St. Ives, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Muncaster, P.W., Precision Systems Ltd, St. Ives, Engl, Precision Systems Ltd, St. Ives, Engl
Abstract: In this article, the author discusses mechanized and automatic precision welding by the TIG process. Other methods such as plasma, electron beam, laser and resistance welding, etc. , all have a place in welding technology but the advent of solid-state electronics has given TIG welding in particular a major boost and many more applications are now possible.
Index Keywords: WELDING MACHINES - Automation; ARC PULSING; SEAM FOLLOWING; TUNGSTEN INERT GAS WELDING; WELDING, ELECTRIC ARC
Correspondence Address: Muncaster, P.W.; Precision Systems Ltd, , Precision Systems Ltd, St. Ives, Engl

Title: Mica: markets built on dry ground.
Authors with affiliations: Benbow, J.
Abstract: The mica industry is very much a tale of contrasting fortunes. Sheet mica has witnessed a gradual, probably terminal erosion of its traditional markets over the last 3 decades. Although the electrical industry has retained its traditional status of being the largest market for sheet, the advent of solid state electronics has severely curtailed mica's widespread usage in many areas except specialised electrical applications. This contrasts sharply with demand for ground mica where wallboard and jointing compounds continue to underpin the current ground mica market. Additionally, the growing use of dry ground mica in plastics reinforcement and wet ground mica in pearlescent pigments are believed to offer the greatest potential for the substained future growth of the ground mica sector. -Author

Title: SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING OF LARGE-DIAMETER CZOCHRALSKI SILICON CRYSTAL GROWTH.
Affiliations: AT&T, Allentown, PA, USA, AT&T, Allentown, PA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lin, Wen, AT&T, Allentown, PA, USA, AT&T, Allentown, PA, USA; Benson, K.E., AT&T, Allentown, PA, USA, AT&T, Allentown, PA, USA
Abstract: Silicon is the major semiconductor material used in solid state electronics. To keep pace with the growth in integrated circuit size and complexity, silicon has to be prepared in single crystal form with continued increases in size and improvements in perfection. Modern integrated circuits called VLSI (for Very Large Scale Integration) and future circuits called ULSI (for Ultra Large Scale Integration) depend upon the availability of highly perfect single crystals which are prepared almost exclusively from silicon pulled from the melt by the Czochralski (CZ) technique. In this review the major advances in the understanding and engineering of this technology are discussed for crystals of 100 mm in diameter and approximately 20 kg in mass.
Index Keywords: CRYSTALS - Growing; MAGNETIC FIELD EFFECTS; MATERIALS SCIENCE; STRESSES; CZOCHRALSKI TECHNIQUE; DOPING; THERMAL STRESS; SEMICONDUCTING SILICON
Correspondence Address: Lin, Wen; AT&T, Allentown, PA, USA, AT&T, Allentown, PA, USA

Authors with affiliations: Gudlavalleti, Ram V., Natl Semiconductor Corp, Santa, Clara, CA, USA, Natl Semiconductor Corp, Santa Clara, CA, USA
Abstract: During his teaching experience, the author has found analogies to be an effective way of conveying complex ideas, sustaining student interest and kindling student imagination. Some of the analogies compiled from the literature on solid-state theory are presented and their use is illustrated in describing complex ideas such as effective density of states and current conduction through holes.

Title: CURRENT FAVOURITE: ELECTRIC PROPULSION.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: The advent of solid state electronics has greatly increased the variety of marine electric drives available. Although their greatest impact has been on the ac side, these devices also have advanced dc systems, increasing the options even further.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC MOTORS; PROPELLERS; SUPERFLEX SYSTEM; SHIP PROPULSION

Title: INHIBITED SPONTANEOUS EMISSION IN SOLID-STATE ELECTRONICS.
Affiliations: Bell Communications Research, Red, Bank, NJ, USA, Bell Communications Research, Red Bank, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Yablonovitch, Eli, Bell Communications Research, Red, Bank, NJ, USA, Bell Communications Research, Red Bank, NJ, USA
Abstract: It is suggested that the direct gap semiconductors are a natural physical system for the study of inhibited spontaneous emission. The performance of semiconductor lasers, heterojunction bipolar transistors, and solar cells is limited by spontaneous emission but for each in a characteristically different way. The different forms of inhibited spontaneous emission are analyzed, starting with the observation by A. Einstein that spontaneous emission must inescapably coexist with absorption and stimulated emission. It is neither feasible nor desirable to eliminate entirely spontaneous emission if the function of the semiconductor happens to be the emission or the absorption of light itself. Examples of this would be the semiconductor laser and the solar cell, respectively. In those cases the goal is to restrict the spontaneous emission to only those electromagnetic modes which are absolutely necessary. In other functions, such as in the heterojunction bipolar transistor where the radiation field ideally plays no role, all spontaneous emission should be suppressed.
Index Keywords: BAND STRUCTURE; LASERS, SEMICONDUCTOR; SEMICONDUCTOR MATERIALS - Radiation Effects; SOLAR CELLS; TRANSISTORS, BIPOLAR; DIGEST OF PAPER; DIRECT GAP SEMICONDUCTORS; INHIBITED SPONTANEOUS EMISSION; PHYSICS
Correspondence Address: Yablonovitch, Eli; Bell Communications Research, Red, , Bell Communications Research, Red Bank, NJ, USA

Authors: Allemang Randall J., Brown David L.
Title: MODAL ANALYSIS: TWENTY YEARS BACK - TWENTY YEARS AHEAD.
Affiliations: SV Sound & Vibration, Bay, Village, OH, USA, SV Sound & Vibration, Bay Village, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Allemang, Randall J., SV Sound & Vibration, Bay, Village, OH, USA, SV Sound & Vibration, Bay Village, OH, USA; Brown, David L., SV Sound & Vibration, Bay, Village, OH, USA, SV Sound & Vibration, Bay Village, OH, USA
Abstract: Modal analysis has involved and will continue to involve the combination of several evolving technologies. In the measurement stage, the technology of digital signal processing and discrete transforms is of primary importance in terms of making accurate measurements and understanding the relative significance of the errors that remain. The understanding of this technology often is the limiting factor concerning the successful estimation of modal parameters. In the estimation stage, the estimation methods are changing rapidly due to the transfer of existing technology from other fields where estimation methods have been more common over the past several decades. Finally, the impact of the technology concerned with solid-state electronics on both the data acquisition hardware and the computational hardware has made advanced measurement and estimation techniques, that were impractical five years ago, routinely accessible.
Index Keywords: DATA PROCESSING - Data Acquisition; SIGNAL PROCESSING; MODAL ANALYSIS; VIBRATIONS
Correspondence Address: Allemang, Randall J.; SV Sound & Vibration, Bay, , SV Sound & Vibration, Bay Village, OH, USA

Authors with affiliations: Naples, J.G., SDS-Relais, SDS-Relais; Antonitsch, Sepp, SDS-Relais, SDS-Relais
Abstract: The development of polarized relays is traced from their role of serving special requirements of electronics to the present where the optimum in relay technology and solid state electronics have combined to provide new functions and performance and to ensure a continuing role for relays.

Title: Zener's contribution to solid-state electronics and magnetism
Affiliations: Westinghouse R and D Center, Pittsburgh, PA 15235, United States
Authors with affiliations: Carr Jr., W.J., Westinghouse R and D Center, Pittsburgh, PA 15235, United States
Abstract: A brief account is given of Zener's contributions to solid-state electronics and magnetism, and of the impact several simple ideas have had on these subjects. Four topics are singled out for discussion: the theory of ferromagnetism, the temperature dependence of magnetic anisotropy, the Zener diode, and the optical Wood-Zener effect.
Correspondence Address: Carr Jr., W.J.; Westinghouse R and D Center, Pittsburgh, PA 15235, United States

Title: SEALED IN SILICON. THE POWER ELECTRONICS REVOLUTION.
Authors with affiliations: Douglas, John
Abstract: Development of power electronics - solid-state technology for the efficient handling of bulk electric power - stands at the point where integrated circuits did 30 years ago. Like their microelectronic counterparts, power electronics devices are expected to have a revolutionary effect, changing forever the way that we generate, deliver, and use electricity. This paper reviews current research on power electronics which can be roughly divided into three broad areas: semiconductor materials, devices and packaging, and applications.

Affiliations: Cominco Electronic Materials Inc,, Spokane, WA, USA, Cominco Electronic Materials Inc, Spokane, WA, USA

Abstract: Germanium has found major uses in infrared optics, fiber optics and as a catalyst for PET plastic production. Other advanced applications are in various stages of development. The solid state electronics industry has been the driving force behind the demand for gallium since the late sixties. Light emitting diodes, lasers, magnetic bubble memories and high performance integrated circuits are some major applications.

Title: EXPERT SYSTEMS AID TEMPERATURE UNIT SELF TUNING.
Affiliations: Eurotherm, Eurotherm
Authors with affiliations: Cheshire, Keith, Eurotherm, Eurotherm
Abstract: It has been more than 20 years since solid state electronics first began to make an impact on the industrial temperature control. The article analyzes the requirements for the temperature controllers and introduces a new digital, advanced tuning system implemented in the Eurotherm Advanced Technology Controller, model 818. This controller, using rule-based software, provides a major step foward in controller technology, ensuring that no special knowledge or expertise is required by the user.

Title: COMPUTER-BASED DISPATCHING IN MINES WITH CONCURRENT OPERATING OBJECTIVES.
Source title: Transactions of the American Institute of Mining, Metallurgical, and Petroleum Engineers, Society
Authors with affiliations: White, J.W.; Olson, J.P.
Abstract: Computer-based dispatching in open-pit truck haulage operations yields many benefits of interest to mine management. The key tangible benefit is a productivity increase with a given fleet of equipment or alternately, a reduction in equipment required to meet production quotas. Recent advances in mini- and microcomputer hardware and software and solid state electronics permit design and implementation of system features not feasible a few years ago. A hypothetical iron mine illustrates the application of the dispatching algorithms described.

Title: COMPUTER REAL TIME CONTROLLED SYSTEM FOR EXPERIMENTAL STUDIES IN SOLID STATE ELECTRONICS.
Source title: Pan Tao Ti Hsueh Pao/Chinese Journal of Semiconductors
Affiliations: Univ of Science & Technology of, China, Graduate Sch, China, Univ of Science & Technology of China, Graduate Sch, China

Abstract: A fully automatic computer controlled system for experimental studies in solid state electronics is designed and implemented. A HP87 microcomputer is used as a controller, interfacing to intelligent measuring instruments via IEEE 488 interfaces. The system is a highly parallel processing system consisting of multiprocessors included in the central controller and intelligent instruments to overcome the low speed disadvantage of the controller. Thus, the system is powerful and flexible for solid state electronics experiments and with reasonable cost. An efficient DLTS measurement is described.

Abstract: A portable system that utilizes solid state electronic timing circuits and a pulsed semiconductor laser for characterizing the optical gate sequence of high-speed image shutters, including microchannel-plate intensifier tubes (MCPTs), and silicon-intensified target vidicons (SITVs), is described and compared to earlier methods of characterization. Title: On the numerical treatment of boundary singularities in elliptic problems
Affiliations: Department of Applied Mathematics, University College of Wales, Aberystwyth, SY23 3BZ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Phillips, T.N., Department of Applied Mathematics, University College of Wales, Aberystwyth, SY23 3BZ, United Kingdom
Abstract: Techniques are considered for improving the numerical approximation to a problem which possesses corner singularities. The particular problem considered here is taken from solid state electronics. Relined numerical solutions are obtained using two techniques. The first employs a non-uniform grid with a smaller spacing of the mesh points in the neighbourhood of the singularities. The second technique involves a transformation of the problem to one which is free from singularities. The dynamic ADI method, which needs no a priori relaxation parameters to accelerate convergence, is used to solve the discretized problem in both cases. © 1986.

Authors: Woollam John A., Bu-Abbud George H., Oh Jae, Snyder Paul G., Lamb Joel D., Ingram David C., Rai A.K.
Title: AMORPHOUS HYDROGENATED DIAMONDLIKE CARBON DIELECTRIC FILMS.
Affiliations: Univ of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, USA, Univ of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, USA
Authors with affiliations: Woollam, John A., Univ of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, USA, Univ of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, USA; Bu-Abbud, George H., Univ of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, USA, Univ of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, USA; Oh, Jae, Univ of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, USA, Univ of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, USA; Snyder, Paul G., Univ of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, USA, Univ of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, USA; Lamb, Joel D., Univ of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, USA, Univ of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, USA; Ingram, David C., Univ of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, USA, Univ of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, USA; Rai, A.K., Univ of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, USA, Univ of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE, USA
Abstract: Hard, semitransparent amorphous hydrogenated carbon films have been under investigation as possible dielectric materials in high frequency solid state electronics, as well as for optical coatings and coatings for computer disks. These films are called 'Diamondlike' by some authors, and can be prepared by several techniques including plasma and ion beam deposition. The properties of these films depend on deposition parameters, and are related to the concentration of hydrogen in the film, as well as to the energy and fluence of energetic species present during deposition. This paper is a review of recent progress in the preparation, characterization, and application of these materials. New results of optical, interfacial (with InP), and combined proton recoil/Rutherford backscattering/ellipsometric studies are presented. Results of Mil Spec testing of film adherence and integrity under extremes of temperature, moisture, and chemical environment are reported.
Index Keywords: CARBON; SEMICONDUCTING DIAMONDS - Amorphous; SEMICONDUCTING FILMS - Amorphous; COMPUTER DISKS; DEPOSITION PARAMETERS; DIELECTRIC FILMS; FILM ADHERENCE; HYDROGENATED CARBON FILMS; MIL SPEC TESTING; DIELECTRIC MATERIALS

Title: Fluid power technology. Still running strong.
Authors with affiliations: Hughes, T.
Abstract: The fluid power industry continues its growth mainly due to its ability to adapt to user complaints and requirements. The development of high water content fluids, miniaturization and incorporation of solid state electronics are particularly significant. The industry seeks to educate its potential users in the advantages of fluid power and held its first International Fluid Power Exposition in December 1984 and another is planned for 1988. The NFPA also sponsors several seminars each year at the Milwaukee School of Engineering. (H.C.B.)

Authors: Giuliani J.F., Bey Jr. P.P., Wohltjen H., Snow A., Jarvis N.L.
Title: OPTICAL WAVEGUIDE CHEMICAL SENSORS.
Affiliations: US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Giuliani, J.F., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA; Bey Jr., P.P., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA; Wohltjen, H., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA; Snow, A., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA; Jarvis, N.L., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: The development of small, portable and rugged devices for detecting toxic vapors and liquids has rapidly accelerated within the last several years due to advances in microfabrication and miniaturization technology in optics and solid-state electronics. Moreover, the renewed interest in organic dyes, polymers and bioactive solid surface films has lead to their successful application as sensing materials for specific toxic compounds when they are coated onto inexpensive optical waveguide glass substrates. A brief review of the principles of total internal multiple reflection and their application to several vapor and liquid sensing devices designed and built at NRL is presented. Preliminary data characterizing these optical devices with regard to film coating response, reversibility, stability, and environmental influences are described in detail. Several recent electronic and optical design modifications have been incorporated into the prototype devices, resulting in significant electrical sensitivity and stability enhancement as well as a considerable reduction in size.
Index Keywords: WAVEGUIDES, OPTICAL - Applications; TOXIC LIQUID DETECTOR; TOXIC VAPOR DETECTOR; SENSORS

Title: GAAS BASED ELECTRONIC TECHNOLOGY FOR SPACE APPLICATIONS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Custom Integrated Circuits Conference
Affiliations: Defense Advanced Research Projects, Agency, Arlington, VA, USA, Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, Arlington, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Roosild, Sven A., Defense Advanced Research Projects, Agency, Arlington, VA, USA, Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, Arlington, VA, USA
Abstract: A review of DARPA's program for achieving a manufacturable GaAs solid-state electronics technology is presented. The emphasis in the DARPA program is on low power, radiation hard integrated circuits for low-orbit, space-based survivable systems' needs. While the DARPA needs are primarily determined by space based systems requirements, major benefits from this program will also extend to high-speed digital systems, as well as to microwave systems, via the new insights gained and the facilities provided for producing GaAs parts on the first high-throughput facility available in the US.

Authors: Orme S., Evans N.J., Wey B.O.
Title: A fail-safe microprocessor-based protection system utilising low-level multiplexed sensor signals
Source title: Journal of Physics E: Scientific Instruments
Affiliations: Nat. Nucl. Corp., Warrington, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Orme, S., Nat. Nucl. Corp., Warrington, United Kingdom; Evans, N.J., Nat. Nucl. Corp., Warrington, United Kingdom; Wey, B.O., Nat. Nucl. Corp., Warrington, United Kingdom
Abstract: The safety of commercial nuclear power plants is of importance to designers, builders and operators of such large and complex plants. The emphasis on safety has led to the requirement for highly reliable fail-safe systems for their control and protection. The authors describe one such system, the individual sub-assembly temperature monitoring system (ISAT) which is being developed for the commercial demonstration fast reactor (CDFR). The system incorporates recent advances in solid-state electronics and in particular microprocessors to implement time-shared data acquisition techniques to obtain and process data from around 1400 fast response thermocouples whilst meeting the required levels for reliability and availability.

Title: Instruments and methods for microfabrication by laser-controlled chemistry
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Lincoln Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Lexington, MA 02173-0073, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ehrlich, D.J., Lincoln Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Lexington, MA 02173-0073, United States
Abstract: The two principal methods of patterning of solid-state electronics via laser-controlled surface reactions, (1) laser direct writing and (2) laser projection, are briefly reviewed with an emphasis on the current instruments and sources. © 1985.
Index Keywords: LASER DIRECT WRITING; LASER-CONTROLLED CHEMISTRY; MICROFABRICATION; SOLID-STATE ELECTRONICS; SURFACE REACTIONS; INTEGRATED CIRCUIT MANUFACTURE

Funding Text 1: The initial studies have made use of existing sources in the visible and near-UV Combined with modified optical instruments developed for measurement and microscopy; however, the new applications in laser-chemical microfabrication are sufficiently important and, at this point, sufficiently developed to warrant a more systematic evaluation of source and instrument engineering. The intent of this paper is to briefly review the main patterning approaches and existing instrumentation for laser-chemical processing, with an emphasis on the current needs in these areas. We will illustrate the principal approaches using examples from our own experiments, although, with minor differences many laboratories have developed similar arrangements. Title: SOLID-STATE MOTOR PROTECTORS
Affiliations: Plant Engineering, Barrington, IL,, USA, Plant Engineering, Barrington, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Palko, Ed, Plant Engineering, Barrington, IL,, USA, Plant Engineering, Barrington, IL, USA
Abstract: Resistance-temperature devices (RTD) embedded in the motor windings have been used to protect against motor winding burnout for many years. However, their true potential for motor burnout protection was not realized until solid-state electronics permitted more refined interpretive circuitry. Some solid-state motor protectors are designed to integrate RTD inputs with motor current and time and to calculate a simulation of temperature conditions within the motor. The result is a more realistic estimation of actual conditions that a determination made on RTD temperature alone. This article discusses advantages of solid-state protectors, motor protection economics, and commercially available devices.
Index Keywords: OVERVOLTAGE PROTECTION; SOLID STATE DEVICES; OVERLOAD PROTECTION; ELECTRIC MOTORS
Correspondence Address: Palko, Ed; Plant Engineering, Barrington, IL,, , Plant Engineering, Barrington, IL, USA

Title: ELECTRO-PNEUMATIC POSITIONERS GET ELECTRONICS.
Affiliations: Kim Valves, Kim Valves
Authors with affiliations: Clements, Len, Kim Valves, Kim Valves
Abstract: Virtually all control valve functions in modern processing plants are achieved by the use of pneumatic or electric actuators, the choice between the two being normally dictated by the size of the valve, the environment, media and availability of power source. Ivco Process Valves has developed the K80P electro-pneumatic positioner, a device that uses solid state electronics to combine the functions of both the electric to pneumatic converter and valve positioner. Such are the savings in size and weight that have been achieved by the use of electronics that the resulting unit is housed in an enclosure small enough to be mounted directly on the actuator which it is to operate.
Index Keywords: ACTUATORS; ELECTRIC CONVERTERS - Applications; PROCESS CONTROL - Accessories; SENSORS; ELECTRIC ACTUATORS; MICRO-PNEUMATIC SWITCHES; VALVE POSITIONERS; VALVES AND VALVE GEAR
Correspondence Address: Clements, Len; Kim Valves, Kim Valves

Authors: Emel'yanenkov D.G., Kozlov A.M., Krinitskii S.L., Tsyplenkov I.N.
Title: CHANGE OF CHARACTERISTICS FOR Ag-InP CONTACTS WITH A PROTECTIVE FILM DURING HEAT TREATMENT.
Authors with affiliations: Emel'yanenkov, D.G.; Kozlov, A.M.; Krinitskii, S.L.; Tsyplenkov, I.N.
Abstract: In view of the prospective use of InP in solid-state electronics, considerable attention is being given to the study of metal-to-InP contact characteristics. When heated, the semiconductor decomposes, In and P diffuse out into the metal, and the phosphorus evaporates from the contact's surface. This, in turn, makes the electrical characteristics of a contact strongly dependent on the 'bake-in' temperature. In the present article we present the results of studies on the electrical characteristics and the elementary composition of Ag-InP contacts after heat treatment for the case when this evaporation of phosphorus from a contact's surface is prevented by a film of SiO//2 deposited on the surface of the silver.
Index Keywords: SEMICONDUCTING INDIUM COMPOUNDS - Heat Treatment; CURRENT-VOLTAGE CHARACTERISTICS; SILICON DIOXIDE PROTECTIVE FILM; SILVER-INDIUM PHOSPHIDE CONTACTS; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES
Correspondence Address: Emel'yanenkov, D.G.

Authors: Sigrimis N.A., Scott N.R., Czarniecki C.S.
Title: PASSIVE TRANSPONDER IDENTIFICATION SYSTEM FOR LIVESTOCK.
Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Superior Coll of Agriculture,, Agricultural Engineering Dep,, Athens, Greece, Superior Coll of Agriculture, Agricultural Engineering Dep, Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Sigrimis, N.A., Superior Coll of Agriculture,, Agricultural Engineering Dep,, Athens, Greece, Superior Coll of Agriculture, Agricultural Engineering Dep, Athens, Greece; Scott, N.R., Superior Coll of Agriculture,, Agricultural Engineering Dep,, Athens, Greece, Superior Coll of Agriculture, Agricultural Engineering Dep, Athens, Greece; Czarniecki, C.S., Superior Coll of Agriculture,, Agricultural Engineering Dep,, Athens, Greece, Superior Coll of Agriculture, Agricultural Engineering Dep, Athens, Greece
Abstract: A system has been developed to remotely identify moving objects, including animals, with potential applications in industry, commerce and livestock. The technique uses a pulsed radar principle. A power antenna transmits radio frequency bursts and a passive transponder (no energy source) returns a coded signal ('echo'). A separate, time division mutliplexed, antenna reads the echo and a synchronous receiver demodulates the signal which then is decoded by the host microcomputer. The present transponder is 5 cm diameter, 0. 8 cm thick and weighs 16 g. Moreover the design allows for integration by hybrid technology which can yield a unit with an estimated incremental manufacturing cost of less than 5 as well as miniaturization. The complete transponder system is solid state (electronics) with major advantges of: low cost, high accuracy, simplicity, long life, easy installation, and ability to withstand the hostile environment of a dairy farm.
Index Keywords: DAIRIES; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS; PULSE TIME MODULATION; RADIO SYSTEMS; COW IDENTIFICATION; PASSIVE TRANSPONDER; CONTROL SYSTEMS
Correspondence Address: Sigrimis, N.A.; Superior Coll of Agriculture,, , Superior Coll of Agriculture, Agricultural Engineering Dep, Athens, Greece

Title: FRONTIERS IN SOLID STATE BIOMEDICAL TRANSDUCERS.
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting
Affiliations: Case Western Reserve Univ,, Cleveland, OH, USA, Case Western Reserve Univ, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ko, Wen H., Case Western Reserve Univ,, Cleveland, OH, USA, Case Western Reserve Univ, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: The lack of reliable biomedical transducers is one of the bottlenecks in realizing the potential for better biomedical research as well as health care. The need for transducers in closed loop prostheses, artificial organs, diagnosis, care of the ill in both hospitals and at home, is discussed. A list of measurements for various physical, chemical and psychological parameters and the transducers needed to make these measurements is given. Solid-state electronics and technology important to transducer research is outlined with examples of sensors and actuators being developed at Case Western Reserve University. Future directions and concepts for new sensors and actuators are discussed.
Index Keywords: Biomedical equipment; BIOMEDICAL TRANSDUCERS; Transducers

Title: Electrical and thermodynamic characterization of water vapour/polymeric film system for humidity sensing
Affiliations: National Bureau of Standards, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States
Authors with affiliations: Huang, P.H., National Bureau of Standards, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States
Abstract: Polymeric films have been used increasingly in solid state electronics as sensing elements for species concentration measurements in gases. To achieve good linearity and low hysteresis for a sensor, the molecular structure of a gas/polymer system should provide, in equilibrium, a maximum entropy associated with adsorptive and desorptive processes of the gas at a constant temperature and pressure. The electrical and thermodynamic characteristics of water vapour in pvc-styrenesulfonate membranes have been investigated. The membrane is a crosslinked copolymer of styrenesulfonate with polyvinylchloride. Electrical conductance of the thin membrane is measured as a function of temperature at various relative humidities. Using the measured conductivity data, thermodynamic functions of free energy (ΔG), enthalpy (ΔH) and entropy (ΔS) are determined. This method of combined electrical and thermodynamic characterization of a gas/polymer system may be used to provide a means for designing suitable polymeric materials for humidity sensing and may provide a means of modelling improved gas sensor behaviour. © 1985.
Index Keywords: ATMOSPHERIC HUMIDITY - Measurements; COPOLYMERS - Film; ELECTRIC PROPERTIES - Measurements; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES - Measurements; ENTHALPY; ENTROPY; FREE ENERGY; HUMIDITY SENSORS; POLYVINYLCHLORIDE-STYRENESULFONATE COPOLYMER; SENSORS

Title: AUTOMATIC CONTROL FOR THE UTILIZATION OF ENERGY AND MATERIALS DRIVE AND PROCESS CONTROL IN THE STEEL INDUSTRY.
Authors with affiliations: Miller, W.E.
Abstract: Distributed Computer Control Systems (DCCS) technology is ideally suited to modernize, upgrade, and improve the productivity of existing steel plant processes. First, the processes themselves are distributed geographically. For example, a hot strip mill may extend over one kilometer. Second, functional distribution is already practiced and proven. Digital computers, microprocessors, data highways, and improved man-machine interfaces have been installed, and are in operation on mills and processes installed before solid state electronics technology. The forecast for the future for drive and process control in the steel industry: more computers, more microprocessors, and more, more, and more. In simple language, the future is to automate, emigrate, or evaporate.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC DRIVE; PROCESS CONTROL; STEELMAKING - Control; AUTOMATIC CONTROL; MATERIALS DRIVE; STEEL INDUSTRY; ENERGY UTILIZATION

Title: Electro-pneumatic positioners get electronics.
Authors with affiliations: Clements, L.
Abstract: The K80P electropneumatic positioner, using solid state electronics, has been developed to combine the functions of both the electric to pneumatic converter and valve positioner for pneumatic control valves. The unit is housed in an enclosure mounted directly onto the actuator which it operates. Actuation is dictated by comparison of the analogue signal with the signal from an internal feedback potentiometer by means of comparator and logic circuits. The K80PC is designed as a temperature controller but can also control pressure, flow and pH by the use of suitable sensors. A remote control unit can also be supplied. (H.C.B.)

Authors: Lai Juey H., Douglas R.B., Mao K., Larson W.L., Yau You-Wen
Title: HIGH PERFORMANCE ELECTRON RESIST FOR SUBMICRON E-BEAM LITHOGRAPHY.
Affiliations: Honeywell Physical Sciences Cent,, Bloomington, NM, USA, Honeywell Physical Sciences Cent, Bloomington, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lai, Juey H., Honeywell Physical Sciences Cent,, Bloomington, NM, USA, Honeywell Physical Sciences Cent, Bloomington, NM, USA; Douglas, R.B., Honeywell Physical Sciences Cent,, Bloomington, NM, USA, Honeywell Physical Sciences Cent, Bloomington, NM, USA; Mao, K., Honeywell Physical Sciences Cent,, Bloomington, NM, USA, Honeywell Physical Sciences Cent, Bloomington, NM, USA; Larson, W.L., Honeywell Physical Sciences Cent,, Bloomington, NM, USA, Honeywell Physical Sciences Cent, Bloomington, NM, USA; Yau, You-Wen, Honeywell Physical Sciences Cent,, Bloomington, NM, USA, Honeywell Physical Sciences Cent, Bloomington, NM, USA
Abstract: The development of very large scale integration and higher speed of operation of solid-state electronics has placed severe demands on the lithography needed to fabricate the integrated circuit devices with submicron dimensions. Electron-beam (e-beam) lithography is an advanced technique which uses a computer-controlled electron beam (10-30 keV) to precisely delineate circuit patterns with submicron features in an imaging medium called an electron 'resist. ' Current electron resists are mainly organic polymers. The main requirements for electron resists are high sensitivity, submicron resolution, high dry etch resistance and high thermal stability. The performance of current commercial electron resists, however, are far from satisfactory in meeting these requirements. In this paper the authors discuss the performance of the positive electron resist EP-25H developed for e-beam direct-write lithography.
Index Keywords: ELECTRON BEAMS - Applications; LITHOGRAPHY; DIRECT WRITE LITHOGRAPHY; DRY ETCH RESISTANCE; EXTENDED ABSTRACT; POSITIVE ELECTRON RESIST; INTEGRATED CIRCUIT MANUFACTURE

Title: REVIEW OF EFFECTS OF PROCESS-INDUCED RADIATION DEFECTS IN VLSI PRODUCTION.
Affiliations: US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Dozier, Charles M., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: VLSI chips will likely undergo several irradiations prior to completion. Since ionizing radiation is known to cause problems with solid state electronics, VLSI fabrication using these approaches, if carelessly used, may produce unreliable devices. VLSI fabrication poses new and different challenges to understanding and control of radiation effects in electronic materials. Techniques which remove damage without altering the long term reliability of the devices must be developed.

Title: PROPORTIONAL CONTROL OF A SPECIAL PURPOSE MACHINE.
Affiliations: Island Associates, Island Associates
Authors with affiliations: Larman, I.S., Island Associates, Island Associates
Abstract: This paper deals with a case study for a special purpose machine tool to produce bandknives for the tanning industry. The hydraulic system incorporates proportional control valves. The machine control incorporates solid state electronics. The specification for the machine called for a cutting speed between 1. 0 and 1. 5 m/s; for the facility to vary the pressure when tensioning the bandknife; for a pressure range variable between 16 bar and 100 bar, with the main control being at 16-35 bar for tensioning and maximum setting for the cutting drive. The box section below the re-circulating ball screw is an integral part of the oil reservoir. The overall length of this machine is 5 metres. The machine was built by Bramley Tanning Machinery Limited for a member of their group of companies.
Index Keywords: CONTROL EQUIPMENT, HYDRAULIC - Valves; CONTROL SYSTEMS, PROPORTIONAL; BANDKNIFE PRODUCTION; CUTTING DRIVE; CUTTING SPEED; PRESSURE VARIATION; PROPORTIONAL CONTROL VALVES; TANNING INDUSTRY MACHINERY; MACHINE TOOLS

Title: SOLID STATE SENSOR RESEARCH AT HONEYWELL: ACTIVE THIN FILMS PLUS MICROSTRUCTURES.
Affiliations: Honeywell Physical Sciences Cent,, Bloomington, MN, USA, Honeywell Physical Sciences Cent, Bloomington, MN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hocker, G.Benjamin, Honeywell Physical Sciences Cent,, Bloomington, MN, USA, Honeywell Physical Sciences Cent, Bloomington, MN, USA
Abstract: The development of Si-based solid state sensors has proceeded over the last decade and a half at Honeywell. Many such sensors, based on several technologies, are in production at Micro Switch and the Solid State Electronics Divisions. The first of these sensors utilized physical phenomena in the silicon itself to sense the desired quantities: The Hall effect for sensing magnetic fields, optical carrier generation for light sensing, and the piezoresistance effect for strain sensing. This paper describes some solid state sensor research at Honeywell.

Title: POSSIBILITIES AND LIMITATIONS OF SEMICONDUCTOR ELECTRONICS.
Source title: Transactions of the South African Institute of Electrical Engineers
Affiliations: Siemens AG, Zentrale Forschung und, Entwicklung, Munich, West Ger, Siemens AG, Zentrale Forschung und Entwicklung, Munich, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Heywang, W., Siemens AG, Zentrale Forschung und, Entwicklung, Munich, West Ger, Siemens AG, Zentrale Forschung und Entwicklung, Munich, West Ger; Krimmel, E.F., Siemens AG, Zentrale Forschung und, Entwicklung, Munich, West Ger, Siemens AG, Zentrale Forschung und Entwicklung, Munich, West Ger
Abstract: Any discussion of the possibilities and limitations of modern electronics must take into account the needs of the user - in other words, human needs. We cannot limit our considerations to signal processing alone, since semiconductor electronics embraces a much larger field of technology and involves not only physics but also questions of a societal nature. This the authors illustrate with selected examples. Those chosen from the field of computers and large scale integrated circuitry deal mainly with problems of down-scaling, complexity and testability. Others, leading to first signs of principal limitations like peripheral devices (such as sensors and actuators), which are no less important than signal processing, are getting a new impact by microelectronics offering novel means for solving complex problems. Additionally besides the field of silicon the wide range of novel possibilities for solid-state electronics is demonstrated by the rapidly evolving field of optoelectronics, with its emphasis on glass fiber communications and by the inclusion of acoustic wave techniques in the realm of signal processing.
Index Keywords: INTEGRATED CIRCUITS - Applications; OPTOELECTRONIC DEVICES - Applications; SENSORS - Applications; SIGNAL PROCESSING; ACTUATORS; PERIPHERAL DEVICES; SOLID STATE ELECTRONICS; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES

Authors with affiliations: Roosild, Sven A., Defense Advanced Research Projects, Agency, Arlington, VA, USA, Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, Arlington, VA, USA
Abstract: A review of DARPA's programs aimed at achieving a manufacturable GaAs solid-state electronics technology is presented. The emphasis in the DARPA program is on low-power, radiation-hard integrated circuits for low-orbit, space-based survivable system needs. R&D successes as well as present needs are described.

Title: 'SAFE ENOUGH' REPLACES FAIL-SAFE.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: A tidal wave of innovation has hit the cosy and conservative world of the signal engineer. The familiar relay is giving way to digital processors with failure modes that are not easy to predict, but cost savings alone ensure that the change to solid-state electronics is inevitable. At a major signaling conference in London there was complete agreement on the need to quantify safety; absolute standards implied by the fail-safe concept are no longer adequate.
Index Keywords: COMPUTERS, MICROPROCESSOR - Applications; RAILROAD SIGNALS AND SIGNALING

Affiliations: GEC, Engl, GEC, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Stevens, G.W., GEC, Engl, GEC, Engl
Abstract: Solid-state electronics has enabled a variety of control functions to be integrated with voltage regulation relays. This has increased the flexibility of standard control schemes and led to a reduction in their size and complexity. The author reports on basic v. r. r. functions, as well as various compensating junctions.

Authors: Meyer E.W., Green R., Cops M.H.
Title: Austin-rover Montego programmed ignition system
Affiliations: Austin Rover Group Limited, Birmingham, United Kingdom; Lucas Electrical Limited, Birmingham, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Meyer, E.W., Austin Rover Group Limited, Birmingham, United Kingdom; Green, R., Austin Rover Group Limited, Birmingham, United Kingdom; Cops, M.H., Lucas Electrical Limited, Birmingham, United Kingdom
Abstract: INTRODUCTION For any engineer serious about consistently achieving maximum power and fuel economy from a reciprocating, internal combustion engine, a complete knowledge of how the ignition system should function as opposed to the way it has been functioning is absolutely necessary. Most engineers today recognize that the mechanical distributor using contacts is the most unreliable part of a motor car. Not all engineers however recognize that the distributor provides only a first approximation of the spark timing that the engine requires for optimum achievement and even that with large errors. Beginning in the early 1970's, breakerless ignition, using variable reluctance transducers and transistors in place of cams, rubbing blocks and contacts, reduced failures by 99.8%. This change has been accomplished almost universally throughout the world in the succeeding twelve years. Since 1976 the use of solid-state electronics in an ignition system to provide optimum spark timing exactly as the engine requires has been occurring. The engineers of Austin Rover and Lucas have created a whole new design of a programmed ignition system with detonation control that we believe is a significant technical step forward by itself and is one of a series of steps we are taking to achieve superior fuel economy on our automobiles. In this paper we hope to show the benefits of our solution, describe the resulting hardware and show how we achieved outstanding reliability. © © IMechE/SAE 1984.
Index Keywords: Engineers; Fuel economy; Ignition systems; Maximum power; Solid state electronics; Spark timing; Variable reluctance; Ignition

Title: Numerical solution of a coupled pair of elliptic equations from solid state electronics
Affiliations: Institute for Computer Applications in Science, Engineering NASA Langley Research Center, Hampton, VA 23665, United States
Authors with affiliations: Phillips, T.N., Institute for Computer Applications in Science, Engineering NASA Langley Research Center, Hampton, VA 23665, United States
Abstract: Iterative methods are considered for the solution of a coupled pair of second order elliptic partial differential equations which arise in the field of solid state electronics. A finite difference scheme is used which retains the conservative form of the differential equations. Numerical solutions are obtained in two ways-by multigrid and decoupled dynamic alternating direction implicit methods. Numerical results are presented which show the multigrid method to be an efficient way of solving this problem. © 1984.

Authors: Way S.C., Wainwright H.K., Ward W.P.
Title: A State‐Of‐The‐Art Approach to Hydrologic Data Management
Authors with affiliations: Way, S.C.; Wainwright, H.K.; Ward, W.P.
Abstract: High‐accuracy electronic data acquisition equipment, a solid‐state memory, computer interface and software have been developed to provide a complete system for measuring and recording water level changes. A small, stand‐alone hydrologic instrument (SE1000) provides the automation and accuracy of solid‐state electronics in pump tests, slug tests, and long‐ and short‐term ground water monitoring. The unit is powered by a high‐performance battery pack with a minimum life of four years. This instrument can be buried at the monitoring site for protection from vandals, animals and temperature extremes. Ten pre‐programmed 949‐point data schedules are standard. One schedule is logarithmic with an initial data interval of 0.2 seconds. Nine linear schedules provide data intervals ranging from 15 minutes to 1.5 days and corresponding test durations ranging from 10 days to 46 months. The stored data can be recovered directly via the LCD display or transferred to a computer. Software provides automatic data reduction with hard copy tables and plots. This instrument has been used successfully in various locations in the United States. Copyright © 1984, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Index Keywords: ground water; pump tests; water level
Correspondence Address: Way, S.C.

Authors: Saad E., Lippitsch M.E., Leitner A., Aussenegg F.R.
Title: SURFACE-ENHANCED RAMAN SCATTERING AS A DIAGNOSTIC METHOD IN PREPARING ORGANIC SEMICONDUCTOR FILMS.
Affiliations: Karl-Franzens-Univ Graz, Graz, Austria, Karl-Franzens-Univ Graz, Graz, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Saad, E., Karl-Franzens-Univ Graz, Graz, Austria, Karl-Franzens-Univ Graz, Graz, Austria; Lippitsch, M.E., Karl-Franzens-Univ Graz, Graz, Austria, Karl-Franzens-Univ Graz, Graz, Austria; Leitner, A., Karl-Franzens-Univ Graz, Graz, Austria, Karl-Franzens-Univ Graz, Graz, Austria; Aussenegg, F.R., Karl-Franzens-Univ Graz, Graz, Austria, Karl-Franzens-Univ Graz, Graz, Austria
Abstract: The suitability of surface-enhanced Raman scattering as a diagnostic tool in preparing semiconductor films has been proven using phtalocyanine as an example. While conventional Raman spectra have a quality insufficient for diagnostic use, surface-enhanced spectra show excellent quality down to submonolayer films. Analytical information can be obtained on the molecular level (e. g. kind of central metal ion) as well as on the crystalline level (modification, direction of crystal axis with respect to the substrate). Surface-enhanced Raman scattering is superior to X-ray diffraction and infrared absorption in sensitivity and, due to its high spatial resolution, could also be used for direct measurements in future organic-semiconductor microcircuits.
Index Keywords: Raman scattering; Semiconducting films; COMPLEX ELECTRONIC FUNCTIONS; DIAGNOSTIC METHOD; PHTALOCYANINES; SOLID-STATE ELECTRONICS; SUBMICROSCOPIC STRUCTURE; SURFACE-ENHANCED RAMAN SCATTERING; Semiconducting organic compounds

Publisher: Springer-Verlag (Springer Series in Chemical Physics 39), Berlin, West Ger
Conference name: Laser Processing and Diagnostics, Proceedings of an International Conference.

Title: Technology: whale oil, Arab oil and no oil.
Abstract: Reviews the accomplishments of electric energy, vacuum tube electronics energy, and solid-state electronics energy. Argues for better use of technology that is available while new technology is being developed. -P.Creese

Title: SOLID-STATE ELECTRICAL CONTROLS.
Authors with affiliations: Palko, Ed
Abstract: Plant engineers have been quick to recognize and accept the advantages of solid-state electronics in equipment such as demand controllers, power factor controllers, computerized building energy management systems, and special-purpose process controllers, which are designed and delivered as essentially turn-keyed type systems by the manufacturer. But many plant engineers will continue to prefer traditional electromechanical equipment for typical inplant-designed systems. However, today's plant engineer can choose from the best of both worlds without having to totally reeducate himself in an engineering specialty different from the one in which he is trained and experienced. A number of these electronic 'building blocks' - motor starters, motor protectors, dc drives, adjustable frequency drives, relays, noncontacting proximity and position sensors, programmable pushbuttons, and programmable controllers - are discussed in this article.
Index Keywords: Electronic equipment; Control equipment, Electric
Correspondence Address: Palko, Ed

Title: Electrostatic Discharge Protection Measures for Membrane Keyboards
Affiliations: Sheldahl, Inc., North Highway 3, Northfield, MN 55057, United States
Authors with affiliations: Munson, J.B., Sheldahl, Inc., North Highway 3, Northfield, MN 55057, United States
Abstract: The trend to minaturized solid-state electronics has made appliance controls more vulnerable to human electrostatic discharge (ESD). Membrane switches may increase the likelihood of damage, since the inherently thin membranes provide less isolation than traditional full travel switches. In contrast to the manufacturing environment, relatively little attention has been given to ESD protection in service, where conditions of use cannot be controlled and where protection depends on the choice of keyboard materials and design. Electronic components can be damaged or destroyed and digital signals and data altered when ESD penetrates or circumvents keyboard dielectrics or electromagnetically induces transients in interface circuitry. Keyboard protection measures fall into three categories: grounded shielding, dielectric encapsulation, and transient suppression. Specific illustrations of these are cited. ESD simulators are discussed and practical suggestions given on objectives, preparation, and approach to ESD evaluation and testing of membrane keyboards. Copyright © 1984 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

Title: CONTRIBUTIONS OF METALLURGY AND MATERIALS SCIENCE TO THE EVOLUTION OF SOLID-STATE ELECTRONICS.
Authors with affiliations: Mahajan, S.
Abstract: Three examples have been chosen to highlight some of the contributions of metallurgy and materials science in the development of solid-state electronics: growth of high-purity, macroscopically dislocation-free silicon crystals; elimination of electromigration in thin metallic conductors; and minimization of growth- and processing-induced defects in silicon.
Index Keywords: Semiconducting silicon
Correspondence Address: Mahajan, S.

Title: DROs: A CLOSER LOOK.
Authors with affiliations: Tarana, Victor
Abstract: Innovations in solid-state electronics have made low-cost, high-reliability digital readout units (DROs) available. And integrated circuitry has added memory and programability. The latest DROs can slice manual machine-slide positioning time in half and reduce calculations, miking and operator fatigue, while simultaneously ensuring dead-on accuracy. So attractive are the benefits that the author predicts that 50 percent of manual machine tools will be DRO equipped by 1990 - a fourfold increase over today's figures. The most critical component of a DRO system is the measuring device, i. e. , some type of transducer or scale. A brief overview is given of the most common measuring devices for DROs.
Index Keywords: MECHANICAL VARIABLES MEASUREMENT - Distance; OPTICAL INSTRUMENTS - Digital Readout; Machine tools
Correspondence Address: Tarana, Victor

Authors: Khan A.A., Woollam J.A., Chung Y.
Title: High frequency capacitance-voltage and conductance-voltage characteristics of d.c. sputter deposited a-carbon/silicon MIS structures
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Nebraska, Lincoln, NB 68588, United States; Universal Energy Systems Dayton, OH 45432, United States
Authors with affiliations: Khan, A.A., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Nebraska, Lincoln, NB 68588, United States; Woollam, J.A., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Nebraska, Lincoln, NB 68588, United States; Chung, Y., Universal Energy Systems Dayton, OH 45432, United States
Abstract: Dark and illuminated C-V and G-V characteristics of A1/a-carbon/silicon MIS structures have been measured in the frequency range of 10 kHz to 10 MHz. The a-carbon passivating layer is prepared by d.c. sputtering of a graphite target in Ar gas. There is no evidence of Fermi level pinning, and surface carrier inversion is clearly demonstrated. Electrical instabilities are noted and briefly discussed. The high frequency electrical behavior seems to be dominated by states in the dielectric rather than states at the interface. a-carbon appears to be a promising dielectric material for use in silicon solid state electronics. © 1984.
Index Keywords: SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES, MIS

Title: STATIC POWER-CONVERSION TODAY (& TOMORROW? ).
Authors with affiliations: Bailey, D.
Abstract: The primary source of electrical power in mobile applications is direct current from generator-charged batteries. Conversion of this dc to meet the ac supply requirements of a whole range of equipment requires an inverter. The progress that has been made in static inverter technology in the last three decades is reported and it is shown how advances in solid state electronics are making it possible to operate ac powered equipment in the remotest places and the smallest of vehicles, marine craft and aircraft.
Index Keywords: Electric inverters; AC POWERED EQUIPMENT; STATIC INVERTERS; Electric converters, Power type

Title: Czochralski growth of silicon
Affiliations: Wacker-Chemitronic GmbH, D-8263 Burghausen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Zulehner, W., Wacker-Chemitronic GmbH, D-8263 Burghausen, Germany
Abstract: The importance of Czochralski (CZ) grown silicon as a basic material for solid-state electronics is outlined. After that, a short review is given of the different possibilities for growing silicon crystals and the history of Czochralski technique. Details of the CZ pulling procedure are discussed. The different aspects of the process like starting material, crucible problems, heat and melt flow conditions, interface reactions, as well as incorporation and distribution of impurities in the crystals are considered. Examples are given of typical and exceptional impurity distributions. Oxygen is of supreme importance in CZ-Si and is dealt with in greater detail. Its origin, typical concentrations and distributions, and its influence on crystal quality are described. Finally, the technical aspects of current CZ-Si growth are outlined and the mechanical designs of the pulling apparatus, including recharging equipment, are illustrated. © 1983.
Index Keywords: CRYSTALS - Growing; Heat transfer; CRYSTAL GEOMETRY; CZOCHRALSKI GROWTH; DISLOCATION FREE GROWTH; OXYGEN LEVELS; Semiconducting silicon

Abstract: Microscopic laser-initiated chemical reactions can be used to write micrometer-scale features on materials of interest for solid-state electronics. In this paper, we describe the nature of direct-write-type fabrication and summarize the laser techniques which have been developed. © 1983, SPIE.

Title: Automatic final test of electronic clocks
Affiliations: Equipment Engrg., Ford Aerospace and Communications Corp.
Authors with affiliations: Frick, W.N., Equipment Engrg., Ford Aerospace and Communications Corp.
Abstract: An automatic test system which eliminates the need for human judgement from the in process production testing of Electronic Clocks is described. The system, designed on a building block concept, is composed mostly of commercially available equipment with a minimum amount of custom hardware. Solid state electronic cameras and an in house developed computer Vision system eliminate the need for an operator to view the displays of the clocks while they are under test. © Copyright 1983 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.

Authors: Proctor S.J., Linholm L.W., Mazer J.A.
Title: Direct Measurements of Interfacial Contact Resistance, End Contact Resistance, and Interfacial Contact Layer Uniformity
Affiliations: Westinghouse Corporation, Baltimore, MD 21203, United States; Semiconductor Devices and Circuits Division, National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC 20234, United States
Authors with affiliations: Proctor, S.J., Westinghouse Corporation, Baltimore, MD 21203, United States; Linholm, L.W., Semiconductor Devices and Circuits Division, National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC 20234, United States; Mazer, J.A., Semiconductor Devices and Circuits Division, National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC 20234, United States
Abstract: A four-terminal microelectronic test structure and test method are described for electrically determining the degree of uniformity of the interfacial layer in metal-semiconductor contacts and for directly measuring the interfacial contact resistance. A two-dimensional resistor network model is used to obtain the relationship between the specific contact resistance and the measured interfacial contact resistance for contacts with a uniform interfacial layer. A new six-terminal test structure is used for the direct measurement of end contact resistance and the subsequent determination of front contact resistance. A methodology is described for reducing the effects of both contact-window mask misalignment and parasitic resistance associated with these measurements. Measurement results are given for 98.5-percent A1/1.5-percent Si and 100-percent Al contacts on n-type silicon. Copyright © 1983 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Author Keywords: Contact resistance; integrated circuit test structure; metal-semiconductor contact; semiconductor devices; solid-state electronics; test chip; test pattern; test structure
Index Keywords: SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES; INTEGRATED CIRCUITS, VLSI

Title: AUTOMATIC ON-LINE INSPECTION OF BOTTLES AND JARS.
Authors with affiliations: Beurskens, Frits
Abstract: The article describes a modular automatic inspection concept, recently introduced to the European market for on-line visual inspection of bottles or jars, regardless of size or color, for bottom, mouth and sidewall defects. The inspection principle is based on special grey scale image processing techniques. Solid-state matrix array cameras are used as receptors.
Index Keywords: IMAGE PROCESSING - Image Analysis; QUALITY CONTROL - Electronic Equipment; HIGH INSPECTION SPEEDS; SOLID-STATE ELECTRONICS; Bottles
Correspondence Address: Beurskens, Frits

Title: CONTROL FLOW WITH VARIABLE SPEED MOTORS.
Authors with affiliations: Hylton, David
Abstract: Most pipe line systems operate at flow rates different than design conditions due to changes in supply or demand, system hydraulics, fluid characteristics or other operating factors. As a result, flow control has been a long standing requirement and challenge to pipeliners. With the induction motor as a prime mover, controlling flow is done with control valves, on/off control or mechanical drive systems between the motor and the pump. Also, multiple pumping units provide flow ranges that operators can match to the demand. High energy costs, however, now provide the incentive to utilize systems that more efficiently control flow in pipe line systems. Solid state electronics has progressed sufficiently to give the option of controlling flow with variable speed motors using practical and reliable equipment. Two popular variable speed ac motor systems are adjustable frequency and controlled slip. Variable speed controllers for small motors use some form of forced commutation. Adjustable frequency controllers for large motors use load commutated inverters (LCI) and are connected to a synchronous motor. The article discusses variable speed motor applications and how they were added to three major pump stations.
Index Keywords: Electric motors; FLOW OF FLUIDS - Control; Petroleum pipelines
Correspondence Address: Hylton, David

Title: RECENT PROGRESS IN SOLID STATE ELECTRONICS AND MATERIALS.
Authors with affiliations: Takamura, Tsutomu; Inomata, Suekichi
Abstract: An overview is provided of the semiconductor industry in Japan, and a survey is given of technological developments in relation to microfabrication for very large scale integration, where the new electron beam resist holds the key to success.
Index Keywords: Integrated circuits, VLSI; Semiconductor device manufacture; ELECTRON BEAM LITHOGRAPHY; ELECTRON BEAM RESIST; Electronics industry
Correspondence Address: Takamura, Tsutomu

Title: Ultrasonic testing enhances pipe corrosion monitoring.
Authors with affiliations: Burkle, W.S.
Abstract: Ultrasonic testing (UT) has proven useful for monitoring corrosion and erosion related metal losses in piping systems and associated components. Improvements in system performance afforded by advanced design and solid state electronics have made modern UT units portable and reliable, requiring only single-sided access to a test specimen. (from paper)

Title: Developments and trends in semiconductor single-crystal technology
Affiliations: Physics Institute, University of Parma, ParmaItaly
Authors with affiliations: Paorici, C., Physics Institute, University of Parma, ParmaItaly
Abstract: The single crystal technology of semiconductor materials has undergone tremendous development in the last thirty years, mainly as a result of the response to application requirement in solid-state electronics. To a large extent, this technology is nowadays dependent upon our understanding of the interaction between the growth features (thermodynamics, fluid dynamics, kinetics, etc.) and the needs of the device fabrication (crystal perfection, compositional macro- and micro-homogeneity, shape control, etc., in as much as they are reflected in the final physical properties of the material). In this paper, the main bulk growth technologies are surveyed with the aim of pointing out, from the crystal grower's point of view, the state of the art for the diverse generations of semiconductors, and what will be, in the author's opinion, possible future trends. © 1983.
Index Keywords: CRYSTALS - Growing; SOLID STATE DEVICES - Materials; SEMICONDUCTOR MATERIALS
Funding Details: Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche, CNR

Title: Epitaxy
Affiliations: Departments of Electrical Engineering and Material Science and Engineering, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT 84112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stringfellow, G.B., Departments of Electrical Engineering and Material Science and Engineering, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT 84112, United States
Abstract: The future growth of solid-state electronics depends on the ability to produce new high-performance semiconductor devices. This requires the development of new semiconductor materials and the ability to grow special structures, particularly those with very thin layers. Epitaxy, the set of techniques used to produce perfect semiconductor layers, is the topic of this review. The basic concepts underlying epitaxy, thermodynamics, mass transport, surface kinetics and defect generation are discussed first. The specific epitaxial techniques are discussed. Liquid-phase epitaxy (LPE) and vapour-phase epitaxy (VPE), including organometallic vapour-phase epitaxy (OMVPE) and molecular-beam epitaxy (MBE), are discussed in detail.
