Title: Brake demand sensors for control of electric brakes
Affiliations: Research and Development Center, Kelsey-Hayes Co., Romulus, MI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Neill, D.L., Research and Development Center, Kelsey-Hayes Co., Romulus, MI, United States
Abstract: Two types of inexpensive brake demand sensors have been developed to provide linearly proportional synchronization between towing vehicle hydraulic brakes and trailer electric brakes. Brake pressure or brake pedal force are converted to electrical signals used to modulate electric brake current via a solid state electronic controller. This paper discusses the application and development of these sensors which use a potentiometer as the basic element to reliably provide a high level signal at low cost.
Index Keywords: Hydraulic brakes; Voltage dividers; Basic elements; Brake pedals; Brake pressure; Electrical signal; High-level signals; Linearly proportional; Solid state electronics; Towing vehicles; Electric brakes
Correspondence Address: Neill, D.L.; Research and Development Center, , Romulus, MI, United States

Title: MICROSTRUCTURAL SCIENCE VOLUME 10, PROCEEDINGS OF THE ANNUAL TECHNICAL MEETING OF THE INTERNATIONAL METALLOGRAPHIC SOCIETY, 14TH, 1981.
Source title: PROC OF THE ANNU TECH MEET OF THE INTMETALLOGR SOC, 14TH
Abstract: THIS CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS CONTAINS 36 PAPERS ON MICROSTRUCTURAL SCIENCE TREATED FROM SEVERAL POINTS OF VIEW: THE MATERIALS, THEIR APPLICATIONS AND THE VARIOUS ANALYTICAL TECHNIQUES USED FOR SPECIFIC METALLOGRAPHIC STUDIES. MATERIALS REPORTED UPON RANGE FROM THE TRADITIONAL FERROUS AND NON-FERROUSALLOYS TO CERAMICS, POWDERED METALS, COMPOSITES, RAPIDLY SOLIDIFIED ALLOYS AND AMORPHOUS ALLOYS. THE APPLICATIONS DISCUSSED FOR THESE MATERIALS INCLUDE SOLID STATE ELECTRONICS, ENERGY CONVERSION AND TRANSPORT SYSTEMS. A BROAD RANGE OF MICROSTRUCTURAL TECHNIQUES ARE REPRESENTED INCLUDING OPTICAL MICROSCOPY, SCANNING AND TRANSMISSION ELECTRON MICROSCOPY AND X-RAY DIFFRACTION ANALYSIS. TECHNICAL AND PROFESSIONAL PAPERSFROM THIS CONFERENCE ARE INDEXED WITH THE CONFERENCE CODE NO. 01433 IN THE EI ENGINEERING MEETINGS (TM) DATABASE PRODUCED BY ENGINEERING INFORMATION, INC.
Index Keywords: METALS AND ALLOYS - MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; CERAMICS; EIREV; MICROSCOPIC EXAMINATION; POWDER METAL PRODUCTS; Metallography
Editors: WHITE WILLIAM E.RICHARDSON JAMES H.MCCALL JAMES L.
Publisher: ELSEVIER, AND AMSTERDAM, NEW YORK, NY, USA

Title: IMPURITY BAND CONDUCTION IN POLYSILICON.
Source title: Journal of the Canadian Ceramic Society
Authors with affiliations: Lombos, B.A.; Pietrantonio, M.
Abstract: Polysilicon has more and more device applications in solid state electronics. It is particularly well suited for large area, simple, low cost and large quantity active devices, such as photovoltaic solar energy converters, and as interconnections and passive components in integrated circuits (IC's). In this investigation, polysilicon films have been grown on graphite and fused silica substrates by the thermal decomposition of silane in a resistance heated furnace. The crystallinity and transport properties of the grown films were investigated as a function of deposition conditions and doping levels. The effect of the grain boundaries, characterizing the polycrystals, are examined using a model based on deep-lying levels in the band gap.
Index Keywords: CERAMIC MATERIALS - Electric Conductivity; Integrated circuits; Solid state devices; POLYSILICON; SOLID STATE ELECTRONICS; Electric insulating materials
Correspondence Address: Lombos, B.A.

Title: Emis: An online fact retrieval and publication system†
Affiliations: Institution of Electrical Engineers, International Information Services for the Physics and Engineering Communities, Station House, Hitchin, Hertfordshire SG5 1RG England, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Sears, J.L., Institution of Electrical Engineers, International Information Services for the Physics and Engineering Communities, Station House, Hitchin, Hertfordshire SG5 1RG England, United Kingdom
Abstract: EMIS is an online multi-purpose research tool for scientists and electrical engineers who study, process or use solid-state electronic materials. It provides for: (a) Retrieval of continuously updated information on hundreds of properties (selected materials). (b) Rapid publication of research results (all electronic materials). (c) Selection of material supply sources (all electronic materials). © 1982.
Index Keywords: INFORMATION RETRIEVAL SYSTEMS; Materials properties; Electrical engineers; Electronic materials; Material supply; Multi-purpose; Research results; Research tools; Solid state electronics
Correspondence Address: Sears, J.L.; Institution of Electrical Engineers, , Hitchin, Hertfordshire SG5 1RG England, United Kingdom

Title: MOTOR DRIVES KEEP PACE WITH CHANGING TECHNOLOGY.
Authors with affiliations: HALL, JOHN
Abstract: IN THE PROCESS OF AUTOMATING FACTORIES, ENGINEERS ARE OFTENCALLED UPON TO MAKE A CHOICE BETWEEN OLD RELIABLE TECHNIQUES AND EQUIPMENT AND NEW DEVICES USING NEWER TECHNOLOGY. NOWHERE IS THIS DECISION REQUIRED MORE OFTEN THAN IN THE SELECTION OF A MOTOR DRIVE. FOR MANY YEARS, THE CHOICE WAS SIMPLE; VIRTUALLY EVERY THING WAS DC AND ANY AGONIZING DONE WAS ONLYOVER THE DRIVE TO BE USED. TODAY, SOLID STATE ELECTRONICS HAS BROUGHT DOWN THE COST OF AC DRIVES TO THE POINT WHERE THEY ARE OFTEN COST COMPETITIVE WITH DC. WHEN FACTORS SUCH AS ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS, EFFICIENCY, HIGHER OPERATING SPEEDS, AND CLOSER CONTROL ARE CONSIDERED, AC DRIVES END UP WINNING MORE OFTEN THAN BEFORE. THIS ARTICLE COMPARES THE MAJOR ACAND DC TYPES AND LOOKS AT WHERE THEY STAND TODAY. IT INCLUDES SEVERAL TABLES THAT WILL EASE THE TASK OF MOTOR DRIVE SELECTION.
Index Keywords: PRODUCTION ENGINEERING; ELECTRIC MOTORS - DRIVES
Correspondence Address: HALL, JOHN

Title: Electro-rheological effect adds muscle.
Authors with affiliations: Brooks, D.A.
Abstract: An electrorheological fluid is a multiphase fluid system that changes its rheological behaviour under the influence of an externally applied electric field. The electro-rheological effect can be used to facilitate the output stage of the mechanical element in hydraulic control systems with direct interfacing with solid-state electronics. Appllications of this effect to actuator systems, dampers and clutches is outlined. (H.C.B.)

Title: Electro-rheological devices.
Authors with affiliations: Brooks, D.A.
Abstract: The Electro-Rheological Effect is a method of providing high performance inexpensive output elements for hydraulic control systems which are directly interfaceable with solid state electronics. The basic principles of this effect are examined and examples of use in actuation systems, damping devices and clutches are given. (H.C.B.)
Index Keywords: electrorheological fluid

Title: ADVANCES IN LONG‐RANGE, HIGH‐SPEED OPTICAL COMMUNICATION
Authors with affiliations: FELDMAN, S.; BARTON, G.G.
Abstract: During periods of radio silence under Emission Control, communication depends on the slow ship‐to‐ship, manual‐visual, 8‐10 wpm Morse code signaling shutter searchlight employing the ac 1000‐watt incandescent or the ac 1000‐watt compact arc mercury‐xenon lamp. These sources can be replaced by the dc compact arc xenon lamp to provide longer daylight ranges and highspeed (100 wpm teletype, 150 wpm Morse code, voice, etc.) communication since this source has superior brightness and the facility of considerably more rapid modulation. The excessive weight and size of the ac‐dc power convertor and modulating circuitry which had prevented use of the dc xenon lamp have been overcome by developments in solid state electronics such as the rapid, high current, simmer‐flash, 100 to one light output xenon lamp pulsing using the reliable, uncomplicated, low‐cost silicon controlled rectifier shunt switch which could eliminate the mechanical signaling shutter. Laboratory and sea evaluations have proved the feasibility of and provided the long daylight high‐speed optical communication ranges that could be attained from operation of the dc 1000‐watt and 2200‐watt xenon lamps at the focus of 12‐inch, 18‐inch searchlights and in the Fresnel lens omni‐directional beacon which a command ship uses to signal all ships in a task force at once. With these advances, optical communication provides the highspeed capability of radio communication, particularly, also, with the new omnidirectional transceiver. © 1981 by the American Society of Naval Engineers
Index Keywords: Optical instruments; Ships
References: Bourne, H.K., Beeson, E.S.G., “The Application of Electric Discharge Lamps to Daylight Signaling,” (1950) Proc. Title: Using materials science
Affiliations: Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States
Authors with affiliations: Baker, W.O., Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States
Abstract: The science of the solid state has joined nuclear science and molecular biology as a field of major importance in the latter half of the 20th century. It took particular shape during the genesis of solid-state electronics and the post-transistor era of integrated circuits for telecommunications, computers, and digital signal machines. However, these developments were soon joined by techniques from the ancient fields of metallurgy and ceramics and contributions from the more current fields of synthetic polymers, rubbers, plastics, and modified bioorganic substances. This vast realm was characterized by a National Academy of Sciences study of the 1970's as "materials science and engineering." The public, as well as the scientific and engineering community, are currently concerned about the uses of research and development and the applications of knowledge for national progress. Consideration is given here to how well we are using the science of materials for industrial strength and such governmental objectives as national security and energy economy.

Title: LASER PROCESSING RESEARCH AT TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute, Coal Combustion Systems Division, (Report) EPRI CS
Authors with affiliations: Parker, D.L.
Abstract: This paper describes a variety of new laser processing applications being investigated in the Institute for Solid State Electronics at Texas A&M University. Areas of relatively advanced research include: 1) improved ohmic contacts in III-V compound semiconductors, 2) computer controlled pattern generating, 3) flying spot laser beam analysis of active devices, 4) lifetime doping in silicon, 5) diffused and polysilicon resistor trimming, and 6) link cutting and capacitor trimming. Areas of research which are being considered for the near future include: laser annealing of polycrystalline film, laser driven diffusion and CVD processes, and laser damage gettering effects.
Index Keywords: Integrated circuit manufacture
Correspondence Address: Parker, D.L.
Conference name: Symp Proc - Univ, Gov, Microelectron Symp

Title: PUBLISH AND RETRIEVE MATERIALS DATA WITH EMIS.
Source title: IEE Proceedings I: Solid State and Electron Devices
Authors with affiliations: Weiss, B.L.; Sears, J.L.
Abstract: EMIS (electronic materials information service) is a computer-based online system currently being developed by INSPEC for launch in October 1981. It gives textual and numeric information on the properties of specified materials used in solid-state electronics and on the suppliers of such materials. The database is interrogated by a simple interactive technique. The user gains access to EMIS using the same equipment as is employed by information officers for searching online bibliographic databases.
Index Keywords: Semiconductor devices; Semiconductor materials; Information retrieval systems
Correspondence Address: Weiss, B.L.

Title: CONCEPTUAL PROBLEMS IN MODELING SUBMICRON DEVICE PHYSICS.
Authors with affiliations: Grubin, H.L.; Ferry, D.K.
Abstract: The study of high field transport in semiconductor devices has progressed very rapidly over the past decade, sustained in part by rapid technological advances in the solid state electronics industry. These have, however, generated important conceptual problems in modeling of high speed transport in nonlinear semiconductors. Some of these problems are discussed.
Index Keywords: Semiconductor devices
Correspondence Address: Grubin, H.L.
Conference name: Proc of the Annu Conf on the Phys of Compd Semicond Interfaces, 8th

Title: RECENT DEVELOPMENTS IN POLYMERIC RESIST MATERIALS.
Authors with affiliations: Mitra, S.
Abstract: A review is presented of recent advances that have been made in the design, synthesis, and performance of polymeric resist materials. Resists for all three of the major lithographic techniques used for solid-state electronics, namely photo-, e-beam, and X-ray methods are surveyed. Though only photoresist systems are now of widespread commercial use, the development of e-beam and X-ray resists has led to the feasibility of attainment of remarkable complexity in integrated circuitry. Studies based on the effect of various physicochemical parameters of these materials on their merits as fine-line lithographic resists have also been included.
Index Keywords: Photoresists; PHOTORESISTS
Correspondence Address: Mitra, S.

Title: EVOLUTION OF PHOTOGRAPHIC DATA MANAGEMENT.
Authors with affiliations: Stern, David M.
Abstract: The paper concentrations on analysis and reduction of data collected on motion picture film at cine or high-speed frame rates. Even though an individual photograph taken at a precise instant contains much information, two pictures separated by a time interval offer even more information. Along with the development of motion picture techniques, suitable projectors were also developed to enable efficient analyses to be made. The stop motion projectors now in common use were eventually developed. The field is rapidly changing, and many innovations are evolving. Digitizing devices that have been developed to increase speed and accuracy in data reduction are described. Advances in solid state electronics make it possible to add many special features to digitizing equipment, some of which are enumerated. Information from the equipment can be transmitted to computers for the necessary processing.
Index Keywords: DATA PROCESSING - Data Reduction and Analysis; MOTION PICTURES - Applications; Photogrammetry
Correspondence Address: Stern, David M.

Authors: Mayo John S., Robinson Arthur L.
Title: POWER OF MICROELECTRONICS.
Authors with affiliations: Mayo, John S.; Robinson, Arthur L.
Abstract: Solid-state electronics has made enormous contributions to allied fields such as computer science and telecommunications and to others as diverse as medicine and space exploration. With the advent of VLSI circuits, even the development of electronics technology itself depends strongly on computers and test instruments that use integrated circuits. A primary example is computer-aided design (CAD). In the last five years, integrated circuits have become so complex that without the advanced analysis and extensive simulation techniques available through CAD, it would be virtually impossible to design VLSI chips. But with CAD, even complex circuits can be designed in a few months with no real increase in labor. The integrated-circuit industry today is essentially pulling itself up by its bootstraps, relying heavily on systems built with the industry's most advanced products.
Index Keywords: Integrated circuits
Correspondence Address: Mayo, John S.

Title: Electronic measurement in the oceans.
Abstract: Use of solid state electronics in wave height buoys, wave force measurement, water velocimeters (for measurement of water particle velocity in waves), water depth measurement, tide gauges, and height above the sea surface are briefly reviewed. (N.G.G.)
Index Keywords: Flow measurement

Title: Application of microprocessor controls to open and close die hydraulic forging.
Source title: IN: PROC. 36TH NAT. CONF. ON FLUID POWER, (CLEVELAND, U.S.A.: OCT. 28-30, 1980)
Volume: 34 , Chicago, U.S.A., Nat. Conf. Fluid Power, 1980
Authors with affiliations: Sonnenberg, S.
Abstract: A short history of application of solid state electronics to the control of forging press installations and the expanded capabilities achieved by use of microprocessors and computer technology in modern hydraulic presses and manipulators. (A)
Abbreviated Source Title: IN: PROC. 36TH NAT. CONF. ON FLUID POWER, (CLEVELAND, U.S.A.: OCT. 28-30, 1980)

Title: ADVANCED SOLID-STATE ELECTRONICS FOR 18 TO 60 GHz COMMUNICATIONS.
Source title: Conference Record - International Conference on Communications
Authors with affiliations: Pan, J.J.
Abstract: Advanced solid-state electronics for 18 to 60 GHz communications are reported. Currently, the medium-power, Si DD IMPATT diode generates 2 w output at Q-band while the GaAs MESFET has 1. 65 w at 18 GHz. The power generation using these devices becomes competitive with the bulky TWTs. New InP TEDs have been developed achieving a 7. 8 db noise figure at 35 GHz, while demonstrating better efficiency than GaAs TEDs. Low noise MESFETs now have frequency ranges to 38 GHz and might be designed for use as LNAs, LOs, modulators, mixers, and limiters. Some system applications for MESFET are illustrated. The new GaAs Schottky-barrier diode recently demonstrated a cutoff frequency of 5000 GHz with zero-bias junction capacitance of 10 fF for high performance millimeter wave mixers, parametric amplifiers, detectors and switches. Monolithic gigabit logics and receiver front-ends are described.
Index Keywords: Semiconductor diodes, IMPATT; TRANSISTORS, FIELD EFFECT - Microwaves; MESFET; Communication satellites
Correspondence Address: Pan, J.J.
Abbreviated Source Title: Conf Rec Int Conf Commun ICC

Title: EVOLUTION OF PAYLOAD SYSTEMS.
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Authors with affiliations: Turner, J.J.
Abstract: Developments in solid state electronics, computers and sensor technology, have resulted in significant changes in the design of payload and control systems for rockets and balloons over the last decade. Computers are now generally used for real time payload checkout or data processing while microcomputers have been used for ground and flight systems and will eventually replace the analog control electronics. New techniques for gyroscopic sensors have produced lower cost and more accurate inertial rate and position sensing devices. Other developments have taken place in optical sensors, low light television, telemetry and telecommand. The paper describes the application of these techniques to sounding rocket and balloon systems and probable future developments.
Index Keywords: Balloons; COMPUTERS - Applications; Control systems; Electronic equipment; ROCKETS AND MISSILES
Correspondence Address: Turner, J.J.
Publisher: Eur Space Agency, Sci & Tech Publ Branch ESTEC, Noordwijk, Neth
Conference name: Eur Space Agency Spec Publ ESA SP 152, ESA Symp on Eur Rocket & Balloon Programmes & Relat Res, 5th

Authors: Higbee Robert G., Ratkevic John J.
Title: NIDIR SYSTEM - PERFORMANCE AND ECONOMY FOR RANGE INSTRUMENTATION.
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Thermoelectric Energy Conversion
Authors with affiliations: Higbee, Robert G.; Ratkevic, John J.
Abstract: Test ranges throughout the world are required to update their range instrumentation to match the operational characteristics of the equipment under test. It has become a fact of life that budgets for range instrumentation rarely, if ever, keep pace with the funding levels for system development: hence the majority of range operators are faced with the very real problem of providing higher and higher performance on a shoestring. A new instrument is described that combines solid-state electronics with a modified high-performance NIKE HERCULES antenna pedestal to provide an economical solution to the needs of today's test ranges.
Index Keywords: Radar
Correspondence Address: Higbee, Robert G.
Publisher: IEEE Aerosp and Electron Syst Soc, Piscataway, NJ
Conference name: Rec of the IEEE Int Radar Conf

Authors: Ehrlich D.J., Osgood R.M., Jr., Deutsch T.F.
Title: Laser Microphotochemistry for Use in Solid-State Electronics
Affiliations: Lincoln Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02173, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ehrlich, D.J., Lincoln Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02173, United States; Osgood, R.M., Jr., Lincoln Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02173, United States; Deutsch, T.F., Lincoln Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02173, United States
Abstract: A. focused, ultraviolet (UV) laser beam has been used to produce micrometer-sized chemical processes on solid surfaces. These processes are initiated by the photodissociation of a molecular gas in the vicinity of the gas-solid interface. Depending on whether the active photofragment reacts with or is adsorbed on the solid, microetching or microdeposition occurs. Both the surface properties of the solid and the gas-phase kinetics contribute to the process localization. Metal alkyls and methyl halides have been used as parent molecules for deposition and etching, respectively. A focused, 3 mW UV laser is sufficiently intense to produce satisfactory rates for both processes. Several applications of this small-scale photochemistry to microelectronics have been investigated. © 1980 IEEE
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Photochemical Reactions; LASERS - Applications; SOLID STATE DEVICES

Authors: Hata Hidetoh, Ishikawa Sadayoshi, Yoshioka Masanori, Matsuo Yuji
Title: OUTLINE OF THE PUBLIC FACSIMILE COMMUNICATION SYSTEM.
Authors with affiliations: Hata, Hidetoh; Ishikawa, Sadayoshi; Yoshioka, Masanori; Matsuo, Yuji
Abstract: Facsimile communication differs from teletype communications because it transmits any character, pattern or drawing which is on paper. Therefore, in Japan, where Kanji characters (Chinese ideographs) are used, facsimile has been widely utilized for recorded communication. With the development of solid-state electronics, a high-speed facsimile machine with redundancy reduction coding function has become popular, and qualities such as multi-address communication, automatic sending/receiving function etc. , have been improved. Nevertheless, facsimile equipment is still expensive. This is why, in spite of the great demand for facsimile communication, it is used mainly in large scale business enterprises. Low cost terminals were developed to meet the requirement immediately. A facsimile network was established to accomplish low cost communication service. This service is called ″the Public Facsimile Communication Service″ .
Index Keywords: Facsimile equipment
Correspondence Address: Hata, Hidetoh

Title: Combined Magnetic Levitation and Propulsion: The Mag-Transit Concept
Affiliations: Automated Transportation Systems Organization of the Boeing Aerospace Company, M.S 9E-68, P. O. Box 3999, Seattle, WA 98124, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rule, R.G., Automated Transportation Systems Organization of the Boeing Aerospace Company, M.S 9E-68, P. O. Box 3999, Seattle, WA 98124, United States; Gilliland, R.G., Automated Transportation Systems Organization of the Boeing Aerospace Company, M.S 9E-68, P. O. Box 3999, Seattle, WA 98124, United States
Abstract: Mag-Transit is a unique combination of magnetic levitation and propulsion for people mover applications. Linear induction motors are used for levitation, propulsion, braking, and guidance. Since there are a minimum of moving parts there is a potential for a substantial increase in system reliability and availability as compared to conventional systems. Modern solid-state technology provides the capability to condition sufficient quantities of electrical energy to control motor excitation, and thereby levitation, within a closed-loop servo system. Real time measurements of air gaps and vehicle accelerations are used to compute the desired levitation force. In addition, the solid-state electronics provides the ability to control independently the speed of the vehicle by a continuously variable excitation frequency to the motors. An overview is provided of the Mag-Transit concept from a control system standpoint. Results from a dynamic simulation of a test vehicle configuration are presented. © 1980 IEEE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC TRACTION

Authors: Musgrave G., Sherlock J., O'Kelly D., Smith I.K., Wilson S.S.
Title: The TIGER project: a proposal for utilizing industrial waste heat.
Source title: Journal of the Institute of Energy
Authors with affiliations: Musgrave, G.; Sherlock, J.; O'Kelly, D.; Smith, I.K.; Wilson, S.S.
Abstract: The paper describes a proposed waste heat recovery scheme to convert low-grade waste heat to electrical power. Essential features of the system are a heat exchanger/boiler using an organic fluid cycle to drive a high-speed vapour turbine directly connected to an induction generator. The high-frequency output, about 1 kHz, is then converted by solid-state electronics to give a constant-voltage mains-frequency electrical output. Projected efficiency values and costs for a 100 kVA unit are given with a brief discussion of the possible areas of application of such a system. (A)

Title: An in situ attenuance meter for very turbid waters
Affiliations: Institut für Meeresforschung Bremerhaven, am Handelshafen 12, Bremerhaven, 2850, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Ohm, K., Institut für Meeresforschung Bremerhaven, am Handelshafen 12, Bremerhaven, 2850, Germany
Abstract: For investigations in very turbid waters an attenuance meter has been built with a range of attenuation coefficients c between 4 m-1 and 400 m-1. The instrument is of conventional mechanical design with opposite windows 10 mm apart. Unmodulated light is used. Basic features of the meter are a rugged and compact housing, solid state electronics and electro-optical components, a monochromatic light source, and an efficient lens system. The underwater unit can operate on a single conductor cable. The data output is compatible with larger data acquisition systems. The low power requirements admit measurements from small boats. The effect of forward scattering is estimated, which may cause an error of less than 5% in the attenuation coefficient. It is shown that a short path length is a reasonable low cost solution to the problem of measuring attenuation in very turbid waters. © 1979 Deutsches Hydrographisches Institut.

Title: Are we really ready for VLSI2?
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers - IEEE International Solid-State Circuits Conference
Affiliations: Intel Corporation, Santa Clara, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Moore, G., Intel Corporation, Santa Clara, CA, United States
Abstract: The industry's technological ability to construct complex circuit functions is in danger of far outstripping its ability to conceive and design products that can utilize the complexity. The few exceptions are mostly memories. The efforts attempting to utilize broadly the technology require qualitatively different commitments than has been the case historically in the semiconductor industry. Systems architecture, software and the need for customer support systems vie with lithography, film deposition and diffusion for resources. There are enough different forces coming to bear to indicate that it is not clear that industry will continue to be driven by the processing technology. This address will attempt to describe principal changes taking place that could affect the structure of the solid-state electronic industries. © 1979 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Product design; Semiconductor device manufacture; VLSI circuits; Complex circuits; Customer support; Design products; Film deposition; Processing technologies; Semiconductor industry; Solid state electronics; Systems architecture; Lithography
Correspondence Address: Moore, G.; Intel CorporationUnited States
Sponsors: IEEE Philadelphia Section;IEEE Solid-State Circuits Council;University of Pennsylvania
Publisher: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc.
Conference name: 26th IEEE International Solid-State Circuits Conference, ISSCC 1979
Abbreviated Source Title: Dig Tech Pap IEEE Int Solid State Circuits Conf

Authors: Palkuti Leslie J., Macpherson Alan C., Prince John L., Glista Jr. Andrew S.
Title: CHARACTERISTICS OF DEVICES AND INTEGRATED CIRCUITS AT 260 degree C FOR NAVY APPLICATIONS.
Source title: Proceedings - Electronic Components and Technology Conference
Authors with affiliations: Palkuti, Leslie J.; Macpherson, Alan C.; Prince, John L.; Glista Jr., Andrew S.
Abstract: Extensive characterizations of discrete devices and integrated circuits are reported over the temperature range from room temperature to 250 degree C and 300 degree C. These are the initial results of a Navy program for the evaluation and design of solid-state electronics to be operated uncooled in aircraft-engine control applications. Discrete devices of essentially all generic types are found to operate with usable characteristics at junction temperatures up to at least 300 degree C. Both analog and digital IC exhibited useful operation at temperature near 250 degree C.
Index Keywords: INTEGRATED CIRCUITS - High Temperature Effects; Semiconductor devices; Aircraft
Correspondence Address: Palkuti, Leslie J.
Conference name: Proc Electron Components Conf 29th

Authors: Walko Lawrence C., Seymour Timothy J.
Title: NEW TECHNIQUES FOR THE MEASUREMENT OF NATURAL AND SIMULATED LIGHTNING PHENOMENA.
Source title: IEEE International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility
Authors with affiliations: Walko, Lawrence C.; Seymour, Timothy J.
Abstract: Within the last few years new techniques have been developed for the measurement of natural and simulated lightning phenomena. These techniques have evolved from the need for increasingly accurate measurements of the electromagnetic effects of lightning as in regards to aircraft lightning protection. This need stems from the use of new technologies such as low power level solid state electronics in critical aircraft structures. This paper describes new techniques used to increase the accuracy of natural and simulated lightning measurements and describes techniques that are in development.
Index Keywords: Lightning
Correspondence Address: Walko, Lawrence C.
Conference name: IEEE Int Symp Electromagn Compat

Title: PROGRAMMABLE CONTROLLERS ADD TO STATION OPERATION.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: A new approach to monitoring and controlling oil pipeline pump stations is described that applies solid-state electronics in the form of programmable logic controllers. Seaway Pipeline Inc, owned by a consortium of refinery and oil-related companies, has replaced conventional relay panels with solid-state programmable logic controllers (PC's) to control pump units and scraper-sequencing functions at six pump stations along its product system. Developed by Struthers-Dunn Inc, the S-D 77 programmable controller has gained wide pipeline industry acceptance since it was introduced for other industrial applications eight years ago.
Index Keywords: Petroleum pipelines

Authors: Lowry James L., Russell Dallas W.
Title: ELECTRONIC CONTROLLER TO REDUCE POWER LOSSES IN LIGHTLY LOADED INDUCTION MOTORS.
Authors with affiliations: Lowry, James L.; Russell, Dallas W.
Abstract: The losses in an induction motor operating at light loads can be reduced by decreasing the supply voltage. Recent advances in solid-state electronics and recent increases in the cost of electric energy make it economically feasible to apply electronic devices to reduce losses in induction motors which operate at light loads for a significant portion of their duty cycle. This paper describes an electronic controller for such applications and presents some test results.
Index Keywords: Electric motors, Induction
Correspondence Address: Lowry, James L.
Conference name: Proc of the Annu Southeast Symp on Syst Theory, 11th

Authors: Hauser James N., Penton Larry S.
Title: NEW MARINE MAGNETOMETER FOR PIPELINE LOCATION AND SEAFLOOR RECONNAISSANCE.
Source title: Proceedings of the Gas Conditioning Conference
Authors with affiliations: Hauser, James N.; Penton, Larry S.
Abstract: In order to acquire state of the art marine magnetometry data, an existing magnetometer design has been updated with all solid state electronics, digital displays and BCD outputs. Significant improvements in field performance have been made through the incorporation of sensor depth display and tow cable interchangeability. These design criteria were in direct response to continuous feedback to the design engineer from field operations personnel.
Index Keywords: PETROLEUM PIPELINES - Offshore; Magnetometers
Correspondence Address: Hauser, James N.
Conference name: Mar Technol 79, Ocean Energy, Mar Technol Soc Annu Conf, 15th

Title: Integrated Circuit Characteristics at 260°C for Aircraft Engine-Control Applications
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Components, Hybrids, and Manufacturing Technology
Affiliations: ARACOR, 1223 E. Arques Ave., Sunnyvale, CA 94086, United States; Clemson University, Clemson, SC 29631, United States; Naval Air Systems Command, Washington, DC 20361, United States
Authors with affiliations: Palkuti, L.J., ARACOR, 1223 E. Arques Ave., Sunnyvale, CA 94086, United States, Naval Air Systems Command, Washington, DC 20361, United States; Prince, J.L., Clemson University, Clemson, SC 29631, United States
Abstract: Extensive characterizations of discrete devices and integrated circuits are reported over the temperature range from room temperature to 250°C and 300°C. These are the initial results of a Navy program for the evaluation and design of solid-state electronics to be operated uncooled in aircraft-engine control applications. Based on these results and results from earlier investigations, discrete semiconductor devices of essentially all generic types function with usable characteristics at junction temperatures up to at least 300°C. First-order device parameter changes result from increased leakage, reduced mobility, and increased resistivity. Both analog and digital integrated circuits were found to exhibit dc as well as useful dynamic characteristics up to temperatures near 250°C. Bipolar circuits with either junction or dielectric isolation degrade due to changes in device operating points and high leakage currents. In analog circuits the temperature capabiity is found to depend critically on the specific circuit design implemented. For a variety of CMOS devices tested a pnpn latchup mechanism between the p-channel transistor and the input protection network limits useful device operation to 260°C. Changes in device and circuit layout are needed to circumvent this failure mode. No fundamental barrier to 300°C functionality of integrated circuits (designed specifically for high-temperature application) was found. © 1979 IEEE
Index Keywords: AIRCRAFT ENGINES - Control; INTEGRATED CIRCUITS

Title: SPACE SHUTTLE LIGHTNING PROTECTION.

Abstract: The paper discusses the evolution of the Space Shuttle Lightning Protection Program, including the generala types of protection, testing, and analyses being performed to assess the lightning-transient-damage susceptibility of solid-state electronics.

Title: COIN HANDLING GOES ELECTRONIC.
Authors with affiliations: Habib, Nelson
Abstract: Coin telephones have to operate in a hostile natural environment and also may be vandalized. In order to make coin sets less vulnerable a kit has been developed which replaces the electromechanical coin-handling apparatus with more reliable solid-state electronics. The new kit consists of a signal unit which contains piezoelectric transducers and a chassis which contains two hybrid integrated circuits and a transistorized speech network. This new electronic kit is more reliable and is easier to manufacture than the electromechanical parts it replaces.
Index Keywords: Telephone apparatus
Correspondence Address: Habib, Nelson

Title: A.C. driven induction motors for variable delivery fluid pumping.
Abstract: The advantages of variable speed pumping over flow regulation with valves etc. are outlined. Three systems of pumping control developed by Ergotron using solid state electronics are briefly described, applicable to the cases of: (i) free liquid flow, as in an open channel, (ii) flow control in pipes at low pressure and (iii) high pressure flow regulation. Each system uses feedback from some type of flow or pressure meter to control electronically the rate of rotation of the pump drive, and this th delivery from the pump. The system may also be applied to dosing and mixing apparatus. (C.C.B.)

Authors: Bezat Alexander G., Montague Lyle L.
Title: EFFECT OF ENDLESS BURN-IN ON RELIABILITY GROWTH PROJECTIONS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Reliability and Maintainability Symposium
Authors with affiliations: Bezat, Alexander G.; Montague, Lyle L.
Abstract: Current reliability prediction methods treat solid-state electronics equipment on the basis of a constant failure rate throughout the operating life of the equipment. This paper presents an extensive data base (over 19 multiplied by 10**9 part hours), supported by theory, that shows failure rate of solid-state electronics to be a decreasing function with operational age of individual equipments. Data is presented in graphical form, including a best-fit equation for the data. The mechanics of prediction methods are shown, along with examples. The entire concept is summarized as a family of growth curves, wherein the applicable curve is dependent upon the design/process maturity of the equipment at the time it is manufactured.
Index Keywords: Avionics
Correspondence Address: Bezat, Alexander G.
Conference name: Proc Annu Reliab Maintainability Symp

Title: MAG-TRANSIT - DEVELOPMENT AT BOEING.
Authors with affiliations: Gilliland, Richard G.
Abstract: Mag transit is a combination of magnetic levitation and propulsion for people mover applications. Linear electric motors are used for levitation, propulsion, braking, guidance and suspension. Since there are a minimum of moving parts there is a potential for a substantial increase in system reliability and availability as compared to conventional systems. Modern solid state technology provides the capability to condition sufficient quantities of electrical energy to control motor excitation, and thereby levitation, within a closed loop servo system. Real time measurements of air gaps and vehicle accelerations are used to compute the desired levitation force. In addition the solid state electronics provides the ability to independently control the speed of the vehicle by a continuously variable excitation frequency to the motors.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC MOTORS, LINEAR - Applications; Rapid transit
Correspondence Address: Gilliland, Richard G.
Conference name: IEEE Veh Technol Conf, 29th, Conf Rec of Pap

Title: Optical data conversion program at white sands missile range
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Optics Division, Instrumentation Directorate, White Sands Missile Range, NM  88002, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hale, A.D., Optics Division, Instrumentation Directorate, White Sands Missile Range, NM  88002, United States
Abstract: This paper covers the Optical Data Conversion (ODC) Modernization Program at White Sands Missile Range (WSMR). During Phase I, the Telereadex film readers were refurbished using solid-state electronics. The recordex accumulators were replaced by solid-state type and the card punches were replaced by magnetic tape units (MTU's). In Phase II, the capability of reading encoded dials was added to the ODC. Two Contraves AFB-2 readers were purchased to read Contraves Model F type film formats. Each Telereadex was retrofitted with data matrix readers to read Contraves Model F type film formats and Cine-Sextant film formats. Phase III is now in progress. Digital controllers will be retrofitted to the film reading station. The controllers will perform an internal error checking on the data prior to sending it to the data handling system. The data handling system will receive data from all nine of the reading stations. The system will format and store the data until all of the data from a given mission is received. The data will be checked for consistency and will be recorded on magnetic tape which will be used in the data reduction. © 1978 SPIE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Magnetic tape; Materials handling; Materials handling equipment; Missiles; Selenium compounds; Data handling systems; Data matrices; Digital controllers; During phase; Error-checking; Modernization programs; Solid state electronics; White Sands Missile Range; Data handling

Source title: Photo and Electro-Opt in Range Instrum
Authors with affiliations: Hale, Amory D.
Abstract: This paper covers the Optical Data Conversion (ODC) Modernization Program at White Sands Missile Range (WSMR). During Phase I, the Telereadex film readers were refurbished using solid-state electronics. The recordex accumulators were replaced by solid-state type and the card punches were replaced by magnetic tape units (MTU's). In Phase II, the capability of reading encoded dials was added to the ODC. Two Contraves AFB-2 readers were purchased to read Contraves Model F type film formats. Each Telereadex was retrofitted with data matrix readers to read Contraves Model F type film formats and Cine-Sextant film formats. Phase III is now in progress. Title: STATIC ELIMINATION - WHERE DO WE BEGIN.
Authors with affiliations: Hartley, Ralph S.
Abstract: Solid state electronics have all degrees of static sensitivity, and a program for static elimination begins with identifying those items which require protection. To the use of these components, this means having a proper package clearly labeled from the supplier so everyone from receiving through assembly is alerted to wear wrist straps, avoid touching leads, use ionized air and apply all other good manufacturing practices. Physical identification is easy. The difficulty is the engineering determination of which items should be so identified. There is no clear definition in the semiconductor, integrated circuits or thin film resistor specifications. Each implies that not all such items are sensitive as illustrated by the section 5, Preparation for Delivery Instructions of MIL-C-38510C, General Specification for Microcircuits. Those who work with the detail specifications could make this determination and implement it through EIA. The user designers could then carry this over to hardware drawings which in turn could be carried over to manufacturing paper cautionary notes. Such a system provides a continuous awareness path from supplier through final assembly.
Index Keywords: Electronics; STATIC ELECTRICITY; Semiconductor devices
Correspondence Address: Hartley, Ralph S.
Publisher: Ind and Sci Conf Manage, Inc, Chicago, Ill
Conference name: Int Microelectron Conf, Proc of the Tech Program, Feb 28-Mar 2

Title: PROGRAMMABLE CONTROLLERS.
Source title: Inst Certif Mech Electr Eng S Afr Arthur Hallet Mem Lect
Authors with affiliations: Girdler, Roger
Abstract: The article discusses the programmable controller as a piece of industrialized solid state electronics which replaces the time-honored relay panel as a means of controlling and interlocking plants and machines. It consists of three main components, the ″central processing unit″ , the ″input/output structure″ and the ″peripherals″ , each of which are discussed. The article explains what a programmable controller is, what it is doing, and, above all, what advantage it offers to plant personnel over conventional control systems.
Index Keywords: Control facilities; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS - Control; PROGRAMMABLE CONTROLLERS; Control systems, Programmed
Correspondence Address: Girdler, Roger
Abbreviated Source Title: Inst Certif Mech Electr Eng S Afr Arthur Hallet Mem Lect

Title: AIRCRAFT LIGHTNING VULNERABILITY TESTING.
Authors with affiliations: Boggess, Robert L.
Abstract: Flight critical fly-by-wire systems, solid state electronics, and an increased use of composite materials tend to increase the vulnerability of modern aircraft to lightning field effects. Lightning is transient, random and destructive. Therefore, laboratory testing is required to determine vulnerability levels. Laboratory testing provides design criteria data now, and improved circuit modeling can provide even better data. One such improvement is suggested and an example is given.
Index Keywords: Lightning; Aircraft
Correspondence Address: Boggess, Robert L.
Conference name: IEEE Proc Natl Aerosp Electron Conf NAECON '77

Authors: Mrochek J.E., Burtis C.A., Johnson W.F., Bauer M.L., Lakomy D.G., Genung R.K., Scott C.D.
Title: A new portable centrifugal analyzer with expanded versatility
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Nat. Lab., Oak Ridge, Tenn. 37830, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mrochek, J.E., Oak Ridge Nat. Lab., Oak Ridge, Tenn. 37830, United States; Burtis, C.A., Oak Ridge Nat. Lab., Oak Ridge, Tenn. 37830, United States; Johnson, W.F., Oak Ridge Nat. Lab., Oak Ridge, Tenn. 37830, United States; Bauer, M.L.; Lakomy, D.G.; Genung, R.K.; Scott, C.D.
Abstract: New developments in solid state electronics applied to the centrifugal fast analyzer have resulted in a prototype portable instrument with several unique improvements, yielding expanded analytical versatility and the capability to operate from 110 V ac or a rechargeable battery pack. The analyzer, contained in a 47 x 28 x 30 cm box and weighing 25.4 kg, utilizes a self contained microprocessor to control some analyzer functions as well as to perform data acquisition and analysis. Hardcopy output is produced by an integral thermal printer. Several analysis options are available, including determination of reaction rate by linear regression analysis. Temperature is controlled at one of three set points (25, 30, or 37°C) by means of a thermoelectric heat pump located in the rotor holder. A clutch brake assembly incorporated in the rotor drive system enables the rotor to be accelerated to 80% of run speed within 100 ms. Utilization of a parallel channel rotor and a high resolution, 2 MHz clock enables reactions to be monitored within 100 ms of solution transfer. A maximum of 99 observations may be acquired at variable intervals, the minimum being one observation per revolution at 4000 rpm (one observation consists of measurements of dark current and transmission or fluorescence signals from 17 cuvets). The drive system, rotor speed, and the clutch brake are controlled by the microprocessor and automatically synchronized with data acquisition. Other analyzer operations currently under control of the microprocessor include the selection of preamplifier gain, transmission filters, and primary and secondary filters for fluorescence. The system is described and its various analytical capabilities are evaluated.
Index Keywords: enzyme

Authors: Meador J.W., Hongo T., Kaku K., Vakamudi A.K., Akutsu T.
Title: Peak and phasic changes of power utilization of a total artificial heart in response to after-load
Source title: Transactions - American Society for Artificial Internal Organs
Affiliations: Cardiovascular Surgical Research Laboratories, Texas Heart Institute, St. Luke’s Episcopal Hospital and Texas Children’s Hospital, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meador, J.W., Cardiovascular Surgical Research Laboratories, Texas Heart Institute, St. Luke’s Episcopal Hospital and Texas Children’s Hospital, United States; Hongo, T., Cardiovascular Surgical Research Laboratories, Texas Heart Institute, St. Luke’s Episcopal Hospital and Texas Children’s Hospital, United States; Kaku, K., Cardiovascular Surgical Research Laboratories, Texas Heart Institute, St. Luke’s Episcopal Hospital and Texas Children’s Hospital, United States; Vakamudi, A.K., Cardiovascular Surgical Research Laboratories, Texas Heart Institute, St. Luke’s Episcopal Hospital and Texas Children’s Hospital, United States; Akutsu, T., Cardiovascular Surgical Research Laboratories, Texas Heart Institute, St. Luke’s Episcopal Hospital and Texas Children’s Hospital, United States
Abstract: Over the past 2 decades, various centers in the United States and throughout the world have been engaged in the development of a partial and/or total artificial heart. As animal survival times with these implanted devices are currently on the order of months, clinical application has ceased to be a dream and more of a reality. Conjunctive development of automatic control mechanisms and implantable power sources for the prosthetic heart has not been as tacid but it has experienced a revitalization in interest with the advent of solid state electronics. In order to properly interface an automatic control system with a partial or TAH, analysis of the power requirements and the concurrent requirements of the utilization of this power for the implantable pump(s) under subtle and radical changes in the physiological environment of the patient are necessary. Evaluation of the TAH stability in nonsteady state conditions will not only serve to simplify the control software but should also concomitantly aid in creating a more active life for the recipient of a cardiac prosthesis. The results of the current experiments indicate that the stability of the pumps being developed in our laboratories show no excessive variance in response to moderately changing after-loads. In addition, for constant ventricular input pressures, resultant ventricular peak and phasic power utilization remains relatively constant through a wide range of after-loads while the delivered power to the arterial system reacts in a physiologically compatible linear fashion as a function of after-load. While future pump designs and experiments of this nature should enhance these results, the time has arrived to evolve the partial or TAH and automatic control and power assemblies not as distinct entities, but rather as an integral system. © 1977 American Society of Artificial Internal Organs.

Title: INTEGRITY IN FLIGHT CONTROL SYSTEMS.
Authors with affiliations: Kurzhals, Peter R.; Deloach, Richard
Abstract: With the increased use of electronic flight-control systems for better aircraft performance and cost-effectiveness, development and test techniques which can insure the integrity of such systems have become critically important. Rapid advances in solid-state electronics have permitted a hundred-fold decrease in control computer size, power and cost the past two decades. Designers have capitalized on these gains primarily by incorporating additional control functions to improve aircraft capabilities. Resulting control systems have become very complex and reliability requirements have mushroomed. A summary is presented of the evolution of these requirements, outlines the current status of flight control reliability, and highlights promising methods of achieving integrity in future flight control systems.
Index Keywords: Aircraft
Correspondence Address: Kurzhals, Peter R.
Conference name: Proc of the Jt Autom Control Conf

Title: The Impact of Engineering Technology Programs on Engineering and Engineering Education
Affiliations: Dean of Division of Engineering, Technology, and Architecture, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK 74074, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mccollom, K.A., Dean of Division of Engineering, Technology, and Architecture, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK 74074, United States
Abstract: Over recent decades, there has been an enormous expansion in the amount and complexity of scientific and engineering knowledge. Space exploration was climaxed by landing on the moon; solid state electronics has had significant impact in computers, controls, and a myriad of other devices; and nuclear fission is being used for the generation of significant quantities of electrical power. Besides learning about these expanded areas of knowledge, the engineering graduate must know the timeless basics as always. Also, it has become apparent that the public, with the increased complexity of our society, is asking that engineering solutions be related to society goals. Title: WHAT'S NEW IN AIR COMPRESSORS.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Solid state electronics, better operating efficiencies and oil separation, plus new compression chamber design are among top features manufacturers praise. The article discusses a number of developments and changes that are being built into this type of equipment, including solid-state control on 200 hp, 250 hp and 300 hp units from one manufacturer, a 2-stage centrifugal compressor, a renewed interest in reciprocating compressor design, and others.
Index Keywords: Compressors

Title: MAGNETICALLY SUSPENDED VEHICLES FOR URBAN TRANSPORT SYSTEMS.
Authors with affiliations: Jayawant, B.V.
Abstract: Of the five different levitation technologies, two are likely to be applicable to low-speed operation. One system using controlled dc electromagnets to suspend large weights such as passenger carrying vehicles has become progessively more feasible technically, owing to advances in solid-state electronics. It is largely through these that a 1 t 4-passenger vehicle operating on a 30 m track has been built in the Applied Science Laboratories of the University of Sussex and has been demonstrated publicly. The operating experience of this vehicle has shown clearly that the controlled electromagnetic suspension is capable of providing a transport system that possesses passenger-attraction potential. This is meant to be a system that provides a frequent and thus highly reliable operation; for city-center or urban application it must be noiseless, and, if it is fully automatic and operating on segregated tracks, the guideway structure must be visually nonintrusive. Although the principal aim of eliminating physical contact is not so much to save energy as to obtain very high reliability, it is worth noting that a vehicle carrying eight passengers at 30 mile/h and using controlled dc electromagnets for suspension is likely to require less power than that wasted in the transmission unit of a car.
Index Keywords: RAPID TRANSIT - Magnetic Levitation; VEHICLES - Magnetic Levitation; Magnetic levitation
Correspondence Address: Jayawant, B.V.

Title: The detection and study of the visible spectrum of the aurora and airglow
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: University of Alaska, Geophysical Institute, Fairbanks, 99701, United States
Authors with affiliations: Romick, G.J., University of Alaska, Geophysical Institute, Fairbanks, 99701, United States
Abstract: Many different sophisticated instruments are used throughout the world in ground based, satellite and rocket studies of the visible spectrum of the aurora and airglow. Three different instruments, the all sky camera, spectrophotometer and meridian scanning photometer, serve as examples of the types of devices representing the photographic, spectrophotometer and photometric categories of instruments currently in use. The extensive application of digital techniques, solid state electronics, and minicomputers emphasizes the concept of system development that combines data acquisition and the capability for real time data reduction and analysis. © 1976 SPIE.
Index Keywords: Data acquisition; Meteorological instruments; Photometry; Radiometry; Rockets; All-sky; Digital techniques; Ground based; Real-time data; Solid state electronics; System development; Visible spectra; Spectrophotometers

Title: Laboratory Isotope Separators and Their Applications
Source title: Advances in Electronics and Electron Physics
Affiliations: Saha Institute of Nuclear Physics, Calcutta, India
Authors with affiliations: Karmohapatro, S.B., Saha Institute of Nuclear Physics, Calcutta, India
Abstract: Laboratory isotope separators originated from the principles of mass spectrometry and have reached a level of sophistication sufficient for separating stable isotopes for use in many experiments and for separating radioactive isotopes of very short duration. There is continuous development of different components, such as ion sources, focusing elements, collection methods oriented to needs for high efficiency, less contamination, and high resolution. A separator in one form or other can perform the separation of isotopes and can be used as a low energy accelerator for other applications or as a high-intensity mass spectrometer. It is possible to interchange the components of a separator to use it as a high or low intensity machine and to use it as a separator or an accelerator. Its applications cover a broad area in physics, including atomic physics, solid-state physics, and nuclear physics. On-line isotope separators and separators for ion implantation are developing rapidly for fruitful research in nuclear physics and solid state electronics; the impact of the latter in the industrial field has shown promising results. Further applications of isotope separators in radiation damage studies, radiation chemistry and surface chemistry studies, and as injectors for accelerators illustrate the versatility of the instruments. © 1976 Academic Press Inc.
Index Keywords: MASS SPECTROMETERS; ISOTOPES

Title: A review of industrial weighing systems (part 1)
Affiliations: Control Engineering Development, Imperial Chemical Industries Ltd, Plastics Division, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Lolley, R.A., Control Engineering Development, Imperial Chemical Industries Ltd, Plastics Division, United Kingdom
Abstract: Industrial weighing now covers a wide field and has developed separately from that of process instrumentation. Special areas have progressed independently resulting in spectacular advances which have taken full advantage of solid state electronics and computer technology. This review starts with five basic weighing methods and gives some examples of their use. Some miscellaneous theoretical points are then brought out concerning high-speed checkweighers, batch weighing, sack filling and weigh feeders. In conclusion, brief treatments of price computing counter scales, blending systems and weighing in motion are given which highlight the use of modern electronics and computers. A few further references are given. © 1976, The Institute of Measurement and Control. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: SCALES AND WEIGHING
Correspondence Address: Lolley, R.A.; Control Engineering Development, United Kingdom

Title: LEVEL AND DENSITY MEASUREMENT.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: This paper has summarised the applications for nuclear level and density measurement systems in the ore processing industry. The equipment technology associated with nuclear gauging has changed drastically from its inception. Today these gauges utilise proven solid state electronics which ensure reliable, accurate, drift-free measurement and contribute to increased recovery and lower operating costs.
Index Keywords: Ore treatment

Authors: Reger S.I., Smith B.M., Updike O.L.
Title: A photometric coagulometer
Affiliations: Division of Biomedical Engineering, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, 22901, Va, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reger, S.I., Division of Biomedical Engineering, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, 22901, Va, United States; Smith, B.M., Division of Biomedical Engineering, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, 22901, Va, United States; Updike, O.L., Division of Biomedical Engineering, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, 22901, Va, United States
Abstract: The reduction of transmitted light at 650 nm caused by scattering from fibrin polymers as they develop in a clotting plasma sample has proven effective for following the course of the coagulation. An instrument designed on this principle and using entirely solid-state electronics has yielded clotting time reproducible to within ±15%, and has enabled discrimination between induction and fibrin polymerisation times. Data on vapour-deposited and sputtered films of polytetrafluorethylene, under study as thromboresistant surfaces, are presented to illustrate the uses of this coagulometer. © 1976 International Federation for Medical & Biological Engineering.
Author Keywords: Coagulometer; Photometric clot detector; Plasma-clotting time; Thrombometer; Thromboresistance
Index Keywords: FLUORINE CONTAINING POLYMERS; PHOTOMETERS; COAGULOMETERS; PLASMA CLOTTING; POLYTETRAFLUORETHYLENE; THROMBORESISTANCE; BIOMEDICAL EQUIPMENT; blood clotting time; coagulometer; computer analysis; methodology; photometry; Blood Coagulation; Blood Coagulation Tests; In Vitro; Photometry; Time Factors

Title: Development of a Portable Polarograph for Determination of Aldehydes in Automotive Exhaust and Production Plant Samples
Affiliations: Dow Chemical Co., Michigan Division, Midland, Mich. 48640, United States; Dept. of Biochemistry, Michigan State University, East Lansing, Mich. 48824, United States
Authors with affiliations: McLean, J.D., Dow Chemical Co., Michigan Division, Midland, Mich. 48640, United States; Holland, J.F., Dept. of Biochemistry, Michigan State University, East Lansing, Mich. 48824, United States
Abstract: While commercial polarographic instruments are useful and sensitive laboratory analytical tools, they have found extremely limited applications in production facilities and on-stream analysis due to the complex and fragile nature of the accompanying equipment. A truly portable polarograph has been developed which overcomes these difficulties with no sacrifice in sensitivity and accuracy. The instrument, with solid state electronics, consists of a small package of about 10 lb. The strip chart recorder of the commercial version has been replaced by direct digital readout. Scan time has been reduced to 1 min. The dropping mercury electrode, with its cumbersome reservoir and stand tube, has been replaced with a small hanging mercury drop electrode with a self-contained mercury supply. The instrument is especially useful for monitoring aldehydes in both aqueous and nonaqueous chemical plant process streams, automotive exhaust, and in air samples where aldehyde pollution is suspected. © 1975, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: ALDEHYDES; AUTOMOBILE ENGINES - Exhaust Gases; POLAROGRAPHIC ANALYSIS; POLAROGRAPHS; AIR POLLUTION; environmental health
References: Lupton, J.M., Lych, C.C., (1944) J. Amer. Chem. Soc., 66, p. 697; Sawicki, E., Hauser, T.R., Stanley, T.W., Elbert, W., (1961) Anal. Chem., 33, p. 93; Papa, L.J., Turner, L.P., (1972) J. Chromatogr. Sci., 10, p. 747
Correspondence Address: McLean, J.D.; Dow Chemical Co., , Midland, Mich. 48640, United States

Title: The digital instrumentation node: An alternative to CAMAC
Affiliations: IBM Federal Systems Division, Owego, NY 13827, United States; Department of Physics, University of Kansas, Lawrence, Kansas 66045, United States
Authors with affiliations: Marple, M.J., IBM Federal Systems Division, Owego, NY 13827, United States; Culvahouse, J.W., Department of Physics, University of Kansas, Lawrence, Kansas 66045, United States
Abstract: During the development of a computer network for diverse real-time applications in physics and chemistry, a system was designed and developed to provide interfacing of instruments to each other as well as to a computer, and also to facilitate utilization of advanced solid state electronics in custom instruments. The result is a well-documented interfacing system with features and capabilities which are of growing importance in scientific and process instrumentation. This paper focuses attention on the distinctive features of the new system, features which are not usually available in CAMAC. These include the use of decentralized control, the addressing scheme, the monitor and control capabilities, the fast cycle time, and the simplicity of using the system. Copyright © 1975 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
References: Hardware for the Chemical Physics Trilevel Computer Network. (1974) Doctor of Engineering, Thesis by Melvyn J.
