Title: NEW CHLORINE GAS DETECTOR.
Source title: Instrumentation in the Aerospace Industry : Proceedings of the International Symposium
Authors with affiliations: Dailey, Leo L.
Abstract: A new electrometric chlorine gas leak detector is described, featuring a built-in sampling system, minimal maintenance due largely to a semi-permanent electrolyte, sensitivity to less than 1 ppm chlorine in air and solid state electronics including a local alarm and remote alarm capability. The detector was designed specifically for chlorine detection but it will respond also to other hazardous, strong oxidizing gases such as ozone, bromine and chlorine dioxide.
Index Keywords: AIR POLLUTION - Analysis; Gas detectors
Correspondence Address: Dailey, Leo L.
Conference name: Proc, 21st Int Instrum Symp, v 21/Adv in Test Meas, v 12

Title: SOLID STATE ELECTRONICS UPDATE THE EXTRUSION PLASTOMETER.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: This paper describes how to adapt an extrusion plastometer's timing system to solid state electronics and digital display. The improved electronic control is used for automatic determination of the melt flow rates in extrusion. Solid circuit details are given.
Index Keywords: Process control; RHEOMETERS - Circuits; Plastics

Title: SOLID STATE COMPONENTS IN ARC WELDING EQUIPMENT.
Authors with affiliations: Fernicola, R.C.
Abstract: In gas metal arc and submerged arc welding solid-state components have had a big impact in terms of improving performance; reducing cost and weight; increasing the number of features available; and extending the life of the equipment. The solid-state components allow a governor (motor speed regulator for a semiautomatic welding control to be built with excellent regulation (2-5%) over a large speed range (30:1) at low cost. This means greater range and more consistent performance at lower cost to the end user. Since the components generate little heat, they can be fully enclosed in a protective enclosure. To further protect the components, they can be encapsulated in a potting compound or sprayed with special insulating coatings, something impossible with vacuum tubes or relays. Another solid state device which is of great use in mechanized controls is the integrated circuit. For instance, in a typical mechanized gas metal arc welding control a number of integrated circuits on a single PC board gives it the capability of being programmed by depressing the correct tab on a small switch. Different modes of operation in gas metal-arc welding such as crater-fill, spot weld, and other features are possible. In a submerged arc control this programmability is also possible. However, the use of the solid-state electronics with its small size and low heat dissipation allows the control box to be small and totally enclosed. This keep out the flux and dirt normally associated with submerged arc welding.
Index Keywords: Solid state devices; Welding, Electric arc
Correspondence Address: Fernicola, R.C.

Title: Advances in the Microwave Domain of Solid-State Electronics. [POSTEPY W DZIEDZINIE MIKROFALOWEJ ELEKTRONIKI CIALA STALEGO.]
Authors with affiliations: Smolinski, Adam
Abstract: A status report and achievements in the development of microwave solid-state devices are reported. Parametric amplifiers, transistors, semiconductor diodes, integrated circuits and microwave acoustic devices are discussed.
Index Keywords: Microwave devices
Correspondence Address: Smolinski, Adam

Title: EXCHANGE AREA AND LOCAL LOOP TRANSMISSION.
Authors with affiliations: Danielson, Warren E.
Abstract: Highlights of progress in exchange area and local loop transmission include extension of the analytical approach to engineering of loops and trunks, taking into account the full array of transmission-affecting factors; more accurate measuring techniques; more economical materials and equipment; widely usable carrier and repeater techniques (made possible by the economies of solid-state electronics); digital transmission; centralized testing and maintenance (aided by minicomputers). For the future, equally far-reaching developments can be expected. For example, optical transmission over glass fibers appears to be a real possibility.
Index Keywords: Telephone systems
Correspondence Address: Danielson, Warren E.

Title: IEEE INTERCON TECHNICAL PROGRAM, PAPERS, VOLUMES 1 AND 2, 1974.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: The papers presented at this convention are published in two volumes. The technical and management program volume contains 122 papers; the manufacturing workshop volume contains 9 papers. The 36 sessions of the technical program include such topics as: domestic and international markets and costs; imaging with charge-transfer devices; CATV; radio-amateur space communication; automatic testing; point-of-sale systems; optical communications; technological forecasting; data base systems; microprocessor architectures; electronics packaging; maincomputer control of switching systems; computer storage; new microwave semiconductors; microprocessor applications; electric display systems; new telephone technology; electronics in earth and ocean physics programs; automotive solid-state electronics; data communication networks. The three workshop sessions are generally concerned with improving producibility. Specifically discussed are: solid-state components and methods of testing them; integrated circuits; aluminum electrolytic capacitors; optoelectronic components; fabricating, testing, and assembling printed wiring boards.
Index Keywords: Data processing; Electronic equipment; ELECTRONICS INDUSTRY - Marketing; Optical communication; Telephone; Electrical engineering

Title: AUTOMATIC SORTING & MACHINE PRODUCTIVITY.
Authors with affiliations: Gray Jr., Thomas A.
Abstract: The recent advances of solid state electronics have given the gage manufacturer a tremendous boost in providing more highly sophisticated, faster and very accurate measuring systems. This paper will cover the development, design and building of injector components. A breakthrough in the state of the art was accomplished in the design of non-contact air measurement combined with electronics, producing closely sized and matched components for assembly.
Index Keywords: Gages; Machine tools
Correspondence Address: Gray Jr., Thomas A.

Title: ATTACKING VOLTAGE FLUCTUATIONS WITH SOLID STATE ELECTRONICS
Authors with affiliations: FLANAGAN, D.B.
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Correspondence Address: FLANAGAN, D.B.

Title: APPLICATION OF COMPUTER SIMULATION IN TEACHING PHYSICAL ELECTRONICS.
Authors with affiliations: Liu, Hua-Kuang
Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to illustrate the concept and technique of how computer simulated programs of physical models may be used as teaching aids for students in the courses such as modern physics, quantum mechanics, and solid-state electronics. Experience in teaching the quantum electronics course at the University of Alabama is reported.
Index Keywords: PHYSICAL ELECTRONICS; Electrical engineering
Correspondence Address: Liu, Hua-Kuang

Title: ARTIFICIAL HEART RELIABILITY FACTORS.
Source title: American Astronautical Society, Scientific Technology Series
Authors with affiliations: Huffman, F.N.; Hagen, K.G.
Abstract: To be considered for clinical application, Implantable circulatory support systems should demonstrate operating lives of over 10**8 beats at high confidence levels with zero maintenance. This reliability must be accomplished within severe constraints of size and weight with limited opportunity for redundancy. This paper describes an implantable Plutonium-238 fueled heart assist system whose development is sponsored by the National Heart and Lung Institute. The power to drive the left ventricular assist pump, which also functions as a blood-cooled heat exchanger, is obtained by converting a fraction of the nuclear heat into hydraulic energy via a vapor cycle engine, termed the tidal regenerator engine (TRE). The TRE pressurization (typically from 5 to 150 psia) is controlled by the displacement of a water droplet by means of an electric motor. The electrical power for the sensor, electronic logic and motor is provided by a thermoelectric module. Reliability factors have been paramount in the formation of this system. Conventional valves and sliding seals have been eliminated. Mechanical simplicity has been achieved by using solid state electronics. Additional reliability considerations are reflected in the low speed (the TRE runs at the natural heart's beat rate), pressure-balanced and moderate temperature operating conditions. Development has reached the stage of in vivo testing.
Index Keywords: Biomedical engineering
Correspondence Address: Huffman, F.N.
Abbreviated Source Title: Am Astronaut Soc Sci Technol Ser

Title: Semiconductor Functional Devices. [POLPRZEWODNIKOWE PRZYRZADY FUNKCJONALNE.]
Authors with affiliations: Paszkowski, Bohdan
Abstract: Achievements obtained in Poland, associated with research activities in solid state electronics, are reported, with emphasis on semiconductor devices. Topics discussed include binary and decade counters, neuristors, logarithmic diodes, nanosecond diodes with heterojunction, optoelectronic and galvanomagnetic instruments, photodiodes and transistors.
Index Keywords: Electric measuring instruments; Semiconductor devices
Correspondence Address: Paszkowski, Bohdan

Title: Comfort Control for Central Electric Heating Systems
Affiliations: Concordia St., Wayzata Minn., United States; Honeywell, Inc., Minneapolis Minn., United States
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, V.R., Concordia St., Wayzata Minn., United States; Tobias, J.R., Honeywell, Inc., Minneapolis Minn., United States
Abstract: Central electric heating systems typically consist of a number of low-mass heating elements. Due to this low mass, fast rates of temperature rise and fall will occur in the furnace. The end result can be large and uncomfortable temperature swings in the living space. In order to provide good comfort, the control system used must take into account the characteristics of an electric furnace. An analog computer study was conducted to determine the best method of controlling an electric central heating system. The analog computer optimized the thermostat design parameters to provide the required end result of homeowner comfort and long heat equipment life. Since mechanical thermostats have practical limitations on minimum switching differentials and only solid-state electronics could overcome this difficulty, the computer optimized controller was built using integrated circuit electronics. A field test compared the performance of a conventional ON–OFF mechanical thermostat system with the new solid-state controller. The conventional system produced excessive room temperature swings of 3°F, while the new controller produced small swings of less than 1°F. © 1974 IEEE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: THERMOSTATS; HEATING

Authors: Zolner William J., Mager Daniel J., Helm Denis A.
Title: SOURCE LEVEL SO2 ANALYSIS VIA PULSED FLUORESCENCE.
Authors with affiliations: Zolner, William J.; Mager, Daniel J.; Helm, Denis A.
Abstract: A new instrumental method for the analysis of SO//2 in the range 0. 5 to 5000 ppm is explained. The method, termed ″pulsed fluorescence″ , utilizes the fluorescent emission of SO//2 molecules due to their being excited by a short, high intensity ultraviolet light pulse. Within the instrument, short bursts of ultraviolet light from a long life flash tube are used to excite the SO//2 molecules that have been drawn into a chamber. The SO//2 molecules then emit fluorescent radiation in direct proportion to their concentration. This in turn is detected by a high gain photomultiplier tube and is processed through solid state electronics to be displayed as a direct indication of SO//2 concentration in parts per million.
Index Keywords: SULFUR DIOXIDE - Recorders; Air pollution
Correspondence Address: Zolner, William J.
Conference name: ISA Anal Instrum Symp, 20th Annu, Proc

Title: The impact of solid-state electronics on the development of radar systems
Affiliations: Royal Radar Establishment, St. Andrews Road, Great Malvern, Worcestershire WR14 3PS, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Fielding, C.C., Royal Radar Establishment, St. Andrews Road, Great Malvern, Worcestershire WR14 3PS, United Kingdom; Roberts, J.B.G., Royal Radar Establishment, St. Andrews Road, Great Malvern, Worcestershire WR14 3PS, United Kingdom
Abstract: The paper indicates the status of radar at the date when the transistor was being developed and shows that the early impact of this device, because of its then limited performance, was primarily in the design of sub-systems to handle the large amount of data generated from radar receivers. I n this respect the invention of the transistor is inseparable from the development of the computer. During the 60s, however, the greater spectrum, together with improved performance, of semiconductor devices allowed for their penetration into all aspects of radar including in many instances the microwave power sources, to yield high performance, portability, reliability and lower cost per function. The paper concludes with a survey of possible future links between solid state electronics and radar systems. © 1973, The Institution of Electronic and Radio Engineers. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: RADAR SYSTEMS; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES; SOLID STATE DEVICES; RADAR CIRCUITS
References: SKOLNIK, M.L., (1962) ‘Introduction to Radar Systems’, , McGraw-Hill, New York; COOK, C.E., BERNFELD, M., (1967) ‘Radar Signals—an Introduction to Theory and Applications’, , Academic Press, New York; BARTON, D.K., (1964) ‘Radar Systems Analysis’, , Prentice-Hall, Englewood Cliffs, N.J; Fitchen, F.C., (1970) ‘Electronic Integrated Circuits and Systems’, , Van Nostrand Reinhold, New York; SHURMER, H.V., (1971) ‘Microwave Semiconductor Devices’, , Pitman, London; WATSON, H.A., (1969) ‘Microwave Semiconductor Devices and their Circuit Applications’, , McGraw-Hill, New York; (1963) IEE Conference on Electronics Research and Development for Civil Aviation; SKOLNIK, M.I., (1970) ‘Radar Handbook’, , McGraw-Hill, New York; BULMAN, P.J., HOBSON, G.S., TAYLOR, B.C., (1972) ‘Transferred Electron Devices’, , Academic Press, New York; KINO, G.S., MATTHEWS, H., ‘Signal processing in acoustic surface wave devices’ (1971) IEEE Spectrum, 8, pp. 22-25. , August; HAGER, R.O., (1970) ‘Synthetic Aperture Radar Systems—Theory and Design’, , Academic Press, New York; OLIVER, A.A., KITTEL, G.H., (1972) ‘Phased Array Antennas’, , Artech House, Dedham, Mass

Title: DEVELOPMENT AND APPLICATION OF RADIO TELEMETRY FOR THE SOLUTION OF NAVAL MACHINERY PROBLEMS.
Authors with affiliations: Tolotta, Samuel
Abstract: With the advent of solid state electronics, it became possible to build sophisticated radio telemetry systems which could operate in severe environmental conditions such as high centrifugal force and high temperature. This led to the development and application of telemetry for use in resolving many rotating machinery problems. This paper will discuss some early problems encountered in telemetry systems, improvements that were made and recent developments. There is a description of some applications of this type of instrumentation for the measurement of shaft horsepower, torsional vibration, cable tension, displacement, temperature, etc. in various types of equipment. The results of these studies demonstrate that telemetry is a reliable and practical tool for solving many machinery problems.
Index Keywords: MACHINERY PROBLEMS; Ship propulsion
Correspondence Address: Tolotta, Samuel
Publisher: Mar Eng Soc in Jpn, Tokyo
Conference name: Int Symp on Mar Eng, Proc, Nov 12-15 1973 Tech Sess 3-3,, Sess 3-3

Title: FUTURE TRENDS IN SOLID STATE ELECTRONICS.
Authors with affiliations: Triebwasser, S.
Abstract: The pace of development in silicon planar technology continues at an anomalously high rate considering its level of maturity. The prospects for this technology during the seventies will be reviewed in the context of digital system requirements. Comparisons will be made with magnetic and cryogenic based technologies during this same time frame and beyond. Impact of hardware developments on systems will be discussed.
Index Keywords: Solid state devices
Correspondence Address: Triebwasser, S.
Conference name: Solid State Devices, Int Conf, 5th, Proc

Title: Computers and technology: Aiding tomorrow’s aged
Affiliations: Human Development, Duke University Medical Center, Box 3003, Durham, 27710, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ramm, D., Human Development, Duke University Medical Center, Box 3003, Durham, 27710, United States; Gianturco, D.T., Human Development, Duke University Medical Center, Box 3003, Durham, 27710, United States
Abstract: This paper investigates the future role of technology in meeting the needs of the elderly in such areas as transportation, medical care, housing, and protection from crime. Technological advances in solid state electronics allowing computers on a single chip of silicon, bringing down the price of mass memories and expediting cable TV and other means of communications, are explored for possible aids to the elderly. An increasing awareness of technological advances is advocated for gerontologists. © 1973 The Gerontological Society of America.
Index Keywords: age; aged; computer; computer analysis; Aged; Computers; Human; Technology

Title: NEW DEVELOPMENTS IN COIL WINDING.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: A new coil winding machine is capable of guiding the wire to an accuracy of one micron per revolution and, at winding speeds of up to 20,000 rpm, and can achieve turns accuracy of 100 percent. The unit incorporates solid state electronics and provides easy changeover from one coil to another.
Index Keywords: Wire

Authors: Neer Roy H., Brenza Robert M.
Title: SCRs IN LARGE MOTOR DRIVES.
Authors with affiliations: Neer, Roy H.; Brenza, Robert M.
Abstract: High-power SCRs and many new electronic components have recently been developed by solid state electronics manufacturers. This paper examines the application of these new devices in converters for large dc motors, based on design and practical experience with actual working equipment.
Index Keywords: Electric drive; Electric rectifiers, Solid state; SCR; Electric motors, DC

Title: Trends in chromatographic automation
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, University of California, Livermore, 94550, California, United States
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, R.E., Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, University of California, Livermore, 94550, California, United States
Abstract: The rapid growth and extensive utilization of chromatography as an analytical method has necessitated improvement of the associated data reduction process. More prompt final data and increased accuracy demand automated techniques. The development of modern solid-state electronics has enabled computer-aided solutions to chromatographic data reduction problems. Increasing software costs and decreasing hardware production costs couple to give new solutions - small calculator-like systems and large distributed computer systems. Currently available U. S. system types will be surveyed and future trends will be conjectured. © 1972 Friedr. Vieweg & Sohn GmbH.

Title: Design and testing of the american airlines prototype b-747 AIDS system
Affiliations: American Airlines, Tulsa, OK, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kruckenberg, H.D., American Airlines, Tulsa, OK, United States
Abstract: American is currently entering the evaluation phase of its B-747 AIDS (Aircraft Integrated Data System) Program. Prior experience focused attention upon the number of engine parameters to be monitored including parameter accuracy and repeatability. The B-747 prototype system design utilizes increased sampling rates, improved sensors and transducers, and solid state electronics. Analysis of AIDS engine data indicates that the increased sampling rates are required for engine pressure measurements but that the high sampling rates for engine speed are not required. Preliminary results indicate that the increased number of engine parameters will allow isolation of faults to particular engine components such as the high compressor, low turbine, etc. The experience gained to date from this program is portrayed including the status of the B-747 AIDS program objectives. Data utilization is briefly discussed. © 1972 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc., All rights reserved.

Title: Design and evolution of a 60-KW, 400-HZ generator set
Source title: Proceedings of the ASME Turbo Expo
Affiliations: Solar Division of International Harvester Co., San Diego, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: McEachern, A.B., Solar Division of International Harvester Co., San Diego, CA, United States
Abstract: The EMU-30/E generator set was developed and produced under contract to the USAF for use in the 407L Tactical Air Control System. For this application, two generator sets, complete with auxiliary equipment, are installed on a pallet to form an A/E24U-8 power plant. One EMU-30/E generator set provides the precise 400Hz power required for the 3-D radar, computers, communications system, and air conditioning; the second set is on "standby" and will automatically start and assume the electrical load if the operating unit malfunctions. Due to the broad range of operating conditions, precise power limits, high reliability, and low maintenance requirements of the 407L System, the design of the EMU-30/E generator set had to incorporate certain unique features such as solid-state electronic controls, winterization equipment, automatic fault shotdown, and automatic paralleling capabilities. The design concept was based on using proven equipment, such as the Titan gas turbine engine, an alternator, and advanced electronic controls, all packaged into a compact and rugged enclosure and featuring low maintenance requirements and ease of servicing. Copyright © 1972 by ASME.

Title: Substation Insulator Failure Prevention by Ultrasonic Corona Detection
Affiliations: The author is with the Glass Division, PPG Industries, Cumberland, Md., 21502, United States
Authors with affiliations: Frederick, W., The author is with the Glass Division, PPG Industries, Cumberland, Md., 21502, United States
Abstract: Ultrasonic detection of electrical corona discharge has become an important and useful tool for the detection of faulty insulators. The ultrasonic test unit consists of a hand-held probe-microphone responsive to acoustic energy in the 36- to 44-kHz range and is battery powered. Solid-state electronics translate high-frequency sonics to the audible range and provide amplification through a speaker or headset. The characteristics associated with a phenomenon are preserved through translation. Energy released at 40 kHz by corona or arcing is recognizable as the familiar “frying” sound. Similarly, air pressure leaks emit “hissing” sounds at 40 kHz. Application of this principal has resulted in the replacement of numerous insulators before occurrence of serious electrical failures. Minute inspections and tests revealed porcelain cracks and mechanical imperfections that would have eventually resulted in critical electrical faults. Similarly, leaks have been eliminated in compressed air systems, thereby reducing compressor service demands. Copyright © 1972 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC INSULATORS--Testing
References: Electrical industries (1963) Americana Ann., p. 220.; Electric utility methods (1967) Elec. World, 167, p. 66. , Jan. 9; (1961) American Standard C29.1, Amer. Stand. Ass.

Title: New processes deserve practical appraisal
Authors with affiliations: ADAMS MJ
Abstract: Welding processes using the latest aids such as friction, electron beams, lasers, explosives and diffusion bonding are successfully competing with conventional methods in a steadily increasing number of applications. They can cut production costs on tough jobs, simplify manufacture of complex components, and give design engineers far more freedom in configuration and materials. Many production engineers, it seems, still regard these newer techniques as devices for the laboratory or for specialized jobs in the aerospace and solid- state electronics industries.
Index Keywords: Welding
Correspondence Address: ADAMS MJ

Title: Optical tachometry for monitoring nuclear magnetic resonance sample spinning rates
Source title: Journal of Physics E: Scientific Instruments
Affiliations: Polymer Sciences Laboratories, Boeing Scientific Research Laboratories, Seattle, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pratt, T.J., Polymer Sciences Laboratories, Boeing Scientific Research Laboratories, Seattle, WA, United States; Brooks, S.D., Polymer Sciences Laboratories, Boeing Scientific Research Laboratories, Seattle, WA, United States
Abstract: A simple optical tachometer utilizing fibre optics and solid state electronics has been designed and constructed in order to monitor sample turbine spin speeds on a Varian HA 100D nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometer. By use of a bifurcated fibre optical path, light is transmitted to the turbine strobe, modulated, and returned to the detector within the same plastic-sheated glass fibre bundle. Rotational information can thus be retrieved without disturbing the magnetic field or sample environment. The relation of sample spinning speed to spectral quality is discussed.

Title: The equivalent circuit model in solid-state electronics-III. Conduction and displacement currents
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Materials Research Laboratory, University of Illinois, Urbana, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sah, C.T., Department of Electrical Engineering, Materials Research Laboratory, University of Illinois, Urbana, United States
Abstract: The equilibrium and nonequilibrium equivalent circuits of a single and a multiple energy level recombination centers were developed in parts I and II. This paper extends the analysis to include the nonequilibrium case arising from a d.c. steady state conduction current in the semiconductor structure. Application is made to minority carrier small signal transport in both homogeneous and heterogeneous semiconductors at low steady state levels (P « N in n-type sample). Samples containing p-n junctions are not included but the effect of static, built-in electric field on the signal propagation is considered. In an extrinsic sample, it is shown that the nonequilibrium equivalent circuit is identical to the equilibrium case for considering carrier trapping, recombination and generation at the defect or impurity centers if the recombination conductances and capacitances are defined in terms of the steady-state carrier concentrations. The conditions on the properties of the imperfection centers and the frequency range in which trapping, recombination or generation event dominates at the centers are discussed in detail. It is shown that the effective small-signal minority carrier lifetime, τp in n-type semiconductor, is a complex variable due to the charge storage or trapping effect at the centers. In addition, τp is positional dependent due to the spatial variation of the steady state carrier concentrations. The small-signal lifetime, τp, is substantially different from the steady state lifetime τpSS which is commonly used in high-frequency, lumped-model device analysis. For strongly extrinsic samples with low concentration of recombination centers, the usual approximation, τp {reversed tilde equals} τpSS {reversed tilde equals} τp0 = 1/cpNTT, is valid. The lump model approximation to a specimen of length W is rigorously derived for minority carrier transport. It is shown that the commonly used stored-charge lump model is valid only at low frequency and zero recombination when the sample is geometrically divided into two or more lumps. For finite recombination, the effective length of each lump is shorter than at zero recombination and the sum of the length of each lump is less than the physical length of the sample. © 1970.

Title: PUTTING SOLID-STATE ELECTRONICS TO WORK IN GRINDING MACHINE CONTROL
Authors with affiliations: WESPI GE
Abstract: The article discusses systems of machine tools control other than numerically controlled systems. This control is used for manufacture of mass produced parts by replacing hydraulic actuators and magnetic relays with more reliable and flexible solid-state electronic circuits. Various designs have been treated. All advantages offered by computer control such as electric feed systems, electronic in-process gages and high power variable- frequency drives are listed and compared with n/c system.
Index Keywords: Grinding machines
Correspondence Address: WESPI GE

Authors: Bean A.R., Newman R.C., Smith R.S.
Title: Electron irradiation damage in silicon containing carbon and oxygen
Source title: Journal of Physics and Chemistry of Solids
Affiliations: J.J. Thomson Physical Laboratory, Whiteknights, Reading, RG6 2AF England, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bean, A.R., J.J. Thomson Physical Laboratory, Whiteknights, Reading, RG6 2AF England, United Kingdom; Newman, R.C., J.J. Thomson Physical Laboratory, Whiteknights, Reading, RG6 2AF England, United Kingdom; Smith, R.S., J.J. Thomson Physical Laboratory, Whiteknights, Reading, RG6 2AF England, United Kingdom
Abstract: Infra-red absorption bands have been measured in the range 1-25 μm for a large number of silicon samples containing oxygen and carbon impurities after various doses of irradiation at room temperature by 2 MeV electrons. Measurements have been made of the removal rates of oxygen and carbon from normal unperturbed interstitial and substitutional sites respectively, and similar results are presented for the growth of the A-centre and divacancy bands. The presence of oxygen increases the carbon removal rate as defined above and likewise the presence of carbon increases the removal rate for oxygen and leads to a large increase in the rate of formation of divacancies. It is concluded that carbon traps interstitial silicon atoms and is then itself ejected into interstitial sites in the manner previously found for group 111 impurities. The interstitial carbon appears to be mobile at room temperature and a large number of new vibrational bands have been observed. Several new bands thought to be of electronic origin and involving carbon atoms have also been detected. © 1970.
Index Keywords: PHYSICS, Solid State; SEMICONDUCTORS, Optical Properties; SEMICONDUCTORS, Silicon; SILICON AND ALLOYS, Electronic Properties; DEFECT PROPERTIES OF SOLIDS; SOLID STATE ELECTRONICS; SILICON AND ALLOYS--Irradiation

Authors: Clem T.R., Berger R.L., Ross P.D.
Title: A differential adiabatic microcalorimeter for the study of heats of transition in solution
Affiliations: Biomedical Engineering and Instrumentation Branch, Division of Research Services; Laboratory of Technical Development, National Heart Institute; Laboratory of Molecular Biology, National Institute of Arthritis and Metabolic Diseases, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD 20014
Authors with affiliations: Clem, T.R., Biomedical Engineering and Instrumentation Branch, Division of Research Services; Berger, R.L., Laboratory of Technical Development, National Heart Institute; Ross, P.D., Laboratory of Molecular Biology, National Institute of Arthritis and Metabolic Diseases, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD 20014
Abstract: A differential adiabatic calorimeter for the study of heats of transition in solution is described. The demonstrated sensitivity of the apparatus is such that a heat effect of 35 cal/liter occurring over a temperature range of 7°C was determined with a precision of ±2%. The results agreed with other reported work. The instrument employs solid state electronics and it may be operated from -10 to 90°C. © 1969 The American Institute of Physics.
Index Keywords: CALORIMETERS; MEDICAL EQUIPMENT AND SUPPLIES
Correspondence Address: Clem, T.R.; Biomedical Engineering and Instrumentation Branch,

Title: Use of Frequencies Above 10 GHz for Common Carrier Applications
Authors with affiliations: Tillotson, L.C.
Abstract: We discuss problems and opportunities inherent in the use of frequencies above 10 GHz for common carrier applications. We also argue that if short hops are used to ameliorate the severe attenuation caused by excessive rain‐fall and if integrated solid‐state electronics are used to achieve cost and reliability goals, a viable system can result. Interference‐tolerant modulation methods and high performance antennas are used in order to permit many repeaters to operate co‐channel in a restricted geographical area. The paper also includes several references to other papers in this issue and elsewhere which describe studies and experiments conducted to demonstrate feasibility of the system concept and components and subassemblies designed especially for broadband short‐hop system application. © 1969 The Bell System Technical Journal
Correspondence Address: Tillotson, L.C.

Title: The microelectronics laboratory at the Technion
Affiliations: The Technion, Haifa, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Bar-Lev, A., The Technion, Haifa, Israel; Klein, N., The Technion, Haifa, Israel
Abstract: The development and activities of the Microelectronics Laboratory at the Technion are described. This Laboratory is the basis for teaching and research in solid state electronics and helps industry in development projects. © 1969.

Authors: McMillan P.W., Partridge G., Ward F.R.
Title: Glass-ceramics for the coating and bonding of silicon semiconductor material
Affiliations: Nelson Research Laboratories, The English Electric Co. Ltd., Beaconhill, Stafford, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: McMillan, P.W., Nelson Research Laboratories, The English Electric Co. Ltd., Beaconhill, Stafford, United Kingdom; Partridge, G., Nelson Research Laboratories, The English Electric Co. Ltd., Beaconhill, Stafford, United Kingdom; Ward, F.R., Nelson Research Laboratories, The English Electric Co. Ltd., Beaconhill, Stafford, United Kingdom
Abstract: Workers in the field of microminiature solid state electronics are interested in the possible use of glass-ceramics for the coating and bonding of silicon semiconductor material in the fabrication of integrated circuit devices. The glass-ceramics must be able to withstand temperatures of 1100-1200°C and should be reasonably well matched in expansion to silicon. It has been shown that glass-ceramics of the ZnO-Al2O3-SiO2 type containing proportions of CaO, BaO or B2O3 give materials which are matched in linear thermal expansion characteristics to silicon and which can be applied to pre-oxidized silicon at temperatures in the region of 1200°C to give smooth, adherent coatings on the silicon, the coatings being refractory at temperatures in excess of 1100°C. The glass-ceramics can also be used to bond together pieces of silicon using similar firing schedules to those used to provide the coatings on silicon. By suitable choice of the firing conditions and control of the thickness of the silicon oxide interlayer, the attack by the glass-ceramic on the underlying silicon can be reduced to a negligible amount. The glass-ceramics of the types examined have been shown to have high volume resistivities (greater than 108 ω cm at 500°C) and can resist the environmental conditions likely to be encountered in diffusion processes. © 1969.
Correspondence Address: McMillan, P.W.; Nelson Research Laboratories, Beaconhill, Stafford, United Kingdom

Title: Large-scale integration and the revolution in electronics
Affiliations: IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY, United States

Title: Trends in rural communications
Authors with affiliations: HITT RE
Abstract: A review of technical changes and progress of rural telephony in the United States from 1950 is presented. The introduction of dial operation; development of buried cables, eliminating many pole lines; and the use of solid state electronics and computer sciences is discussed.
Index Keywords: Telephone
Correspondence Address: HITT RE

Title: VOLUME LIMITED PAEDIATRIC RESPIRATOR
Authors with affiliations: LEWEY GR; BULLUS PB
Abstract: A pediatric respirator has been specifically designed for the small patient, and therefore has the required sensitivity, speed and accuracy to achieve the best results with infants and to eliminate the problems of using an adult respirator on newborns and young children. All solid state electronics has been used in the electrical system.

Title: A new "fuel" gage for electrically powered vehicles
Affiliations: Curtis Instruments, Inc., United States
Authors with affiliations: Beusman, C.C., Curtis Instruments, Inc., United States; Finger, E.P., Curtis Instruments, Inc., United States
Abstract: New techniques, using a special capacitive readout version of the Curtis mercury coulometer, are being used in an ampere-hour meter for rechargeable battery systems. The circuit meets one definition of the "perfect fuel" gage for battery powered vehicles. The unit consists of a small solid-state electronics module driving an indicating meter. It is powered from the battery and will directly and automatically indicate ampere-hours discharged and charged. The unit has an automatic stop when the meter displays "full" or 100% of capacity to permit a safe overcharge situation. Additionally, the unit can provide alarms and detectors for low capacity signals or auxiliary charge control functions. The system is currently under test on a number of battery-powered vehicle programs.
Index Keywords: Gages; Vehicles; Battery powered; Capacitive readout; Charge control; Solid state electronics; Secondary batteries
Correspondence Address: Beusman, C.C.; Curtis Instruments, United States
Conference name: Mid-Year Meeting

Title: Solid state ignition
Affiliations: Motorola Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hufton, A.G., Motorola Inc, United States
Abstract: The author presents a brief description of a present day automotive ignition system with an explanation of its various components. The moving parts of the ignition system such as the distributor shaft which is driven from the cam shaft, centrifugal weights which move the cam, vacuum advance mechanism, and rubbing block with breaker points and rotor can and will be eliminated with the aid of solid state electronics. An analysis of the ignition coil and factors influencing its design as well as its vital part in the present-day system is reviewed. Also mentioned briefly are the transistor system and capacitor discharge ignition system and their current state of application. It is believed that solid state devices and integrated circuits will develop greater reliability and greater cost advantages for the consumer.
Index Keywords: Cams; Solid state devices; Capacitor discharge; Cost advantages; Ignition coils; Moving parts; Solid state electronics; Ignition systems
Correspondence Address: Hufton, A.G.; Motorola IncUnited States

Authors: Severns R.P., Turner T.F., Koelle A.R.
Title: Crossing high-voltage inerfaces with large bandwidth signals
Affiliations: Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Severns, R.P., Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, Mexico; Turner, T.F., Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, Mexico; Koelle, A.R., Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, Mexico
Abstract: In connection with a 50-kV modulatordevelopment, three methods of crossing the high-voltage interfaces at a 1-MHz bandwidth are being developed. The first system uses a pulse transformer driven from ground by solid-state electronics. The transfomer requires special design to obtain a very short (≈500 ns) risetime combined with the ability to maintain a 1000-µs, 200-V pulse with negligible droop. The second system is an amplitude-modulated rf carrier operating at 5 MHz. The interface is crossed with an untuned toroidal rf transfomer. Increased bandwidth is obtained by placing the carrier at the lower edge of the passband and operating in the single sideband full carrier mode. The signal is demodulated with a balanced diode detector having a peak output of +200 V and good linearity. The third method uses a Hewlett-Packard HPA-4309 electro-optical isolator with solid-state amplifier on the high-voltage side. The intrinsic bandwidth of the isolator unit is ~ -10 MHz. With suitable amplifiers to bring the pulse up to +200-V peak, the bandwidth is ~ 2 MHz. Because the interface is crossed at a verylow level reaching an adequate signal-to-noise ratio has presented special problems. All three systems should be useful on a wide variety of high-voltage laboratory machines; each has special advantages depending on the particular application. Copyright © 1967 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

Title: A Solid-State Synchronous Switch for Use in Transient and Modeling Studies
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
Affiliations: Kuljian Corporation Private Ltd., Calcutta, India; Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Wisconsin, Milwakee, Wis., United States; Allis-Chalmers Company, Milwaukee, Wis., United States; Network Calculator Laboratory, University of Wisconsin, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bhaumik, A.K., Kuljian Corporation Private Ltd., Calcutta, India, Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Wisconsin, Milwakee, Wis., United States, Allis-Chalmers Company, Milwaukee, Wis., United States, Network Calculator Laboratory, University of Wisconsin, United States
Abstract: This paper describes a new synchronous switch employing solid-state electronics, that extends the usefulness of the CRO in viewing transient phenomena in electrical circuits by means of a repetitive trace on the CRO. This device is particularly useful in normal research projects and has a unique place in repetitive and “one-time” switching in power system models such as the conventional transient analyzer and the newer EHV simulators. Copyright © 1967 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

Title: The Equivalent Circuit Model in Solid-State Electronics—Part I: The Single Energy Level Defect Centers
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering and Materials Research Laboratory, University of Illinois, Urbana, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sah, C.-T., Department of Electrical Engineering and Materials Research Laboratory, University of Illinois, Urbana, United States
Abstract: The equivalent circuit model is developed in this series of papers and applied to solid-state junction devices. In this paper, the exact equivalent circuit of a single energy level defect center in a semiconductor is developed based on the Shockley-Read-Hall model. It is then applied to the calculation of the steady-state lifetimes of electrons and holes and to the transient decay time constants. The transient decay time constants are obtained for arbitrary nonequilibrium, but steady-state, conditions and are presented as a function of the steady-state electron and hole concentrations by means of contour maps. Simple examples and gold in silicon are used for the construction of these maps. The general criteria of trapping, recombination, and generation are also obtained using the single energy level defect center model which divides the carrier concentration plane log10N versus log10 P into four quadrants centered at the equality carrier concentrations p*and n*. At this equality point the four rates of electron or hole capture or emission at the defect center are equal and the four quadrants represent regions where recombination, generation, electron trapping, or hole trapping dominates. Copyright © 1967 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Correspondence Address: Sah, C.-T.; Department of Electrical Engineering and Materials Research Laboratory, University of Illinois, Urbana, United States

Title: The Equivalent Circuit Model in Solid-State Electronics—Part II: The Multiple Energy Level Impurity Centers
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering and Materials Research Laboratory, University of Illinois, Urbana, Ill., United States
Authors with affiliations: Sah, C.-T., Department of Electrical Engineering and Materials Research Laboratory, University of Illinois, Urbana, Ill., United States
Abstract: In this paper, the equivalent circuit of a defect center with multiple energy levels in a semiconductor is formulated and applied to the calculation of the characteristic time constants of the multiple energy level system. Detailed numerical example of gold-doped silicon is given, including the constant characteristic time constant contour maps. The steady-state charge distribution ratio R N = N s + 1/ N s (s = charge state of the center) and recombination rate ratio R R(s) = R ss(s =1/2)/(R ss(s -1/2) diagrams are developed and appliecl to the numerical calculations of the steady-state recombination and generation rate of electrons and holes in gold-doped silicon. Copyright © 1967 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Correspondence Address: Sah, C.-T.; Department of Electrical Engineering, Materials Research Laboratory, University of Illinois, Urbana, Ill., United States

Title: The Role of Network Theory in Solid-State Electronics-Accomplishments and Future Challenges
Affiliations: Dept. of Electrical Engineering, New York University, N. Y., United States
Authors with affiliations: Mulligan, J.H., Dept. of Electrical Engineering, New York University, N. Y., United States
Abstract: Some major accomplishments in active network theory are summarized, and certain developments in network theory which are relevant to solid-state electronics are reviewed. Specific problem areas are identified in which theoretical advances would yield important guidelines for development, as well as optimal utilization, of solid-state devices. Detailed suggestions are made for research investigations dealing with distributed networks and integrated circuits, statistical network theory, and multivariable network theory. The last named area is defined as that dealing with methods of combining analytically, in a manner which permits systematic synthesis of prescribed network functions and realization of optimal system performance, the variables at external terminals; the acoustical, electrical, mechanical, optical, and thermal properties of device materials; and arbitrarily imposed constraints. © 1963, IEEE. All right reserved.
Correspondence Address: Mulligan, J.H.; Dept. of Electrical Engineering, New York University, N. Y., United States

Title: The coming era of microelectronics
Source title: Proceedings of the 16th Annual Symposium on Frequency Control
Affiliations: U. S. Army Signal Research and Development Laboratory, Fort Monmouth, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meindl, J.D., U. S. Army Signal Research and Development Laboratory, Fort Monmouth, NJ, United States; Tobman, M., U. S. Army Signal Research and Development Laboratory, Fort Monmouth, NJ, United States
Abstract: Solid state electronics is now at the threshold of the era of microelectronics. The salient feature of microelectronics is integration typified by the "functional device". A functional device consists of an interconnected array of conventional devices - transistors, diodes, capacitors, and resistors - fabricated in situ within a single crystal of silicon with the capability of performing a complete electronic circuit function. The most promising applications of functional devices are in digital circuits and systems where they provide potential reliability, cost, size, and weight advantages over conventional circuit techniques. Title: Automatic Spectral Compensation of an Audio System Operating with a Random Noise Input
Affiliations: MB Electronics, Div. of Textron Electronics, Inc., New Haven, Conn., United States
Authors with affiliations: Maki, C.E., MB Electronics, Div. of Textron Electronics, Inc., New Haven, Conn., United States
Abstract: A set of 80 filters is used to divide a random noise input spectrum of an audio system into 25 cps increments. An identical set operating as a spectrum analyzer provides a similar function on the system output. By means of an automatic regulating system using solid-state electronics, each of the 80 loops is closed independently, thus providing a unique control system compensating the audio system spectrum and equalizing disturbing resonance phenomena. This method has been successfully applied to the control of a vibration system spectrum where mechanical resonances at the exciter table produce high Q peaks and notches. The degree of spectral flatness reveals that adequate compensation is possible for typical resonance phenomena occurring over a wide frequency range. Title: The Electronic Energy Band Structure of Silicon and Germanium
Affiliations: RCA Labs., Princeton, N. J., United States
Authors with affiliations: Herman, F., RCA Labs., Princeton, N. J., United States
Abstract: This article, which is of a tutorial character, is concerned with three broad subjects: (a) the theory of electronic energy bands in a perfect crystal; (b) the electronic energy band structure of silicon and germanium crystals; and (c) the relationship between some of the electrical and optical properties of these crystals and their energy band schemes. The article is essentially an introduction to the quantum theory of crystals, with silicon and germanium serving as illustrative examples. As such, the article should appeal particularly to electronic engineers and physicists working in the field of solid state electronics. A knowledge of quantum mechanics is probably not essential to the understanding of major portions of this paper. The following topics are treated: Crystal symmetry and crystal geometry; electronic quantum states in a perfect crystal; the energy band scheme; occupancy of the electronic quantum states; the hole concept; the effective mass tensor; velocity and acceleratibn of electrons and holes; the spin-orbit interaction and its consequences; the energy band structures of silicon and germanium; the band structure of germanium-silicon alloys; theory of lattice vibrations; the phonon concept; collisions between electrons or holes and phonons; the electrical conductivity; optical absorption and emission processes. © 1955 IEEE. All rights reserved.
Correspondence Address: Herman, F.; RCA Labs., Princeton, N. J., United States

Title: Solid state electronics
Authors with affiliations: Breckenridge, R.G.
Abstract: Recent developments in semiconductor physics, especially the discovery of the transistor (See William Shockley's article, Holes and Electrons, in the October, 1950, issue of Physics Today), have greatly stimulated the entire field of solid state electronics. The present article reviews recent work in this subject at the National Bureau of Standards. © 1951, American Institute of Physics. All rights reserved.
